 title : The pycommoncrypto Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AboutCommon Crypto bindings for Python (pycommoncrypto) provides a wrapper to Mac OS X&#39;s CommonCrypto (libSystem) digest library. </p>

<p>Fast hash functions available is this module are: </p>

<p>MD2 MD4 MD5 SHA1 SHA224 SHA256 SHA384 SHA512 </p>

<p>InstallTo install pycommoncrypto into your Mac download the sources and extract the compressed tarball. The build process is straightforward as typing make and then make install. </p>

<p>Pre-built package for Snow Leopard is also available, thanks to Rudix! Get the installation package here: http://rudix.org/packages-opq.html#pycommoncrypto </p>

<p>Testing the installation: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; import CommonCrypto
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; md5 = CommonCrypto.MD5()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; md5.init()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; md5.update(&#39;abc&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; md5.final()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print md5.digest
<br/>?P?&gt;&gt; print md5.hexdigest()
<br/>900150983cd24fb0d6963f7d28e17f72There are many functions to calculate hashes </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; print CommonCrypto.md5(&#39;abc&#39;)
<br/>?P?&gt;&gt; print CommonCrypto.digest2hex(CommonCrypto.md5(&#39;abc&#39;))
<br/>900150983cd24fb0d6963f7d28e17f72
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print CommonCrypto.digest2hex(CommonCrypto.sha256(&#39;abc&#39;))
<br/>ba7816bf8f01cfea414140de5dae2223b00361a396177a9cb410ff61f20015ad</p>
 title : The pykeynote Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pykeynote is a Python extension module for KeyNote.  It provides a high-level object-oriented interface to the KeyNote trust management API.  From the KeyNote web page: </p>

<p>Trust management is a unified approach to specifying and interpreting security 
<br/>policies, credentials, and relationships; it allows direct authorization of 
<br/>security-critical actions.  KeyNote credentials describe a specific delegation of 
<br/>trust and subsume the role of public key certificates; unlike traditional certificates, 
<br/>which bind keys to names, credentials can bind keys directly to the authorization to  
<br/>perform specific tasks. 
<br/>For more information on KeyNote see RFC 2704, keynote(1), keynote(3), keynote(4) and keynote(5). Also, a nice introductory article can be found here. </p>

<p>Although I have developed pykeynote on Linux and minimally tested it on OpenBSD, it will probably work on all Unix-like systems that satisfy the following requirements: </p>

<p>Python version 2.3 or higher. Pyrex version 0.9.4 or higher (optional). The KeyNote trust management system (tested with version 2.3). The OpenSSL cryptographic toolkit (tested with version 0.9.8d). </p>

<p>For the details you can browse the SVN repository; I have included a comprehensive testsuite and a sample application.  There is also the epydoc generated API documentation to help you start coding. </p>

<p>If you are having problems installing KeyNote and pykeynote, Adam Aviv has written detailed instructions for installing both. </p>

<p>The trunk of the SVN repository contains the latest, probably unstable, code.  Nonetheless you may still choose to use it for possible new features and/or bug fixes.  For more details, see the ChangeLog. </p>

<p>Patroklos Argyroudis, argp at domain cs.tcd.ie, http://ntrg.cs.tcd.ie/~argp/.</p>

 title : The qrbgerl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple Erlang client for the Quantum Random Bit Generator service.  Example usage: </p>

<p>Eshell V5.5.4  (abort with ^G)
<br/>1&gt; c(qrbg).
<br/>{ok,qrbg}
<br/>2&gt; {ok, Socket} = qrbg:connect().
<br/>{ok,#Port}
<br/>3&gt; Response = qrbg:get_response(Socket, &quot;username&quot;, &quot;password&quot;).
<br/>&lt;&gt;
<br/>4&gt; {ok, _Response, _Reason, _Length, Data} = qrbg:extract_data(Response).
<br/>{ok,0,
<br/>    0,
<br/>    4096,
<br/>    &lt;&gt;}
<br/>5&gt; {Int, RestData} = qrbg:extract_int(Data).
<br/>{-427507221,
<br/> &lt;&gt;}
<br/>6&gt; Int.
<br/>-427507221
<br/>7&gt; {Int2, MoreRestData} = qrbg:extract_int(RestData).
<br/>{16687880,
<br/> &lt;&gt;}
<br/>8&gt; Int2.
<br/>16687880As of r4, I&#39;ve also included the beginnings of a drop-in replacement for the random number generation in the Crypto API: </p>

<p>Eshell V5.5.4  (abort with ^G)
<br/>1&gt; c(qrbg).
<br/>{ok,qrbg}
<br/>2&gt; crypto:start().
<br/>ok
<br/>3&gt; crypto:rand_bytes(8).
<br/>&lt;&gt;
<br/>4&gt; qrbg:rand_bytes(8).
<br/>&lt;&gt;This requires you to add your username and password to  qrbg.hrl and is extremely inefficient if you&#39;re only looking for a few bytes.  A fresh request is made for each call to qrbg:get_bytes/1, so be gentle.  If you need several sets of random bytes you&#39;ll want to cache the data and extract bytes from it. </p>

<p>It goes without saying that in its current form, this client is susceptible to a man in the middle attack, so don&#39;t use it for anything sensitive.  It&#39;s an excellent source for truly random numbers though, and the QRBG service developers would like to support SSL connections in the future.</p>

 title : The yammer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Gale is an obscure public key cryptography chat system.  Installing and running Gale for the first time is immensely complicated because of the public key authentication framework.</p>

<p>Yammer is a Web UI written in Python on the Webware framework; it
<br/>makes it trivial to get started using Gale: you just create a user
<br/>account and converse with the cranky denizens.  Yammer takes care of
<br/>key generation and distribution.  All public conversation is stored in
<br/>its database, as are your private messages, which are sent encrypted
<br/>over the wire and are readable only by you.</p>

<p>Yammer also provides web services that allow other Gale clients to use
<br/>it to create user accounts.</p>

 title : The SQLExecutor: A Simple JDBC framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The bafprp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The data in a BAF file is documented by Telcordia document GR-1100 which is expensive to license, similar programs like bafview http://www.xach.com/misc/bafview/ were created to help us get at some of the baf data, however it has many short comings.  This program will allow a more thorough and deep analysis of baf records and have many different modes of output, with the ability to make more based on plugable modules. </p>

<p>v 1.3Version 1.3 of bafprp is available for download, please report any bugs or problems. </p>

<p>Special note for 2010As some of you might know bafview was recently updated to allow it to work in 2010.  What some of you might not know is why this was necessary.  PRI files store years as only 1 single digit.  So, 2009 is recorded as just 9.  It has been common practice for both bafview and bafprp to substitute in the remaining year digits but there is a problem.  Originally bafview was hard coded to just tack on the digit in the pri file to 200. This could have caused obvious problems with files dated for 2010.  Bafprp does not have this specific problem.  It looks up the current decade and uses that, however, there is a problem if users decide to parse 2009 files in 2010.  Up to bafprp v1.2.1 those files would get recorded as having taken place in 2019.  In v1.3 you will get a log warning, and it will try and automatically fix the date to 2009 if it can.  Obviously its a bad idea to parse pri files from a different decade, but someone might try it, so if you are worried about it, its probably best to update to v1.3. </p>

<p>Changelog1.2.1 to 1.3 </p>

<p>Added csv output format New record design to make creating records easy New makefiles to build with or without SQL output New BSD specific makefile that does not require gmake (thanks thowe!) Significantly reduced memory footprint yet again Added date auto adjusting code to minimize any problems the new decade might bring Minor house cleaning, typo fixes, etc </p>

<p>1.2 to 1.2.1 </p>

<p>Fixed MS SQL DSN Bug Added getInt and getLong to Phone Number data type Added more field definitions Fixed a bug that caused the program to crash on quad core cpus Improved MS SQL and MySql error reporting</p>
 summary : <p>批量邮件发送器v01 - 2008-03-15 </p>

<p>功能：对于某一路径下的文件，以附件的形式发送到某一个或多个邮箱里。 </p>

<p>可配置参数（properties.txt）包括： -smtp服务器（目前仅支持gmail） -用户名、密码 -发件人地址 -收件人地址（可多个） -邮件主题，文本内容 </p>

<p>-一个本地目录（目录下符合条件的文件将被发送） -文件名过滤规则（自定义正则表达式） -是否递归处理子文件夹 -所用邮箱附件最大值（gmail为10M） -发送邮件的休息间隔 </p>

<p>-是否日志记录 </p>

<p>系统要求： jre6 或者理论上 早期版本jdk+JAF+javamail（需重新编译源代码，未测试） </p>

 title : The flightschool Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project FlightSchoolFlightSchool is an open-source web application aimed at flight schools and air clubs, providing a complete online scheduling, accounting system, content-management and online community solution. The application was originially developed as a project for Software Engineering for Internet Applications class at MIT, taught by Philip Greenspun, and is currently being used by East Coast Aero Club. The full overview of the system is available here. </p>

<p>FlightSchool v2.0FlightSchool  v2.0 is scheduled to be released in Q3 2007. Major updates include </p>

<p>Completely redesigned site navigation  Improved billing module now supporting batch-entry of billing records Expanded Content Management functionality, allowing more intuitive content editing New AJAX-enabled scheduling interface improving performance and allowing editing reservations without leaving the schedule.  Redesigned User Administration component, accelerating most common user management tasks </p>

<p>Interested in Trying FlightSchool?Get your free FlightSchool site set up at open-flight.net!  </p>

<p>DocumentationProject FlightSchool Documentation is hosted in a wiki on this project site.   </p>

<p>ContactFor any FlightSchool  related inquiries (using the software, contributing, etc) please contact Lev Popov: levpopov at gmail</p>

 title : The mappy-email-signup Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>BRAD&#39;S MAPPY EMAIL SIGNUPI wanted a quick and easy way to ask website visitors for their  email addresses and locations. This does that via Google Maps. You can see an example of it in action at: http://www.bradsucks.net/live/ </p>

<p>SCRIPT REQUIREMENTSjQuery PHP 4+ MySQL INSTALLATIONGet a Google Maps API key: http://code.google.com/apis/maps/signup.html Fill out the variables in map-config.php Create the map-table.sql table Upload the files to your web host Visit index.php for an example implementation You can then include the map selector in any PHP page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>EXTRAS- You can specify $mapButtonText before including map-selector.php: </p>

<p>$mapButtonText = &quot;add me&quot;; // changes the submit button text to &quot;add me&quot;; </p>

<p>- If your URL has an email variable in it, the email input box will not be  displayed but that email will be passed through. Example: </p>

<p>http://www.yourhost.com/map/index.php?email=user@email.com </p>

<p>In this instance only a submit button will be displayed beneath the map,  but user@email.com address will be saved along with the location. </p>

<p>CAVEATSThere&#39;s no error checking or location updating. Whatever people click and  enter gets added to the database table. </p>

<p>SUPPORTI can&#39;t offer email support of this script (no time) but you can ask your  questions in the Brad Sucks BFF forums and I&#39;ll do my best to answer:  </p>

<p>http://www.bradsucks.net/forums/ </p>

<p>Thanks! </p>

<p>Brad </p>

<p>http://www.bradsucks.net</p>

 title : The mta-tracker Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a set of scripts developed by OSS Watch as part of the study &quot;Automatic survey of inbound mail (MX) servers in academic domains in the UK&quot;. </p>

<p>The scripts try to guess what academic institution an ac.uk domain belongs to, find their inbound mail servers and query them in parallel trying to identify what Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) is running. Then tables with the results can be built. </p>

<p>The load added to the mail servers by the scripts is negligible, and only public information is used. </p>

<p>These scripts contain a number assumptions which mean they work for .ac.uk only. We are also unable to distribute a list of domains in .ac.uk. </p>

<p>If you are interested in the project, please join our mailing list. </p>

<p>The latest stable release can be obtained from the downloads page. </p>

<p>Instructions on how to use the scripts can be found in the README file.</p>

 title : The php-smtp-email-validation Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PHP SMTP Email ValidationA PHP class that allows validation of email addresses via SMTP. The original code is from On Web Development.  </p>

<p>Email Syntax can check whether an email address has a valid format, however, in order to check if the email address actually exists, you will have to query the email domain for the existence of the email address.  </p>

<p>The PHP class encapsulates the SMTP transation between the remote domain, as well as the DNS lookup for the Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) responsible for that domain.  </p>

<p>The class can take a number of email addresses, and return whether they are valid or not. It will group together emails with the same domain, and create a single SMTP connection to the MTA for those emails for efficiency.  </p>

<p>This class is meant to be a secondary validation of an</p>

 title : The taskbar-notifier Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Taskbar Notifier0.9 Finally Here (Thanks for waiting)Missed call taskbar notifications added, support for 1.1.3 and if run on an iPod Touch will not check SMS or Missed Calls.  It&#39;ll be on installer ASAP. </p>

<p>There are 2 versions.  One for 1.1.3 and one for anything pre 1.1.3.  Please make sure you get the correct one.  The new one runs as mobile and there are other fairly major changes. </p>

<p>This iPhone application adds a small envelope icon in the taskbar when you have an unread email message, a small speech bubble when you have an unread SMS message and a small telephone icon if you have a missed call.  It is useful for reminding you from anywhere within the iPhone user interface that you have an unread message.  This includes the lock screen and on your multiple home screens. </p>

<p>Yes!  You can finally check your email from the lock screen (assuming you have your email set to auto check) </p>

<p>After the initial blue popup when an SMS message is received, the only place in the UI in which you are reminded of the unread message is the home screen, which as we all know is not where you spend the majority of your time! </p>

<p>This application is possibly even more useful for email because you&#39;re never actually notified of these anywhere other than the home screen. </p>

<p>   </p>

<p>Changes in 0.9Once again the code has been significantly cleaned up. It now checks missed calls It fully supports 1.1.3 It now uses an NSTimer to time the checks (if you experience problems with alarms not sounding in the clock application then please let me know.  I have found that deleting an alarm and recreating it seems to fix the problem and I am looking into what is causing it) It now checks whether you are using an iPod Touch or an iPhone and acts accordingly (does not check missed calls and SMS messages on iPod Touch) Know IssuesIf you have unread messages in a disabled account (in preferences) the account will be checked and you will be notified of this message. There is a chance that it may interfere with the alarm clock application (very occasionally).  I have yet to find the exact cause of the problem (it is something to do with my use of NSTimer).</p>

 title : The z-mail Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Free, authenticated, end-to-end secure email with any email application (Outlook, Thunderbird) and OS, no plugins. Local encryption/decryption. Uses NMA&#39;s free secure email Zmail Basic (ZmailBasic) for user authentication and superencryption. </p>

<p>This project removes a limitation of Zmail Basic. Free secure email Zmail Basic (ZmailBasic) can be used by anyone to send and receive authenticated secure email. However, even though Zmail Basic provides SSL access for the sender to connect to the Zmail server for authentication and encryption, there is a security gap at the Zmail server where the SSL terminates and the Zmail encryption begins. Likewise, even though Zmail Basic delivers the email encrypted to the recipients&#39;s mailbox, there is a security gap at the Zmail server when the user connects to decrypt the email, where the SSL terminates and the Zmail is decrypted. This project provides a solution for both of these security gaps in Zmail Basic, allowing free end-to-end authenticated and secure email communication.</p>
 summary : <p>A C library, providing comfortable APIs for a wide range of Finite State Abstract Machines (NFA, DFA, FST, Bimachines, etc). Implements most of the classical algorithms in the field.</p>

 title : The blueprint-pylons Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AboutBlueprint is a  CSS framework that speeds up the process of creating a grid layout in HTML. It also provides clean typography and a stylesheet for printing. </p>

<p>This is a plugin for the Pylons framework that automatically includes Blueprint CSS files into a project. </p>

<p>InstallYou just need to download the Python egg and install it using easy_instal: </p>

<p>wget http://blueprint-pylons.googlecode.com/files/BluePrint-0.1-py2.5.egg
<br/>sudo easy_install BluePrint-0.1-py2.5.eggIf you&#39;re a Mac user, use Curl instead to download the egg: </p>

<p>curl -O http://blueprint-pylons.googlecode.com/files/BluePrint-0.1-py2.5.egg
<br/>sudo easy_install BluePrint-0.1-py2.5.eggIf you&#39;re afraid of the command line, there are also some installers for Windows and OS X. </p>

<p>UsageLet&#39;s say that you have a Pylons project named foo. Under your project&#39;s root folder, there should be another folder named foo.egg-info. Open the paster_plugins.txt file that is inside it. You just need to the following line to that file: </p>

<p>BluePrintAnd your project is already using the plugin. </p>

<p>To install the Blueprint CSS files onto your project&#39;s public folder, just run the following paster command: </p>

<p>paster blueprintYou are all set to go, happy templating! </p>

<p>CreditsI thank, of course, all the guys from the Blueprint project that made this amazing framework happen. </p>

<p>Projects updates will be posted on my blog. </p>

<p>João Moreno</p>

 title : The css-explorer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The purpose of these scripts is to allow for the debugging of HTML and CSS content using nothing more than the onmouseover event, showing the cascade results as ultimately rendered. It can be invoked in one of two ways: </p>

<p>1) Non-instrusive (preferred) - add a bookmarklet to your favorites/bookmarks. Using this method, you can debug CSS styles on any Web page, whether you host it or not. </p>

<p>2) Intrusive (deprecated) - place a script element in the </p>

<p> section of the page to be debugged. </p>

<p>Both will cause another window to open containing debug information for the page this script was called from. Then you can line the two pages up side by side or with the debug page behind the main window but still visible and then as you mouse over places in the main window, the debug window will show you element tags, ids, titles, names, alt text, the element hierarchy, the class hierarchy (if any) and all the styles being applied to the element. You can also update the style(s) of the element being hovered over on the original page from this debug page. There are tools and add-ins that do this, but this allows the information to be seen without installing anything on the browser, and attempts to work on IE, Firefox, Opera and Safari. </p>

<p>This script has been tested using IE 6 &amp; 7, Firefox 2 (Windows and Linux), Opera 9 (Windows) and Safari 3 (beta - Windows). It does NOT work on Konqueror, at least not when launched by bookmarklet (since Konqueror doesn&#39;t support the javascript: URL binding, at least not that I know of). </p>

<p>See comments in the code for more details. </p>

<p>Written by Jim Lehmer.</p>

 title : The css-formatter-task Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionIn bigger flex &amp; html projects, css files can get quite long.  </p>

<p>Also, if don&#39;t want to change and recompile the task, you can remove the dependancy to the &#39;jar&#39; task (... depends=&#39;jar&#39; ...) </p>

<p>Cheers Ralf</p>

 title : The css-trees-and-tabs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Novel method (so far as the author is aware) of displaying tabs and trees using pure HTML/CSS - no javascript needed. </p>

<p>Works on modern browsers which support html labels, css&#39;s :checked property, and css&#39;s + selector. </p>

<p>While playing with radio buttons I accidentally discovered that I could use them to make tabs in my web pages without the use of javascript.  This has already been done, often with pagename&gt;tabname such that the body tag for each page has id=pagename as an attribute.  I&#39;m sure there are other methods too.  A quick google search did not reveal the method I had found.  A couple more minutes with CSS and I had a tree menu which expanded and collapsed on a click.  Cool. </p>

<p>This method is not necessarily better or worse than what&#39;s out there.  It&#39;s just different.  I don&#39;t really care to debate the finer points of whose tabs are more efficient to run or more elegant to read.  This is just another method of doing tabs solely in CSS, without a page refresh.  Use it if you like. </p>

<p>As I already mentioned, this method works for modern browsers.  It relies on form labels clicks going to the appropriate form input as well as css&#39;s :checked property and plus selector.  As of this writing, it works in Firefox2 and Opera but not IE7 and I haven&#39;t even looked at IE6. </p>

<p>See downloads for code.  You&#39;ll have to download treetab.html and style.css to the same directory for a working demo.   </p>

<p>Here&#39;s how css tabs work: </p>

<p>The HTML is straightforward.  You have a form.  Give it an ID so that your css doesn&#39;t clobber other forms in your page.  Each tab goes in the form and has three elements. </p>

<p>input label div  </p>

<p>The input is set to type=radio.  This supplies the page with a behavior.  When you click on a radio button, it gets checked and all other radio buttons get unchecked. </p>

<p>Labels have a for element that indicates which form input they affect.  Each of your labels will point to a radio button.  Unlike a traditional table of text - radio button cells, a label can be clicked on to check it&#39;s radio button. </p>

<p>Finally the div.  This is where the content of each tab lives.  Yes, this means your page will load all the tabs and once and can switch between them without page reloads or AJAX calls. </p>

<p>style.css is where the magic happens. </p>

<p>First we hide the tabs.  You should either class them to .tab or use #tabform&gt;div to select them.  display:none will hide them all. </p>

<p>But tabs that are clicked should be seen.  This is where :checked and + come in.  :checked will match any radio button that is selected.  + is one of those new CSS selectors with a very limited, but occasionally very useful purpose.  E + F selects an F which is immediately preceded by an E.  So in this case, input[type=radio]:checked + label + div.tab will select an div with class tab, whose predecessors are a label and a checked radio button.  Set this div&#39;s display to block.  Now when you click through the radio buttons different divs are displayed!  As the tab divs are set in between the radio buttons, they&#39;ll show up in between them.  Toss in a float:left to push them below the radio buttons.  (Alternatively you could make a row of labels and put your input/tabs elsewhere on the page.  This is probably a better way to do things, though it will mean rewriting some selectors.) </p>

<p>Finally we have to disguise the fact that we&#39;re using forms.  input[type=radio] display:none; will get rid of those pesky circles and leave your clickable labels intact.  Now you have working tabs, with no javascripted mess. </p>

<p>You may want to pretty them up a bit though so that they actually look like tabs.  I like using the following: input[type=radio]+label to format inactive tabs.  I usually give them a 1px solid border. </p>

<p>input[type=radio]:checked+label is the highlighted tab.  To make it look like part of the tab it opens, give it a border-bottom-color: white, or whatever color your tab is.  You may also have to raise the tab div 1px so it&#39;s border gets covered by this white one.   </p>

<p>input[type=radio]+label:hover.  One problem I&#39;ve noticed with this method is that tabs give no feedback that they&#39;re clickable.  You could change the cursor with javascript, but that defeats our no javascript rule.  Instead I&#39;ve been changing the color to blue when hovered over. </p>

<p>div.tab Give your content a border much like the tab border.  Again, you may have to position it up a pixel to make the borders overlap. </p>

<p>Making an expanding tree using this method is trivial.  I won&#39;t go over it in quite as much depth.   </p>

<p>Here you want to use checkboxes rather than radio buttons (unless you want sections to collapse when other sections are opened).  The big difference here is that I took off the pretty colors and borders and added display:block to input[type=checkbox]+label.  This made each label into its own line.  I also removed float:left from the tabs so that they would appear between tabs, rather than under them. </p>

<p>Adding expand and close buttons should be trivial.  Basically you&#39;re going to give each label a background image that doesn&#39;t repeat.  Unchecked the image will be a - (or whatever you choose for your close button).  You&#39;ll want to use a small bit of padding left so that the text doesn&#39;t flow over the image.  Change the image to a + for input[type=checkbox]:checked+label.</p>
 title : The cssbuilder Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CSS Builder is a very simple control that is aimed for developers who are designing editors and want that the users of their editor should be able to create custom styles on the fly and they should do it using CSS. The UI can read CSS and generate CSS based on users&#39; selections. It was created because there were no open source CSS generation related controls available at the time of its writing and aims to be the definitive source where developers go to when they need a control for doing what it does best: CSS editing. </p>

<p>Future scope: </p>

<p>Add a live preview window which previews the style being created by the user. Better the selection of some properties such as font-family etc. Start generating CSS styles on specific elements in code, which might also involve generating complex CSS selectors. Stay updated as CSS changes.</p>

 title : The cssjanus Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CSSJanus is CSS parser utility designed to aid the conversion of a website&#39;s layout from left-to-right(LTR) to right-to-left(RTL). The script was born out of a need to convert CSS for RTL languages when tables are not being used for layout (since tables will automatically reorder TD&#39;s in RTL).  CSSJanus will change most of the obvious CSS property names and their values as well as some not-so-obvious ones (cursor, background-position %, etc...).  The script is designed to offer flexibility to account for cases when you do  not want to change certain rules which exist to account for bidirectional text display bugs, as well as situations where you may or may not want to flip annotations inside of the background url string. </p>

<p>CSSJanus itself is not always enough to make a website that works in a LTR language context work in a RTL language all the way, but it is a start. </p>

<p>Check out a running django-ified webapp version: http://cssjanus.commoner.com/ </p>

<p>Read the blog post and watch the demo video: http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2008/03/cssjanus-helping-i18n-and-ltr-to-rtl.html </p>

<p>Also, for the greatest detail of what gets flipped in CSS Janus, please have a look at the unit test: http://code.google.com/p/cssjanus/source/browse/trunk/cssjanus_test.py</p>
 title : The cubstheme Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Chicago Cubs theme for igskins.</p>
 summary : <p>Default CSS is no longer in development. </p>

<p>Default CSS is a generic CSS standard for HTML rendering. It resets default browser rendering so you can be sure your page will look the same in any browser. </p>

<p>The main objective is to provide styles for a highly-readable and typographically-beautiful page without you needing to anything other than link to the files. </p>

<p>More specifically, the aims behind Default CSS are to: </p>

<p>create a generic standard for rendering HTML and XHTML elements; increase readability; improve web typography and follow age-old typographic rules; and make the rendered HTML look fantastic across both screen and print media. Default CSS is not meant to be the definitive CSS template, merely one of many.</p>

 title : The doctestj Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Doctest for JavaThis port of Python&#39;s Doctest provides a simple implementation of javadoc&#39;s Doclet interface that produces XML fragments, a JSON index and javascript tests.  </p>

<p>CSS, HTML and an AJAX documentation browser are also included. </p>

<p>This package is a work in progress, I use it to document less4j. </p>

<p>Document and test Java at onceText tagged with @test is compiled by Rhino and saved individually in a doc/tests folder. Tests are expected to be a simple script that returns a boolean, true for success and false for failure. </p>

<p>Here is what a brief Doctest comment would look like for java&#39;s String.equals method: </p>

<p>/**
<br/> * Compare this String to another one.
<br/> * 
<br/> * @param string to compare to 
<br/> * @return true if the two strings compared are equals
<br/> *
<br/> * @test return (
<br/> *    &quot;A&quot;.equals(&quot;A&quot;) == true &amp;&amp;
<br/> *    &quot;A&quot;.equals(&quot;a&quot;) == false
<br/> *    );
<br/> */For documentation purposes doctestj supports the original javadoc tags: @param, @return and @throws. And to enhance your documentation with HTML elements with less markup error, it maps a @h3, @h4, @p and @pre tag to the equivalent HTML titles, paragraph and preformatted text elements. Any other tag (including test) will yield a div element with a CSS class named after the tag. You can still use XHTML markup inside the tagged and the untagged comment text, doctestj will try to validate it and document any XML errors in its output.</p>

 summary : <p>ecss is a fully compatible CSS variant. mod_ecss (the ecss apache module) has been in production use since May 2007 serving millions of requests per day. Besides syntax-checking and compressing existing CSS, ecss provides the following extensions: </p>

<p>NestedRulesets Variables Themes IncludeFiles Evaluation UserAgentProperties </p>

<p>Here&#39;s a brief example illustrating some of ecss&#39;s features: </p>

<p>@include &quot;other-stuff/ads.ecss&quot;;
<br/>$width: 800;
<br/>$width_px: eval($width _ px);
<br/>$horiz_padding: eval(floor($width * 0.018));
<br/>$horiz_padding_px: eval($horiz_padding _ px);
<br/>$vertical_padding: eval(floor($horiz_padding / 6));
<br/>$vertical_padding_px: eval($vertical_padding _ px);
<br/>#myproject {
<br/>  #menu {
<br/>    ul, ol {
<br/>      list-style: none;
<br/>      li {
<br/>        height: eval($height _ em);
<br/>        padding: 0;
<br/>      }
<br/>      a {
<br/>        color: #aabbcc;
<br/>        color(msie 7.0): #ddeeff;
<br/>      }
<br/>    }
<br/>  }
<br/>}More stuff to read: </p>

 title : The mycitycab Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Cabs (Taxis) are a critical mean of transportation and in some cities (for example Cairo, Egypt) the taxi fares are not standardized which is a big hassle to estimate based on many factors (Distance, Rush hour, car model, time of day, week day ... etc) This project aims to encourage taxi customers to come and share their experience, and help others to find the right fare. </p>

<p>Featured PagesList of planned features check here List of tools check here Latest UpdatesMonday December 10th, 2007: </p>

<p>Trying to find a better way for user to enter address information  Google Maps API&#39;s are inspected for this purpose, however the time needed for the customer to find the place on Google Map is quite long  Crazy ideas are welcomed for address information gathering. </p>

<p>Friday December 8th, 2007: </p>

<p>A fix in Database table City (City EnglishName field was varbinary not varchar The user control for sharing journeys is created and development in this part started Auto-complete feature is added to City fields using jQuery.autocomplete extension </p>

<p>Saturday December 1st, 2007: </p>

<p>Database is updated with the list of Countries ReturnValue utility class is added Login logic is added to User class Login logic test function is added to test project Login user control is added to the homepage. Site map file is added and a menu control is created and consumes the site map file. </p>

<p>Thursday November 29th, 2007: </p>

<p>Project MyCityCab.Core.Data was deleted, and the generated code is moved to MyCityCab.Core class library under Generated folder Project MyCityCab.Core.Testing is added for Unit Testing, and MbUnit test library is the one being used right now The first UserTest unit test class is added to test the implementation of the Password hashing mechanism. Prototype 1 of the UI using YAML is applied to the Web project </p>

<p>Wednesday November 28th, 2007:  </p>

<p>Database generated code is submitted, please install SubSonic to be able to compiler the code, also thisScreen Cast will show how to configure it right and integrate it with VS SQL Server Database was created and the SQL Script for it was added under trunk\Code\Db Script\</p>

 title : The eZ Publish content management system Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>eZ Publish is an Open Source Content Management System chosen by thousands of enterprises and organizations world wide. It helps you build corporate websites, intranets, webshops and media portals.</p>
 summary : <p>NivelStyle </p>

<p>NivelStyle es una nomenclatura de clases que implican un concepto para maquetar proyectos pequeños o de gran envergadura sin líneas de código innecesarias. NivelStyle no frena la flexibilidad de tu estructura imponiendo nombres de clases para cada tipo de diagramación que necesites.  </p>

<p>Lo que se logra es que utilizando siempre los mismos nombres de clases, puedas diagramar cualquier tipo de estructura, utilizando la herencia y conservando siempre la flexibilidad para poderla editar y brindarle la apariencia exacta que necesites, sin necesidad de seguir una retícula, eres libre.  </p>

<p>La esencial del CSS es separar la estructura HTML de la visualización CSS y NivelStyle está de acuerdo con este principio, permitiendo que tengas un código HTML definido y puedas cambiar su diagramac</p>

 title : The stantest Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Ahhh, FrameWorks. They make my work easier and more fun. By taking out the stuff that is repetitive and dull, frameworks establish a great baseline for creative work. So I combined my 2 favorite front end frameworks in Starter Kit. </p>

<p>Starter Kit starts with a simple layout and ties in Blueprint CSS and jQuery. The layout here is something that anyone can do. I find myself having to recreate the same setup over and over, so it made sense to me to create a place for a SVN Repository of my starting point. Of course, this is a little bare bones, but it is designed as a starting place for integration. </p>

<p>Starter Kit Features:Valid HTML and XHTML Conventional Layout Conventional Navigation Metaphors Starter Kit VersionsBlueprint CSS version 0.7 jQuery version 1.2.3 DemoStarter Kit Demo </p>

<p>Blueprint CSS is a fantastic framework for CSS. Using the grid layout, a designer/developer can quickly deploy a fantastic solution with established conventions. Blueprint CSS was launched by Olav Bjørkøy and he has done a great job developing the framework. </p>

<p>And jQuery is an amazing and light framework for JavaScript. Write less code. Do more stuff. jQuery was developed by John Resig and continues with contributions by many developers. </p>

<p>If you are interested in contributing, please do! There are many ways to skin a cat, maybe you know a less messy one. You can contact me direct at dave.merwin@gmail.com. </p>

<p>Framework Versions: Currently the versions used are  </p>

<p>Please Note:I will try to keep Downloads up to date, but frankly, you are better off doing a SVN checkout if you need code. I update SVN religiously. Like I said, this is MY starter kit too, so I use it often. </p>

<p>Ok, I won&#39;t keep downloads up to date. SVN is the way to go. Or you can get it from the demo site. </p>

<p>You would be ill advised to grab this code and push it to a server and call it a day. First it will be bloated with comments for documentation. Second, it will require a great deal of HTTP requests to large files. These files are left uncompressed to learn from, but it will add overhead to your site if you load them as is. Where I work, we use different methods to get all of the requests down and to compress the file size. </p>

<p>For CSS Compression you can start here: Blogging Pro: CSS-Optimization </p>

<p>For JavaScript optimization you can start here: Websiteoptimization.com: JavaScript Optimization </p>

<p>More performance hints here: Websiteoptimization.com: Speed Tweaks</p>

 title : The 1stlog Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>来源：http://iceskysl.1sters.com_ 
<br/>-1stlog归来，人员征集中:http://iceskysl.1sters.com/?action=show&amp;id=257_ 
<br/>有问题的话，在issues里面提出，我们会尽快修复，如果有新需求，请也一并提出，我们会考虑予以实现，谢谢！ </p>

<p>各位开发者到Issues里面提出尚未完成的功能，领取自己感兴趣的功能实现后及时chenckin到SVN上 </p>

<p>1stlog群：group183346@msnzone.cn </p>

<p>很高兴的告诉大家，1stlog的第一个版本发布了，从规划到实现、测试大概有一个月的时间，谢谢朋友们的支持和帮助，谢谢！ </p>

<p>1stlog诞生的背景大家知道，PHP的领域中，被广泛使用的博客系统应该是WP了；Rails版本的blog系统现在用的比较多的应该是typo和simplog 了，这两个也有不少人使用了。但是我用了后觉得不是很符合国人的习惯，很多 地方用着感觉很别扭，于是打算自己动手写一个用着习惯的blog系统。 </p>

<p>1stlog规划做为一个blog系统，需要很好的通用性和易用性，我们平衡两者的关系，通过研究现有blog的特点，规划了1stlog的大部分功能，简单灵活、可扩展。 
<br/>1stlog的命名我们是1sters.com团队开发设计开发的，又是一个blog系统，所以定其名字为1stlog，很合理，不是么， </p>

<p>1stlog的功能点功能点还是很多的，包含但不限于以下列举的这么多。 
<br/> 安装方便，不需要重新编译  Type / Categories / Tags 的管理  日志的发表 编辑 删除  评论及其评论管理  支持Textile可视化和tiny_mce可视化编辑器（简单、高级两种)  Trackback 及其防spider以及灌水机  基于Ajax的search和Trackback地址生成  文章 / 评论的feeds  按照分类或者性质的feeds  单篇文章的feeds输出  个性化展示配置  自定义显示模板  验证码  上传下载文件  选择自己需要的显示模块  可配置每页显示的篇数等显示数目  可以选择自己喜欢的显示模板  用户管理  友情链接  定时备份数据库 等等等。。。 </p>

<p>搭建1stlog需要mysql4.0及其以上版本数据库 rails2.0及其以上版本 ruby1.8.6及其以上版本 RedCloth RMagick 演示 http://1stlog.1sters.com/ </p>

<p>安装演示 参考：-&gt;</p>

 title : The heronphp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>HeronPHP是一个面向PHP的MVC结构的Framework。HeronPHP目标是提供一个Web应用快速开发的Framework，而又不失弹性和健壮性。</p>

<p>特性</p>

<p>MVC结构，页面和代码逻辑可以进行很好的分离</p>

<p>基于布局的View处理，并与Smarty模版结合,同时不失灵活性你可以定制自己的模版系统</p>

<p>强大的数据校验支持，通过INI配置文件配置校验，HeronPHP将自动生成PHP校验自动生成PHP校验代码</p>

<p>多种Cache机制,让你完全可以灵活的使用Cache功能,无论是PHP级的Cache还是直接生成静态页面,通过配置参数即可实现。</p>

 title : The a-c-o-r-n Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AcornAcorn is a web server for constraint based modeling of genome scale metabolic reaction networks. After signing in users can run Flux Balance Analysis simulations on multiple models loaded by an administrator from SBML files. Initial conditions of computer simulations (reaction bounds, objective function) are stored and can be shared with other users. Models and results are displayed in tables with genes linked to genome information portals, but pathway visualisation will soon be implemented. The server is capable of handling multiple users and iterative FBA simulations by using clusters set up in glassfish environment. Currently acorn supports the following simulation protocols: </p>

<p> Single FBA optimisation  Flux Variability Analysis  Reaction Essentiality Scan  Single gene knock-out   Acorn uses GLPK library for linear programming.</p>
 title : The algonquin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Algonquin provides a canvas on which a programmer lays down building blocks of a computer program, where each block has a designated functionality. The programmer then associates blocks in some manner using linear connectors, which constitute the general data flow of the application. </p>

<p>Executable code chunks inside the basic blocks is written in Python. Future extensions may allow other languages as well. </p>

<p>Predefined blocks can be put into stencils and distributed to support re-use of code. </p>

<p>Intended applications: </p>

<p>Web applications Web services Content-management systems (CMS) Distributed environments GUI</p>

 title : The anml Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>See europa project for actual license. </p>

<p>ANML is being developed to combine the strengths of several existing modeling languages: AML, NDDL, and PDDL are the strongest influences.   </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>1) Clean temporal semantics, with point conditions and effects (in addition to intervals). IxTeT </p>

<p>2) Action/State based (contrast with NDDL) 2a) Arbitrary internal and delayed access to time 2b) Resource effects, including temporary change 2c) An interval change (:-&gt;) operator (see TGP below) </p>

<p>3) User definable types 3a) Including structured types (vectors/arrays and objects) 3b) And inheritance (for object and symbolic types) 3c) Primitives: Symbol, Boolean, Float/Real, Integer, Character Note: Only the first one/two/three primitive types are traditionally accepted by planning systems </p>

<p>4) Chainable fluent access, aiming at modeling continuous processes: </p>

<p>all  loc == alpha :-&gt; beta; </p>

<p>means </p>

<p>start  loc == alpha; ( all ] loc :-&gt; beta; </p>

<p>but has the advantage of gathering the entire timeline of the action&#39;s interaction with the fluent.  This aims at, for example: </p>

<p>( all ] f(t) := f(start) + m  x  (t - start) / duration; </p>

<p>5) Hierarchical decomposition, by reduction to state-based semantics.  Typical HTN supporting languages add additional constraints, greatly inhibiting comparisons between HTN and non-HTN planners. 5a) The exact meaning, however, differs subtly and importantly from the traditional notion of decomposition.  &quot;motivated&quot; modifies an action to restore the traditional notion wrt to that action. 5b) Shortcuts (ordered and unordered) for the common case, and support for the general case. </p>

<p>6) Quantification, conditional effects, complicated nesting, and so forth are all permitted. </p>

<p>7) Domain level facts and constraints are permitted (e.g. safety constraints) </p>

<p>8) Scoped </p>

<p>9) Many shortcuts for omitting redundant text, e.g.: </p>

<p>all  { foo; bar; baz; } </p>

<p>instead of: </p>

<p>all  foo; all  bar; all  baz; </p>

<p>10) At least conceptually, the boolean/real/symbol/object fragment is entirely compilable to PDDL, and similar restricted forms.  Repeated field references on objects, i.e., object valued functions, might only be partially supportable (PDDL is function free (in the sense of predicate calculus), but much can be circumvented via auxiliary actions). </p>

<p>Note TGP: By default, ANML does not permit non-deterministic models, so the TGP interpretation is not possible.  The TGP interpretation is: </p>

<p>( all ] contains [ ] p := T; </p>

<p>Our default interpretation is: </p>

<p>( all ] p :-&gt; T; </p>

<p>Alternatively, if the TGP behavior is desired, then the following functionally equivalent deterministic construction suffices: </p>

<p>...
<br/>[all] contains [] add_p();
<br/>...
<br/>action add_p() {
<br/>(all] p :-&gt; T;
<br/>[all] contains A or B or C ...;
<br/>}where the disjunction is over all adders of p, so that adding p does have to take the duration of at least one of the actions.  This can be shortened to &quot;motivated&quot;, which stands for exactly such a duration constraint over the requesters of the action by name: </p>

<p>...
<br/>[all] contains [] add_p();
<br/>...
<br/>action add_p() {
<br/>motivated; // means [all] contains 
<br/>    // ;
<br/>[all] p :-&gt; T;
<br/>}More generally, such global arbiter actions can always be employed to force a deterministic resolution of a set of blocking processes; provided that every schedule really does result in the same final state.</p>

 title : The brushwave Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Brushwave - Painterly Rendering for Lightwave 3DOverviewBrushwave is a painterly rendering plugin for the 3D modeling and rendering software &quot;Lightwave 3D&quot;. It applies thousands of individual brush strokes to a scene, and can be used for still images as well as animations. </p>

<p>Project Website: http://www.incognitek.com/redge/projects/brushwave </p>

<p>The project was started in 2007 as a proof of concept for a German media company. It is currently fully usable and quite stable, while some features are missing. I plan to enhance the plugin step by step in the future. </p>

<p>Brushwave is licensed under the LGPL. You can use it for any purpose you want. However, if you create some nice images or videos, I would be very pleased if you could send me some material to put on my webpage. </p>

<p>InstallationBrushwave does not have any dependencies besides an OpenGL capable graphics driver. </p>

<p>You can install Brushwave in Layout Mode via &quot;Utilities/Add Plugins&quot;. You will find that Brushwave consists of 2 plugins. One of them controls the settings of the rendering process, the other does the rendering. Both plugins are included in the brushwave plugin binary. </p>

<p>UsageTo render an object with Brushwave, you have to take 2 steps: </p>

<p>a) Per-object settings </p>

<p>Select the object you want to apply the painterly filter to, then open the properties dialog. In the &quot;Geometry&quot;-Tab, add the custom object &quot;Brushwave Object&quot;. Double-click it to manipulate its settings. </p>

<p>b) Global settings </p>

<p>If you rendered the scene now, nothing would happen. You first need to activate the Brushwave image filter. This can be done under &quot;Windows / Image Processing / Add image filter&quot;. Choose the filter &quot;Brushwave&quot;.  </p>

<p>That&#39;s it! If you render the scene now, the model will be rendered in a painterly style. If you save the scene, Lightwave will remember the settings for the next time. </p>

<p>Further informationIf you want more information about Brushwave, visit the project&#39;s homepage.</p>
 summary : <p>Voice stress analysis tool. Sometimes used as an audio lie detector (ie. used for detecting stress in a person&#39;s voice to allow for the determination of truthfulness).</p>

 title : The codemaker Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CodeMaker is a modeling tool that allows desingers to create graphically ERD diagrams. It may look just like any other designing tool, but it has an extra feature: it uses code generators to generate source code from the database model. </p>

<p>Code Generators are plugins that can be dynamically loaded, so basically there are no limits for them: they can be used to generate java code, php code, sql code, etc. You can develope Code Generators yourself, and that way extend CodeMaker capabilities. </p>

<p>CodeMaker will shorten your developing times, and you will end up with a consistent api for database access, that you can fix/improve with just a mouse click. </p>

<p>CodeMaker is a tool created by software developers and oriented to software developers.</p>

 summary : <p>The goal of this project is to produce an open-source model that couples hydrodynamics (circulation and waves), sediment transport, and morphodynamics. The model will be suitable for realistic and useful simulations of processes that influence sediment transport in the coastal ocean, including estuaries, nearshore regions, and the continental shelf over regional length scales (10’s of meters to 100’s of kilometers) and time scales ranging from transport events to decades. The code will be written in modern, portable languages (mostly FORTRAN95) using a modular approach that will allow flexibility and extensibility. In addition to the source code (which will have an open-source license and run on most computer systems from laptops to multi-processor clusters), the project will provide model documentation, training, test cases, tools for processing model input and output, and demonstrated applications.</p>

 title : The diffusion-mri Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Modeling and Reconstruction of Multi-fiber Population from DWMRICopyright (C) 2008-2009, Bing Jian and Baba C. Vemuri </p>

<p> </p>

<p>AboutThis website provides Python modules for modeling and reconstruction of diffusion weighted MRI data. It is a subset of the code internally used in the CVGMI lab at the University of Florida. Three different reconstruction methods are currently included in this program, namely, Mixture of Wisharts (MOW), Diffusion Orientation Transform (DOT) and Q-ball Imaging (QBI).  </p>

<p>This program is mainly developed and maintained by Bing Jian, as part of his Ph.D. research, supervised by Prof. Baba Vemuri. For how to obtain the latest source code from this website, please read this page. For more information on how to use this program, please refer to the README file. You can download the source code for free, use and change it as you like, but please refer to this website  and cite our TMI and NeuroImage papers. </p>

<p>ReferencesBing Jian and Baba C. Vemuri. A Unified Computational Framework for Deconvolution to Reconstruct Multiple Fibers From Diffusion Weighted MRI. IEEE Trans. Med. Imaging, 26(11):1464-1471, 2007. Bing Jian, Baba C. Vemuri, Evren Özarslan, Paul R. Carney, and Thomas H. Mareci. A novel tensor distribution model for the diffusion weighted MR signal. NeuroImage, 37(1):164-176, 2007. Maxime Descoteaux, Elaine Angelino, Shaun Fitzgibbons, and Rachid Deriche. Regularized, Fast and Robust Analytical Q-Ball Imaging. Magn. Reson. Med., 58:497-510, 2007.  Ken E. Sakaie and Mark J. Lowe. An objective method for regularization of fiber orientation distribution derived from diffusion-weighed MRI. NeuroImage, 34:169-176, 2007. Evren Özarslan, Timothy M. Shepherd, Baba C. Vemuri, Stephen J. Blackband, and Thomas H. Mareci. Resolution of complex tissue microarchitecture using the diffusion orientation transform (DOT). NeuroImage, 36(3):1086-1103, 2006.  Maxime Descoteaux, Elaine Angelino, Shaun Fitzgibbons, and Rachid Deriche. Apparent diffusion coefficients from high angular resolution diffusion imaging: Estimation and applications. Magn. Reson. Med., 56(2):395-410, 2006 Adam W. Anderson. Measurement of Fiber Orientation Distributions Using High Angular Resolution Diffusion Imaging. Magn. Reson. Med., 54(5):1194-1206, 2005 Daniel C. Alexander. Multiple-fibre reconstruction algorithms for diffusion MRI. Proc. N.Y. Acad. Sci., 1064:113-133, 2005. Evren Özarslan, Baba C. Vemuri, and Thomas H. Mareci. Generalized scalar measures for diffusion MRI using trace, variance, and entropy. Magn. Reson. Med., 53(4):866-876, 2005. David S. Tuch. Q-ball imaging. Magn. Reson. Med., 52(6):1358-1372, 2004.  J.-Donald Tournier, Fernando Calamante, David G. Gadian, and Alan Connelly. Direct estimation of the fiber orientation density function from diffusion-weighted MRI data using spherical deconvolution. NeuroImage, 23(3):1176-1185, 2004. Evren Özarslan and Thomas H. Mareci. Generalized diffusion tensor imaging and analytical relationships between diffusion tensor imaging and high angular resolution diffusion imaging. Magn. Reson. Med., 50(5):955-965, 2003. Daniel C. Alexander, Gareth J. Barker, and Simon R. Arridge. Detection and modeling of non-Gaussian apparent diffusion coefficient profiles in human brain data. Magn. Reson. Med., 48(2):331-340, August 2002.   </p>

<p>AcknowledgmentThis research was supported by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Grant EB007082.  The simulated data and the IDL visualization program used to generate the picture in this page were provided by Dr. Evren Özarslan. Many thanks go to Santhosh Kodipaka, Angelos Barmpoutis, Ritiwk Kumar and Guang Cheng for testing this program and providing helpful suggestions. Related LinksMICCAI 2008 Diffusion MRI Tutorial: Technology trends and unsolved problems Camino(diffusion MRI toolkit) MRI studio DSI studio CATNAP Tractor  --- </p>

 title : The dylab-apps Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is part of a larger project called DyLab, which offers a component based system for testing and prototyping soft tissue models on an ordinary PC and also for rapid development of new applications belonging especially to the area of organ and organ system simulators. </p>

<p>The whole system consists of three layers:  DyLab framework,  Dylab components and  DyLab applications, all highly configurable with simple text configuration files. </p>

<p>This subproject provides applications base on DyLab framework and DyLab components. There is currently only one stub application availabe, serving as a testbed for the framework and the implemented components. However, due to component architecture and high configurability, it can be used for almost any scenario without the need to alter its source code. </p>

<p>The project DyLab is implemented using the C++ language and it was compiled and tested only on Windows platform, so far. However, it was designed with support for other platforms in mind as well.</p>

 title : The elvishrayrenderer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>elvish ray is a powerful programmable renderer with robust productivity of high-quality images, high-perfomance and extremely efficient ray-tracing supports ray differentials. </p>

<p>elvish ray takes advantages of parallel hardware automatically, including thread parallelism, SIMD parallelism both on CPU and GPU, and network parallelism which exploits loading balance using a distributed shared database . </p>

<p>elvish ray simulates caustics, global illumination and volume scattering using a hybrid algorithm. All types of light transports such as diffuse, glossy, specular reflection and transmission and their combinations can be simulated. </p>

<p>elvish ray has its native scene description language supporting geometric primitives including polygons, trimmed free-form surfaces and subdivision surfaces, and solid modeling. A scene can either be described in a text file in ASCII format, or written in a ANSI C binding format with the API of elvish ray. Translators and exporters may be coded for generating such files from modeling or animation systems. </p>

<p>elvish ray also can be integrated into any suitable modeling or animation systems with some corresponding connections. </p>

<p>elvish ray supports incremental changes to the scene database, only the parts of the scene that change from one frame to the next need to be redefined. This allows elvish ray to take advantage of temporal coherency of animation. </p>

<p>elvish ray has a shader-driven architecture and can be programmed through shader writing flexibly. There are a variety of shader types, including lens shader, surface shader, light shader, shadow shader, environment shader, volume shader, texture shader, geometry shader, displacement shader, and imager shader. Shaders can be connected together to build shader trees.</p>
 summary : <p>FaPe3DMost of you may have used 3D engines in flash such as PaperVision3D ,Alternativa ,Away 3D ,Sandy or any other 3D engine. All of them are powerful and created by great actionscript developers around the world. As a developer you must familiar to the high level Actionscript topics to archive best of these classes. FaPe3D is a simple 3D modeling engine aims to create 3D environments using some XML data providers, and render them as 3D Flash elements. Even materialize them, add some event listeners to them, shade them and more.</p>

 title : The floodzilla Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is Floodzilla?Floodzilla is the Web based real time flood and natural disasters alert system which is basically targeted to inform people immediately about a flood and natural disasters threat via web. This project has been specially design to display various flood situations around a selected geographical area and areas that have been threatened will be pin pointed by a ‘Place Marker’ and an ‘Info Window’. </p>

<p>The roll of the Flood and natural disasters alert system has a wide range of activities such as giving information about the flood areas immediately, uploading videos and images that are related to particular flooding area, managing Volunteers and Subscribers information, modifying the related data which are added by volunteers, sending flood alert (SMS) to all the subscribers...etc.  </p>

<p>In order to achieve our goal we will basically focus on </p>

<p>Floodzilla basically targeted to inform people immediately about a flood threat or natural disaster via web.                                                                                                                                                                                                              Floodzilla act as a dashboard that displays various flood or natural situations around a selected geographical area. Areas that have been threatened will be pin pointed by a ‘Place Marker’ and an ‘Info Window’.  A ‘place marker’ is a graphical icon that stands on a particular location on the map. An ‘Info window’ is a component which displays small description about a ‘Place marker’ and it can carry small textual data. Volunteers can upload photos and videos about a particular flooding and natural disasters area. For the sake of convenience and correctness, that information will be moderated before publishing on the site. Moderation can be done via the site administrator. Interested users can register to receive flood and natural disasters alerts via Floodzilla. In this case, people who live near water resources are highly targeted. All subscribers will be alerted by a SMS.</p>

 title : The gmftools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project offers a collection of development tools, extensions to the runtime library and extensions to the code generator of the Graphical Modeling Framework (GMF).  </p>

<p>GMF is an generative framework to design graphical model editors based on the Eclipse platform. To create an editor, the user designs couple of EMF based models, which are fed into GMF&#39;s code generator which produces an Eclipse plug-in that implements the diagram editor. While being quite productive in the development of the first 80% of an application it is rather hard to finish the remaining 20% manually, as the underlying frameworks are quite complex.   Nevertheless, some reoccurring tasks can be cast into templates and extensions of the runtime library, encapsulating the nifty details and pushing productivity even further.  </p>

<p>This project is all about making development with GMF easier and more productive. It contains </p>

<p>Development tools M2M transformations to customize the existing/generated GMF models Template extensions for reoccurring tasks Runtime library extensions </p>

<p>If you want to stay uptodate with GMFTools, subscribe to http://groups.google.de/group/gmftools.</p>
 title : The google-summer-of-code-2008-brl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>BRL-CAD is represented and developed by a consortium of individuals in the open source community from industry, academia, government, and private industry from all over the world.  Our organizational interests in BRL-CAD vary across the project&#39;s primary focus areas including computer-aided design (CAD), computer-aided manufacturing (CAM), solid modeling, and computer graphics.  We have about a half-dozen core developers that are active on a daily basis with the project and several dozen community contributors, modelers, artists, and engineers.  Our developers predominantly interact over IRC and through our various mailing lists. </p>

<p>The BRL-CAD package is a powerful cross-platform open source solid modeling system that includes interactive solid geometry editing, ray-tracing support for rendering and geometric analysis, image and signal-processing tools, system performance analysis tools, a robust high-performance geometry engine, and much more.  Currently standing at more than a million lines of code, 400 utilities, and hundreds of man-hours investment, BRL-CAD has more than 20 years of development history (since 1979) and is in production use by more than 2000 organizations around the world (this was our last statistic before we went open source and became untraceable). </p>

<p>As useless bragging rights and fun statistics, the Ohloh source code statistics site recognized BRL-CAD as having &quot;the world&#39;s oldest source code repository&quot;.  Ohloh is a site that tracks the commit activity for more than 12,000 open source repositories performing in-depth historical analyses and commit tracking.  When they reviewed the project histories for all projects in their database, BRL-CAD came in as the oldest project that has had continuous uninterrupted activity even edging out Emacs and GCC: </p>

<p>http://www.ohloh.net/blog/worlds_oldest_source_code_repositories </p>

<p>Released as open source software just a little over three years ago, BRL-CAD has received considerable attention from the CAD and solid modeling communities.  We&#39;ve had more than 230K downloads within last 12 months alone and our download rate is increasing.  As far as we&#39;re aware, BRL-CAD is actually the only open source solid modeling system available with production-quality capabilities under an OSI-approved license. </p>

<p>The BRL-CAD user-base is primarily composed of individuals in the CAD industry where the modeling requirements are fundamentally different to those of content modelers (e.g., Blender) that are used for animation, gaming, and film purposes.  Where content modelers include commercial products like Maya, Softimage, and 3D Studio; BRL-CAD&#39;s primary competitors are in an entirely separate industry where commercial products like Unigraphics, Solidworks, Pro/Engineer, CATIA, and AutoCAD dominate.  See  for a visual overview of where BRL-CAD fits within the various CAD industries. </p>

<p>Our goal is to become the best solid modeling system available by encouraging collaboration throughout the CAD communities, improving recognition that we&#39;re a production-quality F/OSS project, providing effective/better user-friendly tools, and by continuing to work hard at implementing the features needed by our users.</p>

 title : The jaql Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Jaql is a query language designed for Javascript Object Notation (JSON), a data format that has become popular because of its simplicity and modeling flexibility. Jaql is primarily used to analyze large-scale semi-structured data. Core features include user extensibility and parallelism. In addition to modeling semi-structured data, JSON simplifies extensibility. Hadoop&#39;s Map-Reduce is used for parallelism. </p>

<p>You can get started with the JaqlOverview of the current version, and check out the RoadMap of future changes.   </p>

<p>Announcement: we&#39;ve checked in the updated syntax (+ enhancements) and are in the process of re-working the documentation to reflect the new changes. While we&#39;re working on the docs, you can get a feel for the new syntax by looking at unit tests that include all of the online examples (found at src/test/com/ibm/jaql/exampleQueries.txt). All feedback/comments/questions are greatly appreciated.</p>

 title : The jcml Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>JCML is a Java Card Specification Language based on JML (http://www.jmlspecs.org). This language has tried to solve problems about runtime checking. </p>

<p>As Java Card is a subset of Java, it’s necessary defines a subset of JML to apply specification in Java Card and check it at runtime. There are same compatibilities problems that doesn’t make possible use JML in Java Card.  </p>

<p>The new grammar corresponds to a representative subset of JML and is expressive enough to use in Java Card classes. This subset was named as JCML (Java Card Modeling Language). </p>

<p>Java CardJava Card technology provides a secure environment for applications that run on smart cards and other devices with very limited memory and processing capabilities. Multiple applications can be deployed on a single card, and new ones can be added to it even after it has been issued to the end user. Java Card technology is compatible with existing smart card standards. </p>

<p>abstract public class Applet  { 
<br/> 
<br/>   public static void install
<br/>      ( byte[] bArray, short bOffset, byte bLength ) 
<br/>           throws ISOException;  </p>

<p>   public abstract void process(APDU apdu) 
<br/>     throws ISOException;</p>

<p>   public boolean select();
<br/> 
<br/>   public void deselect();</p>

<p>   public Shareable getShareableInterfaceObject
<br/>     (AID clientAID, byte parameter);</p>

<p>   protected final void register() 
<br/>      throws SystemException;</p>

<p>   protected final void register
<br/>     (byte[] bArray, short bOffset, byte bLength ) 
<br/>         throws SystemException;</p>

<p>   protected final boolean selectingApplet(); 
<br/>} 
<br/> Applet Abstract Interface  </p>

<p>JMLTo allow a program to be verified, a formal semantics for the source language is needed. Annotations help to define the semantics of the source language by setting up a contract between the user and the developer about the usage and purpose of variables or procedures. </p>

<p>JML can be used in Java Card applets to specify functionalities in the on-card running. It requires from the specifier to get into details of Java Card specific restriction about processing and memory. </p>

<p>The Java Modeling Language (JML) is a behavioral interface specification language that can be used to specify the behavior of Java modules.</p>

 title : The jsonpp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Recursive Data-Structures Template Library (RDSTL) is currently sitting in the old JSONpp library. The RDSTL is both a library and a set of supporting libraries. The main library is the RDSTL, itself, defines an generic interface for recursive data-structures. Libraries can be built on top of the RSDTL, for instance, the XGTL, which provides run-time XPath to any data-structure which satisfies the RDSTL and some further constraints. </p>

<p>Entry points: JSON Library, BEL, XGTL, RDSTL. </p>

 title : The jtrace-psych Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>jTRACE is a freely-available re-implentation of the TRACE model of spoken word recognition. It is implemented in Java, and runs on any computer that supports Java. Researchers can run simulations quickly and easily, using code that has been validated against the original TRACE code. Advanced programmers can extend the jTRACE model to implement new behaviors. </p>

<p>Wait a minute, what&#39;s TRACE? TRACE is a highly influential model of speech perception and spoken word recognition, created by Jay McClelland and Jeff Elman (1986). The original implementation of that model was used to run dozens of simulations comparing TRACE&#39;s behavior with results from experimental studies with human subjects. TRACE&#39;s behavior accounted for human behavior in a number of important ways, and it is still frequently cited as the canonical interactive-activation model of speech perception and spoken word recognition. TRACE has proved remarkably robust, accounting for results in paradigms that were developed 10 years after the model (e.g., fine-grained time course measures from eye tracking). </p>

<p>jTRACE was created by the Magnuson Lab at the University of Connecticut with the support of the National Institute of Deafness and Other Communications Disorders.</p>

 title : The mitlm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The MIT Language Modeling (MITLM) toolkit is a set of tools designed for the efficient estimation of statistical n-gram language models involving iterative parameter estimation.  It achieves much of its efficiency through the use of a compact vector representation of n-grams. Details of the data structure and associated algorithms can be found in the following paper. </p>

<p>Bo-June (Paul) Hsu and James Glass.  Iterative Language Model Estimation: Efficient Data Structure &amp; Algorithms.  In Proc. Interspeech, 2008. Currently, MITLM supports the following features: </p>

<p>Smoothing: Modified Kneser-Ney, Kneser-Ney, maximum likelihood Interpolation: Linear interpolation, count merging, generalized linear interpolation Evaluation: Perplexity File formats: ARPA, binary, gzip, bz2 MITLM is available for download under the MIT License. It has been built and tested on 32-bit and 64-bit Intel CPUs running Debian Linux 4.0. It currently requires the following: </p>

<p>ANSI C++/Fortran compiler (GCC 4.1.2+) Boost C++ Libraries (1.32+) AcknowledgmentsThe design and implementation of this toolkit benefited significantly from the SRI Language Modeling Toolkit by Andreas Stolcke.  The project is supported in part by the T-Party Project, a joint research program between MIT CSAIL and Quanta Computer Inc. </p>

<p>©2009 Bo-June (Paul) Hsu, Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.</p>

 title : The openhtmm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Hidden Topic Markov Model </p>

<p>We propose modeling the topics of words in the document as a Markov chain.  Specifically, we assume that all words in the same sentence have the same topic, and successive sentences are more likely to have the same topics. Since the topics are hidden, this leads to using the well-known tools of Hidden Markov Models for learning and inference. We show that incorporating this dependency allows us to learn better topics and to disambiguate words that can belong to different topics. Quantitatively, we show that we obtain better perplexity in modeling documents with only a modest increase in learning and inference complexity. </p>

<p>See: </p>

<p>Amit Gruber, Michal Rosen-Zvi and Yair Weiss, &quot;Hidden Topic Markov Models,&quot; in Artificial Intelligence and Statistics (AISTATS), San Juan, Puerto Rico, March 2007.</p>
 title : The osgmodeling Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>osgModeling is a open source modeling library for OpenSceneGraph(OSG). Its purpose is to help generate kinds of parametric curves and surfaces, like extrusions, revolutions, lofts, Bezier and NURBS. Another important feature of the library is to help implement multiple polygon technologies. The subdivision of low polygons is supported at present. It also helps construct the binary space partitioning (BSP) trees and do boolean operations (Intersection, Union and Difference) based on the BSP. </p>

<p>New ReleaseosgModeling 0.1.1 is available on November 17th, 2008. Changes includes: </p>

<p>New polygon mesh generator to convert any geometries to vertices-edges-faces list. New subdivision classes to support Loop and Sqrt(3) methods to subdivide polygon meshes. New normal generator to generate normal arrays using different mean weights (MWE, MWA, MWSELR, MWAAT, MWELR, MWRELR). New osgdb_osgmodeling plugin for read/write osgModeling objects in .osg files. Only a framework at present. Support for creating the document and .chm help file based on doxygen. FeaturesSupport for 4 kinds of curves: k-degree Bezier curves. k-degree NURBS curves. Helix (3-dimensional spiral curves resembling a spring). And user customized curves. Support for 6 kinds of surfaces: m,n-degree Bezier surfaces. m,n-degree NURBS surfaces. Extrusions (constructed by a profile extruded along a path). Revolutions (constructed by a profile rotated specified angles). Lofts (constructed by lofting a series of curves that define the cross section on a specified path). And user customized models. Generate normal arrays and texture coordinate arrays for various models (except user customizations). Support generating normals with different weights. Support the normal-flip operation. Free to define customized algorithms to created vertices arrays, normal arrays and texture coordinate arrays for own models. Construct the polygon mesh structures (Vertices-Edges-Faces) for geometries. Subdivide polygon meshes into higher level using different methods. Loop method: Split each face into 4 parts at every level to build subdivisions. Sqrt(3) method: Split each face into 3 parts at every level to build subdivisions. Construct the binary space partitioning (BSP) trees for models in built or converted from osg::Geometry. Geometric boolean operations (Intersection, Union and Difference) based on BSP trees of models. SnapshotsSubdivision of the Stanford Bunny. The original model has 1500 polygons and subdivide to level 2, with Loop (Above) and Sqrt(3) methods. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Subdivision of a chess pawn. Yopu will see the different between Loop (Above) and Sqrt(3) methods (Below and seems a little unnatural at level 1). </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Models (pentagrams, bottles, curtains, and what you want) generated by osgModeling::Extrude, Lathe and Loft </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The famous OpenGL teapot generated by osgModeling::BezierSurface, a circle by osgModeling::NurbsCurve and an earth model by osgModeling::NurbsSurface </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The boolean operation bewteen a box and a sphere (not good mesh at present)</p>

 title : The overtone Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Overtone is a software framework useful for modeling devices (both physical or virtual) that exist in some physical plant (such as a home, factory or campus). Its provides a common meta model that can be used for describing devices and how they relate to each other. Device models may correspond to some attached physical hardware (such as an IR transmitter, a television or a light) or to some virtual hardware that doesn&#39;t exist in the physical system (typically some sort of controller, virtual switcher or some other system level abstraction). Overtone is implemented primarily in Java, although its design does not restrict it to the Java platform. </p>

<p>Please read the DesignPhilosophy and OvertoneModeling documenation </p>

<p>StatusI am currently working on getting the baseline framework complete.  Once it is, I will provide a release with example modules (i.e. the modules I currently use to automate my home theatre) and move to a public subversion repo. </p>

<p>I will be adding design documentation as I produce it.  I&#39;m sure the absence of code is frustrating, but releasing it at this point won&#39;t help anyone. </p>

<p>Here are the driver modules I&#39;m working on, with a quick status: </p>

<p>Lirc - A lirc to Ir Message bridge is working on linux via sockets.  Should work on windows over tcp/ip, but untested there Receivers - ... Insteon - Not Started Sonos - Researching</p>

 title : The sbpipeline Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The process of constructing and testing models, particularly those that incorporate significant prior knowledge, involves multiple steps that are currently very poorly integrated. We have developed SB-Pipeline to create an effective workflow based on open-source code, public standards and modern software practice.  </p>

<p>SB-Pipeline is a multi-faceted software platform that pulls together all of the steps involved in collecting and transforming primary data; constructing, annotating and calibrating models; and distributing and sharing simulations and analyses. SB-Pipeline is primarily concerned with data and model management for the purpose of calibration; in existing modeling tools, calibration is an ancillary rather than a primary activity. Conversely, SB-Pipeline does not recreate existing tools for model simulation. Second, SB-Pipeline implements a robust system for tracking the provenance of data, links between data and models, and the origins of model assumptions in data or the literature. Third, SB-Pipeline is a collection of discrete but interoperable software tools, rather than a single integrated system. SB-Pipeline incorporates standard protocols for import and export of data and thus components can be integrated into external packages.  </p>

<p>SBPipeline comprises a number of toolboxes to store and handle data and models in systems biology:  </p>

<p>DataRail is an open source MATLAB toolbox for managing, transforming, visualizing, and modeling data, in particular the high-throughput data encountered in Systems Biology. </p>

<p>CellNetOptimizer is a MATLAB toolbox for creating logic-based models of signal transduction networks, and training them agains high-throughput biochemical data.  </p>

<p>SbWiki  is a wiki-based system which utilizes Semantic Web technologies and a lightweight data entry and cataloging framework to support collaborative management of unstructured and semi-structured Systems Biology data.</p>

 title : The simulations-and-modeling Open Source Project on Open Hub

 summary : <p>* a swing based agile modeling tool that i developed in 1999
