<p>this API is far from complete and more features are added regularly and/or can be exposed on request (if they make sense) by contacting ifile.it support and/or administrator. I would be more than happy (free time permitting of course) to work with anyone willing to build software with ifile.it functionality</p>
 title : The imdb-api Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Donations/DonativosFeel free to donate/Esteja à vontade para doar: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>AttentionI have made another api, for tv series. It uses the site TheTVDB.com instead of IMDb. Check it out! </p>

<p>Description:This is a simple API to access IMDb information about movies and tv series. This was developed with visual studio 2008 and the solution has two projects, the actual API, that creates a dll and a commented test project to show how to use the api. Those are available in the Source section, and now in the downloads section also. In the Downloads section, it&#39;s available the most recent version of the dll, ready to be used. In the Downloads section there is also a .chm file with the API and test project documentation.  </p>

<p>Basic functions:Searchs a movie or a tv-show by title or by ID (if the search is by ID, it loads the right page immediatly, if not, it may load the correct page or a result page with a list of several movies/tv series with that title. Gets the links of a result list page and send them to the main application, where the user must choose one. Then it parses the choosen title and send the information to the user. It allows to get the title, link to imdb, year of release, url to the cover, imdb user rate, the first of the directors, the genres, plot, info of all the actors (or the number selected) listed in the main title page (name, link to actor page, link to picture and character) and the runtime. It is possible to refresh some fields of the title, choosed by the user, without changing all of them. If you try this and come across some kind of problem, please report it to me. </p>

<p>jpmassena@gmail.com </p>

<p>Descrição:Isto é um API simples para aceder a informações sobre filmes e série de TV contidas no IMDb. Foi desenvolvido com o Visual Studio 2008 e a &quot;solution&quot; contém dois projectos, o API em si, que cria um dll e um projecto de teste comentado que demonstra o uso do api. Estes ficheiros estão disponíveis na secção de &quot;Source&quot; e agora também na secção de downloads. Na secção de &quot;Downloads&quot; está a versão mais recente do dll, pronta a ser utilizada. Nesta secção também se encontra um ficheiro .chm que contém a documentação do API e do projecto de teste. </p>

<p>Funções básicas:Procura filme ou séries por título ou ID (se a procura é por ID, ele vai directamente à página correspondente, senão pode ir à página correcta ou a uma página com uma lista de resultados com o título procurado. Obtem os links da página de resultados de procura e envia uma lista à aplicação principal onde o utilizador escolhe um dos resultados. Depois o api faz o parse da pagina escolhida e envia a informação à aplicação principal. As informações que podem ser obtidas são: o título original, o link para IMDb, ano de lançamento, url para a capa, pontuação IMDb, o 1º realizador, géneros, sinopse, informação sobre todos os actores (ou só os primeiros &quot;x&quot; que decidir) listados na página normal do título (nome, link para a pagina, link para a foto e personagem desempenhada) e o tempo de duração. É possível actualizar alguns dos campos, escolhidos pelo utilizador, sem alterar os outros. Se experimentar este software e encontrar algum erro ou bug, por favor informe-me. </p>

<p>jpmassena@gmail.com</p>
 title : The ims-api Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A high-level API to access IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) services. This API hides IMS technology details and exposes service-level support to enable easy development of IMS applications. </p>

<p>High-level support for the IMS registration mechanism Support for co-location of multiple IMS Services Use of IMS service sessions (based on SIP sessions) Use of Java Media Framework for media transmision. Hiding and encapsulating internal protocols managed and used by the IMS protocol stack (and open at the same time for IMS experts). The IMS Services API allows application developers to easily utilize the IMS functionality without requiring knowledge of the underlying protocols and IMS implementation details. </p>

<p>As you can read, the abstraction level of this API is based on JSR-281 (designed for Java ME). There are slightly differences due to the fact that JavaSE offers more possibilites (for instance: audio/video captures can be more than one). </p>

<p>The API have been packaged at different levels: </p>

<p>IMS Core API - Basic IMS API and framework for building communication services.  IMS Core XDM - An framework for provisioning of Communication Services (for instance, presence, messaging) IMS Presence API - An high level abstraction API for interacting with a Presence Server (as specified by OMA Presence. IMS Messaging API - High level abstraction for interacting with a Messaging Server (as specified by OMA Messaging).</p>

 title : The javabook Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewFacebook provides a Java-based API, but I wanted a slightly different API for a few reasons: </p>

<p>The Facebook Java API returns org.w3c.Document for calls, which is quite a pain to work with. I prefer using JSON. Javabook uses json-lib, which is a good JSON library that is getting better by the month. It provides conveniences for JSON-&gt;Java bean mapping. The Facebook Java API uses the JDK&#39;s HTTP client, which is quite poor. The Apache Jakarta Commons HttpClient that Javabook uses is a much better. I wanted to incorporate logging and request latency measurement. Javabook uses Apache Jakarta Commons Logging, which integrates nicely with many Java people&#39;s existing logging infrastructure. I prefer to turn certain exceptions (such as invalid sessions) into specific exceptions that can be caught and handled by the application. I prefer separating the APIs for session-based and non-session-based Facebook methods into separate classes. While the Facebook Java API is open source, there&#39;s not an obvious community process by which contributions can be incorporated. I wanted something that could be a Maven package. </p>

<p>None of these are criticisms--I find the Facebook Java API generally well coded; I just have different requirements. </p>

<p>Javabook LimitationsThe Javabook client API is only for Web-based applications. Desktop applications cannot use this API, at least right now. The Javabook client API does not include all the read methods that the Facebook API does, as nearly all data can be requested through FQL. The Javabook API requires you to write FQL. The API is currently missing a number of methods, like dealing with photo albums. The API is mostly for Facebook applications that use FBML rather than iframes and applications that aren&#39;t using the Facebook platform. Quick StartHere&#39;s how you can make an FQL query for a user given an auth key (e.g., one that you receive from the FB login procedure). </p>

<p>      String apiKey = &quot;&quot;; // YOUR API KEY
<br/>      String secret = &quot;&quot;; // YOUR SECRET</p>

<p>      // Just create one of these for your app/process
<br/>      FacebookRpcClient fbRpcClient = new FacebookRpcClient(apiKey, secret);</p>

<p>      // You just need one of these for your app, too
<br/>      FacebookClient fbClient = new FacebookClient(fbRpcClient);</p>

<p>      String authToken = &quot;&quot;; // an auth token you&#39;ve received
<br/>      
<br/>      // creates a session from the auth token
<br/>      FacebookSession session = fbClient.createSessionKeyForAuthToken(authToken);
<br/>      FacebookSessionClient fbSessionClient = new FacebookSessionClientImpl(App.getServer().getFacebookRpcClient(), session);</p>

<p>      JSONObject obj = fbSessionClient.queryForObject(&quot;select first_name from user where uid=&quot; + session.getUid());</p>

<p>      String name = obj.getString(&quot;first_name&quot;);</p>

 title : The kindeditor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>KindEditor是一套开源的HTML可视化编辑器，主要用于让用户在网站上获得所见即所得编辑效果，兼容IE、Firefox、Chrome、Safari、Opera等主流浏览器。 KindEditor使用JavaScript编写，可以无缝的于Java、.NET、PHP、ASP等程序接合。 KindEditor非常适合在CMS、商城、论坛、博客、Wiki、电子邮件等互联网应用上使用，2006年7月首次发布2.0以来，KindEditor依靠出色的用户体验和领先的技术不断扩大编辑器市场占有率，目前在国内已经成为最受欢迎的编辑器之一。 </p>

<p>主要特点体积小，加载速度快，但功能十分丰富。 内置自定义range，完美地支持span标记。 基于插件的方式设计，所有功能都是插件，增加自定义和扩展功能非常简单。 修改编辑器风格很容易，只需修改一个CSS文件。 支持大部分主流浏览器，比如IE、Firefox、Safari、Chrome、Opera。 程序演示http://kindsoft.net/demo.php </p>

<br/>        id : &#39;your_editor_id&#39;,
<br/>        width : &#39;700px&#39;,
<br/>        height : &#39;400px&#39;
<br/>    });</p>

 title : The photobucket-api-php5 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This library, though developed by Photobucket developers, is not supported by Photobucket, and is distributed with The MIT License, provided as-is for you to use. </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>Implements the request format as shown in the examples. This is &#39;fluent&#39; syntax and provides a very readable structure. Supports multiple request methods: curl, fopen wrappers and fsockopen, with an extensible model to add new strategies in the future. Curl and fopen wrappers are not supported on every host, so I thought I would provide a few different alternatives. Those users behind proxies may want to create a derivative of one of the strategies provided to request through the proxy. Alternately, a new request strategy using the PEAR HTTP_Request could be built. Supports multiple response formats and parses them to local PHP data structures. Most of the time one would use just the PHP array serialization format, but in the event you really want to use one of the other methods, for whatever reason, those methods are available. Exceptions thrown by the server are turned into Exceptions in the library through the response parsers. Packaged as PEAR packages, but you can extract the .tgz files or check out the code and use without PEAR. </p>

<p>This library is coupled with the OAuth library also hosted on this site, which implements a relatively strict version of the OAuth spec. Both packages should be used. </p>

<p>PEAR packages will be built from the code in the branches (with corresponding version numbers), if there are changes.  For example, PBAPI-0.1 is built from the branches/release-0.1 branch.  Trunk code is potentially unstable, but usage of this line could provide valuable feedback.</p>

 summary : <p>Physical.js is a framework for rapid development with physical hardware and virtual software. It&#39;s aimed at soft-core audiences, interested in speed-of-development rather than raw, hard-core execution speed. </p>

<p>Currently used machinery: Phidgets RFID Reader. Mozilla Rhino. Jetty.</p>

 title : The piwiked Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Piwik aims to be an open source alternative to Google Analytics. This is easy to use Piwik ActionScript 3 API. It enables you to get the data from Piwik really easy and use it in your ActionScript projects - it&#39;s mainly focused on Flex framework. It also includes ready to use charts. </p>

<p>This project will be published on 7.July 2008.</p>
 summary : <p>OverviewWe just wouldn&#39;t be a true Web 2.0 company if we didn&#39;t have an API now would we? The main reason for creating the API was so that vendors could manage their shirts in our index after an approval process, but we thought it&#39;d be fun to open up access to our entire index. You can search shirts by keyword and tag, look up tags, etc. from the API. What use is this to you? We have no idea, but we&#39;re looking forward to finding out! </p>

<p>All queries to the API are sent via an HTTP GET with the exception of all of the vendor endpoints, which required an HTTP POST along with a standard HTTP-Auth username and password. All queries to the API are sent over SSL. </p>

<p>Install PEAR Package$ pear install http://pleasedressme.googlecode.com/files/Services_PleaseDressMe-0.0.1.tgzShirtsSearchThe search endpoint allows you to search the tshirt index and return a list of shirts that match the search criteria. The only argument is q and should be the query you wish to search for. </p>

<p>https://pleasedress.me/api/1.0/shirts/search.xml?q=jerryTagThe tags endpoint allows you to find tshirts by tag. It also allows you to find shirts by color since colors are just tags on a shirt. The only argument is tag and should be the tag you wish to find shirts by. </p>

<p>http://pleasedress.me/api/1.0/shirts/search.xml?q=blueTagsLetterThe letter endpoint lets you find tags that begin with the letter specified. This endpoint returns the tag, number of shirts tagged with that tag and the URL to view all shirts tagged with that tag. The letter expected is a through z or 0 through 9. </p>

<p>http://pleasedress.me/api/1.0/tags/h.xmlVendorsAll requests to vendor endpoints must be sent via SSL and use HTTP-Auth to authenticate via a POST request. Use your login email and password to access the API. You may only add shirts, which are then put in a pending queue for review and tagging, remove shirts or flush their information/image from cache.</p>

 title : The servant-api Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This java library helps to build arbitrary client-server applications. Instead of specifying details of communication protocol, the library makes accent on high level details of communication process.  </p>

<p>The communication between the client and the server is specified on general level. It allows to use this library for solving the most of the possible tasks, not losing in efficiency. </p>

<p>The library works with four main concepts: client, server, servant and connection. Client sends requests to a server. For each request the server creates special object - servant, that serves this request. To have multi-threading behavior and to handle all communication specific details the connection object is used as wrapper around servant object.</p>

 title : The springnote-api Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is springnote-api?Springnote-api is API set for the springnote service (http://www.springnote.com). This service also provides OpenAPI but this project serve a easy way to handling springnote api. </p>

<p>Springnote-api 는 스프링노트 서비스(http://www.springnote.com)의 API를 여러가지 프로그래밍 언어에서 쉽게 사용할 수 있도록 포장해놓은 API 들입니다. 스프링노트에서 제공하는 HTTP 기반의 API가 이미 존재하지만 조금 더 쉽게 사용하고자 하는 개발자들을 위한 API 세트입니다. </p>

<p>Java (1.5 or greater)  PHP ActionScript 3.0 (avm2) Release Note2008-10-20, 댓글을 가져오는 API가 추가되었습니다. getComments NOTE2007년 9월 17일부터 http를 통한 call을 사용할 수 없습니다. 새로운 springnote-api for java 0.7을 다운로드 받아 교체하시기 바랍니다. </p>

<p>HOW-TOCreate a SpringNote instanceSpringNote note = new SpringNote();
<br/>note.setOpenID(new URL(&quot;your openid here&quot;));
<br/>note.setUsername(&quot;your note-name here&quot;);
<br/>note.setUserKey(&quot;your UserKey that delived from API center (https://api.openmaru.com)&quot;);
<br/>note.setApplicationKey(&quot;your ApplicationKey that delived from API center (https://api.openmaru.com)&quot;);Get comments from the pageSpringNote note = new SpringNote();
<br/>...
<br/>List comments = note.getComments(123456);
<br/>for(Comment cmt : comments) {
<br/>  System.out.printf(&quot;%s, %s: %s%n&quot;, cmt.getCreationDate(), cmt.getCreator(), cmt.getDescription() );
<br/>}</p>

 title : The wikixmlj Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>(Part of the larger WikiSense project aimed at understanding Wikipedia for semantic annotation of texts) </p>

<p>WikiXMLJ provides easy access to Wikipedia XML dumps. </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>Easy access to important elements of a Wikipedia page Also provides interfaces for Wiki text parsing. Memory efficient SAX interface for parsing Lazy loading of files for DOM Callback support with DOM Directly operate on compressed wikipedia dumps (gzip/bzip2/native xml supported) Note: gzip streams are way faster than bzip2 for a slight trade off in space. </p>

<p>DOMParser Example: </p>

<p>import edu.jhu.nlp.wikipedia.*;</p>

<p>...</p>

<p>	WikiXMLParser wxp = WikiXMLParserFactory.getDOMParser(args[0]);
<br/>	try {
<br/>		wxp.parse();
<br/>		WikiPageIterator it = wxp.getIterator();
<br/>		while(it.hasMorePages()) {
<br/>			WikiPage page = it.nextPage();
<br/>			System.out.println(page.getTitle());
<br/>		}</p>

<p>	}catch(Exception e) {
<br/>		e.printStackTrace();
<br/>	}SAXParser Example: </p>

<p>import edu.jhu.nlp.wikipedia.*;</p>

<p>...
<br/>	WikiXMLParser wxsp = WikiXMLParserFactory.getSAXParser(args[0]);
<br/>		
<br/>	try {
<br/>		  
<br/>	    wxsp.setPageCallback(new PageCallbackHandler() { 
<br/>                           public void process(WikiPage page) {
<br/>		                  System.out.println(page.getTitle());
<br/>	                   }
<br/>            });
<br/>		
<br/>	   wxsp.parse();
<br/>	}catch(Exception e) {
<br/>		e.printStackTrace();
<br/>	}Notes: </p>

<p>1. The DOM parser is known to run out of memory despite of lazy loading the DOM tree for very large Wikipedia dumps (like English). This issue will be fixed eventually until then using the SAX parser interface is highly recommended. If you really want to use the DOM parser, try it with the callback interface.  </p>

<p>2.This should not be confused with the Java Wikipedia Parser that converts wiki-text to HTML.  </p>

<p>Dependencies: </p>

<p>All dependencies are packaged into this source. The dependencies might have different licensing terms.  </p>

<p>Apache Xerces DOM parser for lazy loading. Optionally uses bzip2 code refactored by Kohsuke Kawaguchi from Apache&#39;s Ant project.</p>

 title : The wm-api Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Библиотека для работы с XML-интерфейсами WebMoney в среде Microsoft .Net. Основные преимущества библиотеки: </p>

<p>1. Легко добавлять новые интерфейсы. Вся логика зашита в классах специальной серилизации, которые при добавлении новых интерфейсов не изменяются.  </p>

<p>2. Специальные типы (такие как WMID, кошелек и пр.) позволяют избежать многих ошибок исполнения.  </p>

<p>3. Использовать библиотеку легко! Библиотека содержит XML-комментарии, на основании которых автоматически генерируется документация и подсказки для разработчика в Visual Studio.  </p>

<p>4. Библиотека работает как с представлением ключей WM Keeper Classic, так и с сертификатом WMKeeper Light.</p>

 title : The barrio Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Active development in this project has ceased. However, some of the ideas of Barrio are now addressed in our new project, gql4jung.  </p>

<p>Barrio is a dependency analyzer for object-oriented programs implemented in Java. It discovers and visualizes community structures in the dependency graph which might represent opportunities to refactor the program into a more modular structure. For instance, a package containing two independent clusters could be split, and the new packages could be deployed in separate jar files. Barrio will also detect if there are few   dependencies that destroy the modularity of programs (i.e., glue clusters together). </p>

<p>For more information, see  </p>

<p>Dietrich, J., Yakovlev, V., Mccartin, C., Jenson, G., and Duchrow, M. 2008. Cluster analysis of Java dependency graphs. In Proceedings of the 4th ACM Symposium on Software Visualization (Ammersee, Germany, September 16 - 17, 2008). Softvis08. ACM, New York, NY, 91-94. DOI: http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1409720.1409735 </p>

<p>The following figure shows the dependency graph of the classes in the Apache Commons Collection library analysed with the barrio Eclipse plugin. The blue and red regions show clusters and explicitly defined packages. The large package on the left side of the graph contains several clusters, and could therefore be split.   </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Barrio is designed as an Eclipse plugin. Barrio has the following features: </p>

<p>Barrio can import dependency graphs stored as ODEM files (these graphs can be generated with CDA from bytecode). Barrio can also extract the graph from project source code. Graphs extracted from source code can be exported back to ODEM files. Barrio can apply filters to the graph. Barrio can visualize the graph. Visualization is based on Prefuse. Barrio can find clusters in the graph based on the Girvan-Newman algorithm. The Jung implementation of the algorithm is used. Barrio allows users to set a separation level in order to remove edges destroying the modularity of the program. Those edges might present refactoring opportunities. The discovered clusters are compared with the modular structure of the program (i.e., the use of packages and jar containers). Barrio can be used to define stereotypes based on rules. For instance, UI classes can be defined as classes referencing the java.awt package. UsageThe software is distributed using the Eclipse Update mechanism. The update site is http://barrio.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/barrio.update/ . Please check from time to time for new versions. The plugin requires Eclipse version 3.3 or better! Once installed, you will need some input data. You can download a zip file containing sample data from the download section, or create data for your own project using the CDA tool.  Planned featuresDetection of motifs (patterns) in the graph using a declarative graph query language.</p>
 summary : <p>This will hold custom gephex and frei0r modules (real time video effects applications) and small 3D apps using OpenSceneGraph and OpenGL. </p>

<p>See binarymillenium.com for updates and information I haven&#39;t yet turned into wiki pages.</p>
 title : The binarymillenium Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewBio3D is an R package containing utilities for the analysis of protein structure, sequence and trajectory data.  </p>

<p>It is currently distributed as platform independent source code under the GPL version 2 license.  Please visit the Main Bio3d Site for further information, Installation instructions, Quick start guide and full Documentation. </p>

<p>FeaturesThe ability to read and write structure, sequence and dynamics trajectory data. </p>

<p>Perform atom summaries, atom selection, re-orientation, superposition, rigid core identification, clustering, torsion analysis, distance matrix analysis and principal component analysis of structure data. </p>

<p>Perform conservation analysis of sequence and structural data. </p>

<p>In addition, various utility functions are provided to enable the statistical and graphical power of the R environment to work with biological sequence and structural data. </p>

<p>CitationBio3D: An R package for the comparative analysis of protein structures. Grant, Rodrigues, Elsawy, Mccammon, Caves, (2006) Bioinformatics 22, 2695-2696 FULL TEXT</p>

 title : The blopex Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Block Locally Optimal Preconditioned Eigenvalue Xolvers (BLOPEX)1 is a package, written in C and MATLAB/OCTAVE, that includes an eigensolver implemented with the Locally Optimal Block Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient Method (LOBPCG) 2. Its main features are: a matrix-free iterative method for computing several extreme eigenpairs of symmetric positive generalized eigenproblems; a user-defined symmetric positive preconditioner; robustness with respect to random initial approximations, variable preconditioners, and ill-conditioning of the stiffness matrix; and apparently optimal convergence speed.  </p>

<p>BLOPEX supports parallel MPI-based computations. BLOPEX is incorporated in the HYPRE package and is available as an external block to the PETSc package.  SLEPc and PHAML have interfaces to call BLOPEX eigensolvers, as well as DevTools by Visual Kinematics. </p>

<p>1 A. V. Knyazev, I. Lashuk, M. E. Argentati, and E. Ovchinnikov, Block Locally Optimal Preconditioned Eigenvalue Xolvers (BLOPEX) in hypre and PETSc  (2007). SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing (SISC). 25(5): 2224-2239, http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/060661624. </p>

<p>2 A. V. Knyazev, Toward the Optimal Preconditioned Eigensolver: Locally Optimal Block Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient Method. SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing 23 (2001), no. 2, pp. 517-541. http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/S1064827500366124</p>

 title : The staticwiki Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Use wiki syntax and notation to produce a website. This should make it much easier to control the markup. Styles are entirely separated from content. The actual wiki renderer is a separate module which can be used in other (more dynamic) products.</p>
 summary : <p>clustelA java implementation of a grid based clustering algorithm intended for clustering points on maps.  </p>

<p>The project evolved from the need to cluster hundreds of points to avoid overloading the browser and user with overlapping and unnecessary points at lower zoom levels. </p>

<p>how it worksBeginning with a single cluster it recursively divides clusters until the maximum number of clusters is reached or the minimum scale is reached. It determines which cluster to next subdivide by applying a cluster index.  The cluster index is simply the area of the cluster mulitplied by the scale of the cluster (relative to the initial cluster size). </p>

<p>Download the jar and have a look at the example to get started. </p>

<p>documentationBuild from the source A quick example</p>

 summary : <p>The cluster validation toolbox is a collection of functions for evaluation of cluster indices. The toolbox contains: </p>

Henning link) extensible standard adapter for cluster algorithm, implemented for 4 cluster algorithms ( PAM, KMeans, DBScan and Chinese Whispers) parametergenerator for cluster algorithms, the parameters are generated depending on the distance matrix of dataset  automatic batch calculation of partitions and cluster indices: for some datasets with optional reference partitions run a set of algorithm, with different parameter sets per algorithm a set of inner cluster indices an external index for comparing result cluster with reference clusters save the results per dataset and algorithm visua</p>

 title : The blexisma2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a suite of several software agents to provide a complete architecture of lexical base as proposed in Didier Schwab&#39;s PhD. thesis. It will be used for automatic translation, information retrieval and other natural language processing tasks.</p>
 summary : <p>This software package allows the user to perform various consensus clustering operations on any numerical data using PCA to select informative features. </p>

<p>NewsNEW - The power of consensus clustering with the speed of the GPU: The first alpha of CUDAConsensusCluster has been released! </p>

<p>Defining clusters explained! Find out how to track your clusters between runs in DefiningClusters. </p>

<p>Clustering can now be fully automated! See command line options in the CmdLineOpts Wiki. </p>

<p>Current Version - 0.6You can find the most current version for your operating system in the &quot;Featured&quot; box on the right of this page. </p>

<p>InstallationIf using the Win32 binary, simply extract the zipped folder.  The executable is called &#39;common.exe&#39; </p>

<p>If using the source package, please have the following packages installed: </p>

<p>Required, all OS </p>

<p>Python 2.6 (3.0 NOT currently supported) Python-numpy &gt;= 1.1.0 Python-scipy </p>

<p>Highly Recommended, all OS </p>

<p>Python-matplotlib &gt;= 0.98.0 Python-pil &gt;= 1.1.6 Python-pygtk </p>

<p>Linux Optional </p>

<p>psyco GCC GNU Make pyMPI </p>

<p>Please see the README file for operating system instructions for installation of the C-Source modules, which are HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for purposes of increased speed.  There are also instructions for the use of multiprocessing using MPI on linux systems. </p>

<p>Quick Start GuideCreate a tab-delimited file for your data.  Put the &#39;samples&#39; to be clustered in the columns, and the &#39;features&#39; that define them in the rows.  Make sure the first row and the first column are labels. </p>

<p>Example </p>

<p>SAMPLE_IDSample 1Sample 2... Gene 13.42341.4244 ... </p>

<p>To use the GUI, run common.exe or type python common.py from a command line if you downloaded the Win32 binary or the python source, respectively. </p>

<p>Choose File-&gt;Open and select your datafile.  Make sure Normal is the selected parser (this is the parser which understands the file format described in the example above.) </p>

<p>Click Begin Clustering.  Clustering progress will be tracked in the text window and output in the form of PNG and LOG files. </p>

<p>Configuration option descriptions are found in the Settings Wiki: http://code.google.com/p/consensus-cluster/wiki/Settings</p>
 title : The consensus-cluster Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The cougarcluster Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Code for producing clusters of data for the Eastern Slopes Cougar Project., </p>
 summary : <p>Information retrieval is a traditional application for computers that has become even more prominent with the advent of the World Wide Web. The process of retrieving content from a text corpus (collection of text files) is normally managed by analyzing the text files to produce an index, and then having a separate query engine that uses the index to retrieve the desired text from its source files. For Project 5, queries will retrieve documents instead of lines. Hence, the structure of the index file and the kind of analysis used to construct it will differ somewhat from that of Projects 3 and 4. Other differences will include the kinds of queries allowed and the user interface.</p>

<p>For this project, the analysis tool is called DTI (pronounced ditty and standing for Document-Term Indexer), and the query tool is called RABID (Retriever and Browse Indexed Documents).</p>

 title : The ctypes-opencv Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ctypes-opencv is a package that brings Willow Garage&#39;s (formerly Intel&#39;s) Open Source Computer Vision Library (OpenCV) to Python. OpenCV is a collection of algorithms and sample code for various computer vision problems. The goal of ctypes-opencv is to provide Python access to all documented functionality of OpenCV.  </p>

<p>Advantages   </p>

<p>Complete interface to OpenCV&#39;s CXCORE, CV, HighGUI components. Pythonic interface. OpenCV&#39;s objects are safely deleted when not used. No need to invoke cvRelease...(). Pure Python package. Neither C/C++ compiler nor OpenCV&#39;s source code is needed. Support for both versions 1.0 and 1.1pre1 of OpenCV. Cross platform, running on any OS that OpenCV can be installed, including: Windows, Linux, and Mac OS X. Ability to convert between OpenCV&#39;s arrays (CvMatND, CvMat, and IplImage) and arrays used in wxWidgets, NumPy, PyGTK, and PIL. </p>

<p>Disadvantage   </p>

<p>No support for OpenCV&#39;s ML component yet. This is a limitation of the current ctypes package. The ML component contains mostly C++ classes. ctypes at the moment cannot wrap C++ classes and their member functions. This limitation will be overcome in the future. A new Python wrapper using Boost.Python and NumPy has been under development. </p>

<p>ExamplePython code for demonstrating K-Means Clusteringfrom ctypes_opencv import *
<br/>MAX_CLUSTERS=5</p>

<p>if __name__ == &quot;__main__&quot;:</p>

<p>    color_tab = [CV_RGB(255,0,0),CV_RGB(0,255,0),CV_RGB(100,100,255), CV_RGB(255,0,255),CV_RGB(255,255,0)]
<br/>    img = cvCreateImage(cvSize(500, 500), 8, 3)
<br/>    rng = cvRNG(-1)
<br/>    cvNamedWindow( &quot;clusters&quot;, 1 )
<br/>        
<br/>    while True:
<br/>        cluster_count = cvRandInt(rng)%(MAX_CLUSTERS-1) + 2
<br/>        sample_count = cvRandInt(rng)%999 + 1
<br/>        points = cvCreateMat(sample_count, 1, CV_32FC2)
<br/>        clusters = cvCreateMat(sample_count, 1, CV_32SC1)
<br/>        
<br/>        # generate random sample from multigaussian distribution
<br/>        for k in range(cluster_count):
<br/>            first = k*sample_count/cluster_count
<br/>            last = (k+1)*sample_count/cluster_count if k != cluster_count else sample_count
<br/>            if first &lt; last:
<br/>                cvRandArr(rng, cvGetRows(points, None, first, last), CV_RAND_NORMAL,
<br/>                    cvScalar(cvRandInt(rng)%img.width,cvRandInt(rng)%img.height), cvScalar(img.width*0.1,img.height*0.1))
<br/>        cvRandShuffle( points, rng )
<br/>        
<br/>        # K Means Clustering
<br/>        cvKMeans2(points, cluster_count, clusters, cvTermCriteria(CV_TERMCRIT_EPS+CV_TERMCRIT_ITER, 10, 1.0))</p>

<p>        cvZero( img )
<br/>        for i in range(sample_count):
<br/>            pt = points[i,0]
<br/>            cvCircle(img, cvPoint(cvRound(pt[0]), cvRound(pt[1])), 2, color_tab[clusters[i,0]], CV_FILLED, CV_AA, 0)
<br/>        
<br/>        cvShowImage( &quot;clusters&quot;, img )</p>

<p>        if &#39;%c&#39; % (cvWaitKey(0) &amp; 255) in [&#39;\x1b&#39;,&#39;q&#39;,&#39;Q&#39;]: # &#39;ESC&#39;
<br/>            breakEquivalent C code for demonstrating K-Means Clustering#ifdef _CH_
<br/>#pragma package 
<br/>#endif</p>

<p>#ifndef _EiC
<br/>#include &quot;cv.h&quot;
<br/>#include &quot;highgui.h&quot;
<br/>#endif</p>

<p>int main( int argc, char** argv )
<br/>{
<br/>    #define MAX_CLUSTERS 5
<br/>    CvScalar color_tab[MAX_CLUSTERS];
<br/>    IplImage* img = cvCreateImage( cvSize( 500, 500 ), 8, 3 );
<br/>    CvRNG rng = cvRNG(-1);
<br/>    CvPoint ipt;</p>

<p>    color_tab[0] = CV_RGB(255,0,0);
<br/>    color_tab[1] = CV_RGB(0,255,0);
<br/>    color_tab[2] = CV_RGB(100,100,255);
<br/>    color_tab[3] = CV_RGB(255,0,255);
<br/>    color_tab[4] = CV_RGB(255,255,0);</p>

<p>    cvNamedWindow( &quot;clusters&quot;, 1 );
<br/>        
<br/>    for(;;)
<br/>    {
<br/>        char key;
<br/>        int k, cluster_count = cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%MAX_CLUSTERS + 1;
<br/>        int i, sample_count = cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%1000 + 1;
<br/>        CvMat* points = cvCreateMat( sample_count, 1, CV_32FC2 );
<br/>        CvMat* clusters = cvCreateMat( sample_count, 1, CV_32SC1 );
<br/>        
<br/>        /* generate random sample from multigaussian distribution */
<br/>        for( k = 0; k &lt; cluster_count; k++ )
<br/>        {
<br/>            CvPoint center;
<br/>            CvMat point_chunk;
<br/>            center.x = cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%img-&gt;width;
<br/>            center.y = cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%img-&gt;height;
<br/>            cvGetRows( points, &amp;point_chunk, k*sample_count/cluster_count,
<br/>                       k == cluster_count - 1 ? sample_count :
<br/>                       (k+1)*sample_count/cluster_count, 1 );
<br/>                        
<br/>            cvRandArr( &amp;rng, &amp;point_chunk, CV_RAND_NORMAL,</p>

<p>                       cvScalar(center.x,center.y,0,0),
<br/>                       cvScalar(img-&gt;width*0.1,img-&gt;height*0.1,0,0));
<br/>        }</p>

<p>        /* shuffle samples */
<br/>        for( i = 0; i &lt; sample_count/2; i++ )
<br/>        {
<br/>            CvPoint2D32f* pt1 = (CvPoint2D32f*)points-&gt;data.fl + cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%sample_count;
<br/>            CvPoint2D32f* pt2 = (CvPoint2D32f*)points-&gt;data.fl + cvRandInt(&amp;rng)%sample_count;
<br/>            CvPoint2D32f temp;
<br/>            CV_SWAP( *pt1, *pt2, temp );
<br/>        }</p>

<p>        cvKMeans2( points, cluster_count, clusters,
<br/>                   cvTermCriteria( CV_TERMCRIT_EPS+CV_TERMCRIT_ITER, 10, 1.0 ));</p>

<p>        cvZero( img );</p>

<p>        for( i = 0; i &lt; sample_count; i++ )
<br/>        {
<br/>            int cluster_idx = clusters-&gt;data.i[i];
<br/>            ipt.x = (int)points-&gt;data.fl[i*2];
<br/>            ipt.y = (int)points-&gt;data.fl[i*2+1];
<br/>            cvCircle( img, ipt, 2, color_tab[cluster_idx], CV_FILLED, CV_AA, 0 );
<br/>        }</p>

<p>        cvReleaseMat( &amp;points );
<br/>        cvReleaseMat( &amp;clusters );</p>

<p>        cvShowImage( &quot;clusters&quot;, img );</p>

<p>        key = (char) cvWaitKey(0);
<br/>        if( key == 27 || key == &#39;q&#39; || key == &#39;Q&#39; ) // &#39;ESC&#39;
<br/>            break;
<br/>    }
<br/>    
<br/>    cvDestroyWindow( &quot;clusters&quot; );
<br/>    cvReleaseImage(&amp;img);
<br/>    return 0;
<br/>}Related Python wrappers for OpenCVOpenCV has its own swig-based Python wrapper. However, it has conflicts in memory management between C/C++ and Python, and hence is not suitable for large projects. It is also particularly hard to maintain and develop.  </p>

<p>Another project called CVtypes was pioneered by Michael Otto and is currently maintained by Gary Bishop (at http://wwwx.cs.unc.edu/~gb/wp/blog/2007/02/04/python-opencv-wrapper-using-ctypes/). The wrapper is based on ctypes. It supports a large set of OpenCV&#39;s functions and a limited set of OpenCV&#39;s structures.  </p>

<p>I used to provide some improvements to CVtypes here and there. While Gary Bishop was a kind professor, I felt not so nice to keep asking him to update his code. Therefore, I decided to branch from his CVtypes, and the result is this project. ctypes-opencv supports a fairly complete set of OpenCV&#39;s structures and functions. More importantly, I have put a lot of efforts in making ctypes-opencv faster, better memory-managed, and easier to use, by not only adopting but also improving the pythonic interface introduced by OpenCV&#39;s developers. Nevertheless, credits should also go to OpenCV developers, and CVtypes&#39; authors and contributors. I intend to eventually merge back to Gary Bishop&#39;s CVtypes when the project is mature enough. </p>

<p>Bugs and CommentaryPlease send information on issues of usage to Minh-Tri Pham , post a message to ctypes-opencv&#39;s discussion group, or create an issue in the Issues pannel.</p>

 title : The dblp-expert-finder Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewAn Expert Finder System for DBLP.  Extends the ACM Computing Classification System to build a hierarchy of expertise areas.  Associates experts with areas of expertise in this extended taxonomy. </p>

<p>This work is a part of Philip Fisher-Ogden&#39;s Master&#39;s Thesis at UC Davis.  Professors Michael Gertz and Ian Davidson are the thesis advisors for this research. </p>

<p>Primary GoalsExpertise areas: synthesize associations between topics and experts, enabling expertise identification for a given topic or a given researcher. Taxonomy: extend an existing taxonomy to produce an exploratory interface to browse for experts in. Contributions1. We augment the information in DBLP with enough additional data to be able to make a judgment on expertise areas and experts for a given area. </p>

<p>2. We address the problem of topic extraction by leveraging existing author-generated metadata to build a light weight controlled vocabulary. </p>

<p>3. We propose an exploratory interface for finding experts that utilizes an extended form of a well known taxonomy combined with spatio-temporal visualizations of each node&#39;s document sets. </p>

<p>MilestonesBuilding an expert finder system for DBLP requires reaching the following milestones: </p>

<p>Create an object/domain model for the DBLP data and load the DBLP XML data into a database.  (Leverage JAXB and JPA technologies to do this) Create an object model for the ACM Computing Classification System taxonomy and load the XML version of that taxonomy into a database.  (Leverage JAXB and JPA technologies to do this) Extract classification information, general terms, keywords, and abstracts for each DBLP entry and associate that information with each DBLP entry in a database. Associate topics in the extended taxonomy with researchers that have published on each topic. Provide an interface to allow users to identify experts for a given topic, where the topic is an element in the extended taxonomy. Identify communities of expertise. Evaluate various spatio-temporal visualizations for the exploratory interface. </p>

<p>Related WorkFaceted DBLP allows users to browse the DBLP data using keyword searches and faceted navigation.  It also allows users to automatically generate categories from their search results by using the Semantic GrowBag algorithm LinksFor a current list of links related to this effort, see my thesis links on delicious.</p>
 title : The detecting-repeated-shapes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This program attempts to detect repeated shapes in images, using segmentation and hierarchical agglomerative clustering of image segments. The program was developed in the hope that this would be a useful adjunct to developing content based image recognition. </p>

<p>As a more practical matter, the code can create attractive image transformations. </p>

<p>More information on the original project, including samples, is located at my website.  </p>

<p>The abstract follows: </p>

<p>An important visual capability is the ability to quickly detect the presence of multiple similar shapes in an image. We seek a fast method to either determine that no repeated objects are in a image, or to determine that there are repeated objects and identify them. We term this the perceptual clustering property. We segment an image and present a heuristic for the similarity between image segments, and then cluster segments. For segmentation we use the fast MST-based image segmentation presented by Felzenszwalb &amp; Huttenlocher. We define a metric space for segments based on simple per-segment measures including color, size, rough shape etc. Over this space we cluster using a modified hierarchical agglomerative clustering (HAC) algorithm based on shortest distance between clusters. The running time is dominated by the segmentation algorithm, which is itself quite fast; run times are on the order of one second for 240×320 images. We find that our clustering does indeed capture the perceptual clustering property for a wide variety of images.  </p>

<p>The code is in C. Originally written in 2004, I am updating the code to be based on Felzenszwalb&#39;s new code release of December 2006. The initial repository tag is of Felzenszwalb&#39;s segmentation code.</p>

 title : The digital-philology Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Sic ergo quaeramus tamquam inventuri, et sic inveniamus tamquam quaesituri.  (Saint Augustine, De Trinitate, IX, 1,1) 
<br/>Interpretive Semantics, is a linguistic theory founded by François Rastier. It is a &quot;second-generation&quot; synthesis of European structural semantics, developed in the wake of Saussure. François Rastier aspires to reunify hermeneutics and philology in material hermeneutics. </p>

<p>This paper, Web Semantics V. Semantic Web, he wrote recently, explains the ideas behind this project. </p>

<p>We aim at building the basic computer platform of this endeavor. We will focus in particular on string processing (Finite State Technology, Suffix Trees, Suffix Array), textual statistics (cooccurrences, clustering, statistical learning) and textual interfaces (annotations, passage of text highlighting). Eclipse is the development and integration platform. </p>

<p>The first very important step of this project is to build a Textual Data Base Management System (TDBMS) </p>

<p>Visit our site at www.esemio.com </p>

<p>contact: cmauceri@gmail.com</p>
 summary : <p>In short its less sophisticated version of Google News </p>

 title : The dowser Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rewrite of dowser.sf.net. Currently in planning stages and in need of at least one more good Python hacker. Please email me if you are interested. </p>

<p>Basic Design Goalscross-platform and cross-browser transparent archiving of web pages that matter to the user change tracking of URLs after they have been added to the archive fully portable archives fast search, keyword extraction, summarization metasearch (?) advanced search tools (custom filters, results clustering, etc) Big-Picture GoalsMake it easy and useful to archive &amp; re-find /everything/ you read World domination   My 20-year goal is to lay the groundwork for a network of independent, redundant, internet archives. They&#39;d do what libraries do: collect and preserve. Several archives already exist, such as archive.org and the Google cache. But Google&#39;s cache exists for Google&#39;s purposes. Archive.org is often forced to take down material because they are a sitting target. We need a real decentralized network that is both lawyer- and disaster-resistant.  </p>

<p>It is impossible for, say, the New York Times to change or obliterate what it printed on some day in 1997. For NYT.com it&#39;s a simple as a mouseclick and a letter. That means there is no such thing as &quot;public record&quot; on the internet. Public record is the basis of a literate society.</p>
 title : The dssh Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Given a role name execute a given command on a cluster of machines.</p>
 title : The LDE(X) for Windows Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>An advanced, modular, production-proven, multi-user Windows 2000/XP LiteStep-based desktop environment distribution that supports plugins, alternative interfaces and is designed for reliability and extensibility.</p>
 title : The elcluster Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The elastic cluster allows the creation of a cluster within the Amazon EC2 cloud. This cluster is able to dynamically allocate additional nodes to handle increased traffic. When traffic decreases, spurious nodes are killed off. All nodes within the cluster communicate using a peer to peer protocol and elect a master. The master is the owner of various resources, which could include an elastic IP address as well as a load balancing daemon. </p>

<p>The test setup utilizes nginx for load balancing and an elastic IP address. Slave (non-master) nodes run apache to serve content.</p>

 title : The ep-kawa Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>KAWA is a web-based service where scientist can either upload or execute pre-defined workflows for bioinformatics data analysis. The workflow engine and definion format is driven by Taverna (developed at EMBL-EBI and Manchester University with other collaborators).</p>

<p>KAWA will be integrated closely with the Expression Profiler/DIAMONDS framework for microarray data analysis, and will include several pre-defined workflows for common tasks like large-scale data normalization, filtering, clustering and visualization. KAWA will take advantage of the powerful computing infrastructure the European Bioinformatics Institute has to offer. KAWA can also function independently of these frameworks.</p>

 title : The erlinda Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Vision StatementProvide a high level framework for developing high performance applications that can scale linearly with higher resources. </p>

<p>AbstractWe live in the world where Moore&#39;s law and Von Neumann&#39;s model of programming will soon be obsolete. As Dr. Dobb&#39;s article http://www.ddj.com/web-development/184405990;jsessionid=0LJW3X4MBU5TSQSNDLRSKH0CJUNN2JVN?_requestid=131749 on &quot;Free Lunch is over&quot; indicated we will have to adjust in this world. Fortunately, parallel programming field has been dealing with this for several decades and there are plenty of solutions available. Unfortunately, most of them are still very research oriented and difficult to use in the real world. I wrote similar system called JavaNOW several years ago as a research project in Java that I will port to Erlang. I plan to leverage concurrency capability of Erlang language and its supported libraries such as OTP and provide a framework for writing high performance applications. Though, Erlang is concurrent language and OTP provides sophisticated support for writing fault tolerant services and provides high availability (with hot code swaps), but it does not inherently support writing parallel applications. Erlinda fill in that gap and provide abstraction to write high performance applications. It is built on top of Erlang and OTP and uses RabbitMQ for messaging middleware. </p>

<p>IntroductionErlinda provides a framework for writing parallel applications. It provides a number of abstractions for creating parallel applications such as: </p>

<p>Tuple Space model based on Linda memory model (JavaSpaces) MPI like APIs for communication (Scatter/Gather) Map/Reduce Master/Slave (Computing Farm) Service oriented (OTP) Clustering Agents and Mobililty Messaging oriented (Queues/Topics) Service/Resource discovery mechanism (similar to JINI) Integration with other languages and middlewares Code Server (similar to JINI/RMI) Security </p>

<p>Project OwnerShahzad Bhatti ContactEmail: bhatti AT plexobject.com URL: http://bhatti.plexobject.com Join the ProjectThough, Erlinda is in early phase of development, anyone who wants to get involved is welcome, especially with experience with Erlang/OTP and parallel computing. Any feedback or suggestions is greatly appreciated.</p>

 title : The gusto Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Gusto!</p>

<p>   Gusto is a set of APIs for building intelligent web 2.0 applications with semantic similarity, content analysis, collaborative filtering, recommendation functionalities etc. </p>

<p>You can use Gusto in a wide range of applications: e-commerce and product recommendation, Jobs and profile matching, Social networks and user profiles, etc. </p>

<p>The goal of Gusto is to provide the common bricks necessary for building intelligent applications, rather than developing them from scratch. Check the documentation for more details. </p>

<p>The current version 0.8.3 of Gusto focuses on the semantic similarity module, check the Semsim documentation to try the module and don&#39;t hesitate to send us your precious feedback. Other modules are in the process of being integrated. </p>

 title : The h2osgi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Enable deployment of the H2 Database in OSGi containers.  </p>

<p>What is the value in this? I&#39;m still looking at different scenarios. Here&#39;s what I have so far: </p>

<p> H2 is nearly 3x faster in embedded mode. But in this mode it is available only to the application that launched it. As an OSGi service, H2 and any db instance becomes available to as many OSGi applications or services as you want, in-VM...with run-time deployment. This is very compelling. Additionally, the database can be run in  mixed mode (embedded and vi TCP/IP) so that standard SQL tools and processes can connect over the network.  We&#39;ll see OSGi versions of java databases like we do with http servers, j2ee servers, etc. With this model, I can choose to embed the database in my application code or just deploy it as a service that other services listen for and use.  H2 functionality (services) can be mixed and matched as needed rather than as one monolithic deployment. This cuts down on deployment footprint and opens the door for 3rd party value-add services. For example, here is how H2 might be service-ized: </p>

<p>H2 Core Service (Memory and Embedded) Remote Service(s), http, ftp, other Lucene Service Web, Shell, Swing/JFX/GUI Admin Services Replication/Clustering Services Persistence Manger for JPA or JDO drop-in services App Specific Services Status (6/2/08): I have successfully wrapped and launched H2 as an OSGi service and will post the code when the project is more organized.  </p>

<p>Status (1/3/09): After job change and move I&#39;m finally back to it. I&#39;ve uploaded code for a concept proof. Using mvn you can package a ConsoleService-xyz.jar file. It&#39;s a bundle that can be installed into an ipojo-enabled osgi container (Felix). Or you can just download the .jar file since I&#39;ve included the target directory as well with this commit. Basic stuff but it&#39;s a start. Also checkout the powerpoint in the /doc directory. Next step is to decide a reasonable way to segment osgi into bundles while keeping in sync with the main development line. Suggestions and participation welcome...Erik</p>

 title : The hounder Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Hounder allows you to crawl the web, index documents and search them. It can be used to build a standard web search engine or to integrate into existing apps to index and search  data. </p>

<p>Hounder is designed as a whole product, with the idea of bringing a complete search engine solution that runs out of the box. It includes an installation wizard (powered by wiz4j) and a webapp for monitoring &amp; controlling all parts of the engine (powered by clusterfest). </p>

<p>Hounder is built in java based on Apache&#39;s Lucene. It can be run as standalone process, allowing for communication via different RPCs (xml-rpc, RMI, etc), integrating with applications written in any language. </p>

<p>Hounder was designed for performance, it can handle a great number of concurrent queries and can be distributed across several search and indexing servers to increase the number of indexed documents and query performance. </p>

<p>Documentation </p>

<p>ContributingTo join the project send an email to the project administrators or write to the hounder mailing list.  </p>

<p>You can also send modifications as patches via e-mail.</p>

 title : The icsisumm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This summarization system, crafted for the Text Analysis Conference (TAC) evaluation campaign, generates summaries by extracting sentences that contain the most frequent word bigrams (called concepts) from the input documents. It uses Integer Linear Programming (ILP) for determining, under a length constraint that set of sentences. With this system, we obtained very good scores for the update task at the TAC&#39;08 evals and among the best scores at TAC&#39;09. </p>

<p>So far, we only released the raw code which contains a lot of dependencies to internal stuff at ICSI, but we plan to add a cleaned-up, standalone version for public use. </p>

<p>NEWS: </p>

<p>2009-12-28 Added TAC&#39;09 code </p>

<p>DEPENDENCIES: </p>

<p>glpsol , ILP solver splitta, sentence splitter icsiboost, a classifier nltk, for tokenization and stemming Berkeley Parser, a constituency parser mate, a dependency parser and SRL system (unreleased yet, use your own) </p>

<p>Note that the SRL system is only needed if you want to use sentence compression in TAC&#39;09. </p>

<p>REFERENCES: </p>

<p>Dan Gillick, Benoit Favre, Dilek Hakkani-Tür, Bernd Bohnet, Yang Liu, Shasha Xie, &quot;The ICSI/UTD Summarization System at TAC 2009&quot;, to appear in Text Analysis Conference, Gaithersburg, MD (USA) - 2009 Daniel Gillick, Benoit Favre, &quot;A Scalable Global Model for Summarization&quot;, NAACL/HLT 2009 Workshop on Integer Linear Programming for Natural Language Processing - 2009 Dan Gillick, Benoit Favre, Dilek Hakkani-Tür, &quot;The ICSI Summarization System at TAC 2008&quot;, Text Analysis Conference, Gaithersburg, MD (USA) - 2008</p>

 title : The lingdongsearch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The linloglayout Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewLinLogLayout is a simple program for computing graph layouts (positions of graph nodes in two- or three-dimensional space) and graph clusterings. It reads a graph from a file, computes a layout and a clustering, writes the layout and the clustering to a file, and displays them in a dialog. LinLogLayout can be used to identify groups of densely connected nodes in graphs, like communities of friends or collaborators in social networks, related documents in hyperlink structures (e.g. web graphs), cohesive subsystems in software systems, etc. With a change of a parameter in the main method, it can also compute classical &quot;nice&quot; (i.e. readable) force-directed layouts. </p>

<p>The program is primarily intended as a demo for the use of its core layouter and clusterer classes MinimizerBarnesHut, MinimizerClassic, and OptimizerModularity.  While MinimizerBarnesHut is faster, MinimizerClassic is simpler and not limited to a maximum of three dimensions. </p>

<p>LinLogLayout optimizes LinLog and related energy models to compute layouts, and Newman and Girvan&#39;s Modularity to compute clusterings.  For more information about LinLog and Modularity, see </p>

<p>A. Noack. Energy Models for Graph Clustering, Journal of Graph Algorithms and Applications, 11(2):453-480, 2007. M. E. J. Newman. Analysis of Weighted Networks, Physical Review E, 70:056131, 2004. A. Noack. Modularity Clustering is Force-Directed Layout, Physical Review E, 79:026102, 2009. </p>

<p>UsageUsage: java LinLogLayout    computes a -dimensional layout and a clustering for the graph in , writes the layout and the clustering into , and displays (the first 2 dimensions of) the layout and the clustering.  must be 2 or 3. </p>

<p>Input file format: Each line represents an edge and has the format   , where the weight is optional and defaults to 1.0. </p>

<p>Output file format:      </p>

<p>Example: java -cp bin LinLogLayout 2 examples/WorldImport1999.el WorldImport1999.lc </p>

<p>Example </p>

<p>The screenshot shows a layout and a clustering of the world trade graph, where the nodes represent countries, and the edge weight of each node pair specifies the trade volume between the corresponding countries.  Both the layout (node positions) and the clustering (node colors) group the countries of the three major economic areas East Asia / Australia, America, and Europe.  The layout also reflects that countries like IRN and EGY are rather between the East Asian and the European group, and shows many smaller groups like CHN and HKG, AUS and NZL, and GBR and IRL.</p>
 summary : <p>Automatizar juegos de palabras, </p>

 summary : <p>A simulation of galaxy crashes., </p>

 title : The mailsrvd Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Mail server daemon that accepts incoming emails (it is an MTA), sends outgoing emails, and serves POP3.  Uses an MySQL database to store most configuration, and all email data.  Handles multiple domains easily and good for virtual hosting. </p>

<p>Development on this project is slow.  It does what the original author needed it to do, and hasn&#39;t got much further than that. </p>

<p>It currently does not send emails out, and POP3 support hasn&#39;t been tested very well (it works for us) </p>

<p>Installation is not very well automated because we were the only ones using it, and we hadn&#39;t had to install it anywhere else </p>

<p>If you want more development done on this, we&#39;ll see what we can do.</p>
 title : The Famulus Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Back in 80&#39;s there were outstanding czech program for computer modeling called Famulus. We&#39;ve decided, that it&#39;s time to bring it back to live, since many poeple still use it, but no development was done in last 15 years.</p>
 title : The majimock Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MajiMock is a toolkit to help you write unit tests for Java code. Its primary focus is to help developers generate and use mock implementations of Java interfaces and classes in their unit tests, but it includes several other useful features. </p>

<p>MajiMock helps you to: </p>

<p>Generate mock implementations of interfaces and classes on the fly in test code. Express expected interactions between the code under test and mock objects, and later verify that the interactions have occurred. MajiMock provides a record-replay style API for defining expectations. Express constraints using predicate objects and make assertions about whether predicates hold true for objects under test. The predicates can be used quite separately from mock objects. Test asynchronous code. Again, this can be used separately or in conjunction with mock objects. Write JUnit tests. MajiMock provides a number of utility classes and fixtures commonly used to write JUnit test cases.</p>
 summary : <p>Utilize all kind of Machine Learning approach to enhance antispam techniques.

 title : The migok Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Simple application which was written for my MSc thesis. It clusters microarray data using various algorithms and selected similarity metric. Similarity metric can be composed from gene expression similarity and KEGG/GO similarities. The application allows to asses how using a priori biological knowledge helps to improve clustering results. (at least it was meant to do so :)</p>

 title : The moduleeval Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Gene lists can be partitioned by their expression profiles, cis-regulatory information and other features.  Here we explore and develop existing methods for the functional evaluation of those partitioned groups.  When the features of a group are both cis-regulatory and expression gene signature data, then they are considered cis-regulatory modules (CRE).   </p>

<p>One generally accepted method uses counts of Gene Ontology (GO) terms and determines statistical significance based on the hypergeometric distribution (Cho et al, 2001).  There are similar methods based on the binomial distribution, chi-squared test for equal proportions (Fisher et al, 1993) and the Fisher&#39;s exact test (Man et al, 2000).  Another method based on information content and the graphic nature of GO was implimented by Speer et al, 2005.  Additionally, there are several Bayesian methods.        </p>

<p>We aim to create a module evaluation software.   </p>

<p>Cho, RJ., et al., (2001) Transcriptional regulation and function during the human cell cycle. Nat. Getet., 27, 48-54.  </p>

<p>Fisher, LD., et al., (1993) Biostatistics: A Methodology for Health Sciences, John Wiley and Sons, New York.  </p>

<p>Man, Mz., et al., (2000) POWER_SAGE: comparing statistical tests for SAGE experiments: Bioinformatics, 16 953-959.  </p>

<p>Speer, N., et al., (2005), Biological Cluster Validity Indices Based on the Gene Ontology},  Advances in Intelligent Data Anylsis VI: 6th International Symposium on Intelligent Data Analysis (IDA 2005), (2005) 3646, Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS),429-439</p>
 summary : <p>Windows LDAP editor, includes support for POSIX groups and accounts, SAMBA accounts, some Postfix objects and more</p>

 title : The papertoolkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Note: Ron graduated from Stanford and is not currently maintaining this project. So it&#39;s currently frozen in its mid-2007 state. He&#39;d love to help transfer this project to a new project lead, or advise someone in designing/implementing a PaperToolkit 2.0 from scratch. If you are interested, please email him. </p>

<p>Also: You may be interested in the new LiveScribe digital pen (http://www.livescribe.com/) which also provides a Java SDK </p>

<p>DescriptionThis is a toolkit for building applications that integrate pen, paper, and computers. The toolkit leverages Anoto pen technology to provide a next-generation design environment for pen-and-paper interactions. </p>

<p>Although this toolkit is mostly in Java and Flash, it depends on the Anoto SDK, which is built on .NET. Thus, the toolkit does not work on Mac OS X computers, although the individual Java and Flash components can be used or inspected. </p>

<p>RequirementsWindows XP Windows Vista (if you can get Bluetooth to not BSOD your computer) Java 6 Anoto SDK (to work with digital pens, see http://www.anoto.com/) Nokia SU-1B digital pen (also works with other digital pens, but tested mostly with the Nokia)</p>

 title : The parametric Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Your content already has great meta data?  Wouldn&#39;t it be nice to give your users access to that information to help refine their search results?  The Google Search Appliance and Google Mini support for parametric search makes using that metadata a breeze.  Simply plug in this AJAX-based UI component, and see search in a whole new light. </p>

<p>Hint: This module dynamically creates facets based on meta tags within your indexed corpus. If you are interested in a solution that adds a faceted search menu that is static, you should take a look at a project called gsa-faceted-search: http://code.google.com/p/gsa-faceted-search/.  </p>

<p>Please email us at enterprise-labs@google.com after you download the software so we can keep you up-to-date on new versions and bug fixes as they are released.  You can also join the Google Enterprise Labs Discussion Forum to ask questions, hear about new experiments that are coming, and suggest ideas for new experiments!</p>

 title : The philomine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PhiloMine (release 2)PhiloMine is a &quot;drop-in&quot; extension to current  releases of PhiloLogic, to support a variety of machine learning, text mining, and document clustering tasks. It is designed to work with databases loaded under PhiloLogic, with extensions included in this release. PhiloMine release 2 is a completely rewritten and significantly enhanced revision of our first release  PhiloMine.  Like PhiloLogic, PhiloMine is a Free Software implementation designed to support research and development activities at the ARTFL Project and the Digital Library Development Center with the generous support of the  Provost&#39;s Program for Academic Technology Innovation (ATI) at  the University of Chicago. </p>

<p>If you are interested in PhiloMine2, we recommend that you first consult our Poster Session  Abstract which is to be presented at the Digital Humanities 2008 conference to be held in Oulu Finland, June 25-29th and our PhiloMine Tour which provides an extensive overview of PhiloMine&#39;s functions and interface.   </p>

<p>Installing PhiloMine is a non-trivial exercise.  Much of this work involves installation of our very numerous dependencies. We expect this code to be fairly volatile so please do take the latest version from our  Downloads.  We have tested our  installation instructions on two different flavors of Mac OS-X.  You will also find on our Wiki, instructions on PhiloMineLoad, HintsAndTips, a  Bibliography and a list of FunctionsAndParameters (pending).   </p>

<p>Contact: Please direct all comments, suggestions, bug reports, etc. to  artfl DD project ASIGN gmail DD com (you know what to do with this). </p>

<p>Philomine was a common 19th century French name (particularly Québécois), probably derived from Philomena, patron saint of &quot;lost causes&quot; amongst other things.</p>

 title : The phyutility Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Phyutility (fyoo-til-i-te) is a command line program that performs simple analyses or modifications on both trees and data matrices. Makes use of JADE (PEBLS) and JEBL libraries. Please see the NEWS page for info concerning updates, etc. </p>

<p>Please use this citation when using Phyutility Smith, S. A. and Dunn, C. W. (2008) Phyutility: a phyloinformatics tool for trees, alignments, and molecular data. Bioinformatics. 24: 715-716 </p>

<p>Currently it performs the following functions (to suggest another feature, submit an Issue and use the label Type-Enhancement) : </p>

<p>Trees </p>

<p>rerooting  pruning  type conversion  consensus  leaf stability  lineage movement  tree support  Data Matrices </p>

<p>concatenate alignments  genbank parsing  trimming alignments  search NCBI fetch NCBI please reroot your trees before performing the leaf stability, lineage movement, or consensus functions -- unrooted functions for these will be incorporated ASAP </p>

<p>07-04-2009 Uploaded new .jar file for phyutility. Please download this and replace your existing phyutility.jar file (of course, if yours is named Phyutility.jar, change the name of the new file to reflect that). If you haven&#39;t downloaded phyutility package before, please download both and replace the .jar in the folder with the new one. More features soon!</p>

 title : The picktools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Pick is a python tool set for extracting and analyzing data from open source mailing lists and source code repositories. </p>

<p>Currently, it can parse and store the following information into a relational database: </p>

<p>email messages, with parsed header info and directional conversation graphs threads of conversation in mailing list email addresses and repository usernames, linked to the real humans that use a set of them.  successful and non-successful patch submissions in mailing list repository commits and comments version controlled files lines changed in each commit method interfaces, interface changes, start and stop line of methods (limited language support) methods changed in each commit (limited language support)    See the wiki for more information on each module.  </p>

<p>Pick uses a custom framework for state management and logging. It is designed to be extended and is easily modified and this makes Pick a great research tool.  </p>

<p>Many academic papers have been based on the data produced by Pick. Some examples are:  </p>

<p>Bird, C., Gourley, A., Devanbu, P., Swaminathan, A., and Gertz, M. Mining Email Social Networks, ICSE 2006 Workshop on Mining Software Repositories (MSR 2006) </p>

<p>Christian Bird, Alex Gourley, Premkumar Devanbu. Detecting Patch Submission and Acceptance in OSS Projects. ICSE 2007 Workshop on Mining Software Repositories. 2007. </p>

<p>Michael Ogawa, Kwan-Liu Ma, Christian Bird, Premkumar Devanbu, Alex Gourley, Visualizing Social Interaction in Open Source Software Projects (Asia-Pacific Symposium on Visualisation 2007) </p>

<p>Thanks go to Professor Devanbu at UC Davis for paying me to write the first version of this as an undergrad and then letting me liberate it. Thanks also go to Christian Bird for letting me include his clustering module.</p>

 title : The plop Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Common Lisp framework for experimenting with meta-optimizing semantic evolutionary search (MOSES) and related approaches to learning with probability distributions over program spaces based on: </p>

<p>reduction to normal form representation-building deme (sub-population) management probabilistic model-building (aka estimation-of-distribution algorithms)  </p>

<p>ContributingJoin the plop-dev mailing list File a feature request or bug under Issues, or tackle one already listed (also see the ToDo list) Try the code on your favorite Common Lisp implementation other than CLISP &amp; SBCL and see if it works or not Add comments to the code, critique the design, add unit tests ... Try the system out for supervised classification / timeseries prediction / whatever on your favorite data set (note that it will probably do rather badly at the moment as the system is still very immature and some important subcomponents are just stubs) and post your results</p>
 title : The poy4 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to the public source code repository of POY version 4!POY is a phylogenetic analysis program written in OCaml and C. POY version 4.0 supports the inclusion if insertions, deletions, translocations, loci indels, inversions, as well as breakpoint distances in the phylogenetic analysis of molecular and morphological sequences. It supports sequential and parallel execution using an implementation of the Message Passing Interface Standard (MPI), such as MPICH or Open MPI. </p>

<p>We provide precompiled universal binaries for Windows (parallel and sequential), Mac OS X  (parallel and sequential), and Linux (sequential only), in the project&#39;s homepage. </p>

<p>Latest released version is: 4.1.2.1 (August 6, 2009). </p>

<p>Latest development version is: 4.1.2.1 (August 6, 2009).</p>

 title : The redpoll Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to Redpoll! The name of this project redpoll means a kind of small finches in northern North America and Eruasia, having a red crwon and black chin. We hope our project will grow agilely like these kinds of birds. </p>

<p>What is Redpoll?Redpoll is a distributed machine learning library written in java. It works by the power of hadoop, which is an open source implementation of google&#39;s MapReduce computing Model. We intent to parallelize some traditional classification, clustering algorithms like Naive Bayes, K-Means, EM so that can deal with large-scale data sets. It&#39;s Apache 2.0 licensed. </p>

<p>Who may use Redpoll?People who want to do data mining on large-scale datasets as well as those who are interested in distributed computing or data mining. </p>

<p>News25 November 2008K-means clusterer implementation Canopy performance improvement. 9 November 2008This commit, adds a canopy implementation, was developed in a rush. It still exists somewhat space inefficiency problems inherit from mahout. </p>

<p>6 November 2008It can successfully create tf-idf based vector space model now. Some bugs were fixed. 4 November 2008 - It can parsing Sogou News NowA hadoop style sogou record reader is finished. link: sogou news datasets   First map/reduce stage for analyzing the textual stuff and counting the document frequency for each term and outputting the results is done.  Has added a method for feature selection to increase precision of next steps.  Getting StartedTutorials will come soon. </p>

<p>Architecture</p>
 title : The rhizosphere Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rhizosphere is an innovative approach to help you navigate and filter through your data. Lightweight, web-based, intuitive, its purpose is to provide a simple but effective way to flow through your data, isolate them, filter them and help you locate that information that you know it&#39;s there, but it&#39;s lost amidst the noise.  </p>

<p>100% pure HTML and JS, no Flash, no Java, no Silverlight, no plugins. You just need your browser.  </p>

<p>The Rhizosphere project focuses both on traditional and innovative ways to browse through data:  </p>

<p>A desktop like metaphor, with Selections and Drag&#39;n&#39;Drop Zooming Dynamic Filtering Data layouting Data fetching and remoting Interoperability with multiple sources Color coding and information clouds The project focuses on merging together the benefits of the desktop metaphor with the ubiquity and flexibilty of a web based approach. </p>

<p>Rhizosphere integrates with other technologies and can be used to navigate your data inside Google Docs and Google Gadgets. </p>

<p>Wanna learn more?Visit the Project Site or Give it a try</p>

 title : The sadbit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project implemented lots of popular Data-Mining/Machine-Learning algorithms.All candidate algorithms must be proper to implemented on Distribution and|or Parallel computing platform, such as Hadoop. 
<br/>The ultimate goal of this project is to resolve the store and compute for very large dataset, especial for high-dimension. I known it is very difficult for this topic, if you would like to join into this challenge, please mail to me: moonblue333@hotmail.com.  
<br/>Thanks Wei.Dong at cs.princeton.edu for LSH. 
<br/>Additional, There is a &#39;proof of concept&#39; software about distribution database, the attachment is ting-0.5.0.zip. More information about it please refer to: http://www.sadbit.com or sadbit333.appspot.com (Do not ask for source-code password for this package: ting-0.5.0.zip(binary is OK); but password for any other package is OK.) 
<br/>  </p>

<p>The research focus in 2009:  
<br/>1) how to prepare data input such as special normolization to fit the LSH to get better 3-rate. 2) how to construct a better kernel-LSH to fit the final similarity-metric, such EMD, grid-feature. 3) search and research the better similarity-metric algirthms. (so far, the EMD and grid-freature are better, at least better than original L1, L2.) </p>

<p>I will update this summary to introduce all implemented main algorithms:  
<br/>Hash-Family:     
<br/>LocalitySensitiveHash ConsistentHash PerfectHash MinimalPerfectHash BloomFilter(Hash) CuckooHash DynamicHash ExtendableHash LinearHash     Image-Processing: 
<br/>Color-Space Transformation Edge-Histogram EMD ImageGridFeatureExtraction Others        Dimension-Reduction/Feature-Extraction: 
<br/>LLE Wavelet PCA ICA           AI-Related: 
<br/>ANN SVM    Distribution-Computing: 
<br/>Paxos (TODO)Failer-Detection-Algorithms</p>
 title : The saje Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A generic application platform, with an architecture loosely based on that of the popular multi-protocol instant messenger Miranda. It is implemented in pure Qt (c++) and will therefore run on multiple platforms including Windows, Linux and Mac OS X. </p>

<p>Current functionality includes a minimal Jabber client, with SSL and MD5-DIGEST authentication (meaning it can be used with google talk and most jabber hosts), support for multiple accounts and jabber &#39;transports&#39;. </p>

<p>The core program is just a plugin loader - all functionality is made available via plugins. This enforces modularity and ensures well defined component interaction via interfaces.</p>

 summary : <p>息壤（SeRang）面向理性应用群网的引擎 类似GAE的app. Engine </p>

<p>故事初始讨论贴 </p>

<p>不过这名字忒土了，要有趣有意义好记，
<br/>建议先在社区中讨论一下</p>

<p>比如说 息壤 XiRang
<br/>等等 ;)</p>

<p>息壤，信息的土壤?</p>

<p>NOT! 息壤 是中国神话中的神物，可以生成土壤的法宝哪，
<br/>所以，可以是
<br/>SeRang
<br/>= SeRang engine for Rational application network group
<br/>面向理性应用群网的息壤引擎息壤 是中国神话中的神物，可以生成土壤的法宝哪 http://zhidao.baidu.com/question/11894088.html?fr=qrl http://scholar.ilib.cn/abstract.aspx?A=mzsfgdzkxxxb200201010 等等，都有相关描述的... </p>

<p>...“息壤土”果然神奇，撒到何处，何处就会形成高山挡住洪水，并随水势的上涨自动增高。 </p>

 title : The simplebeat Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple 2-node Active/passive cluster designed to be robustQ:Why is it so limited? </p>

<p>A:It&#39;s simple. </p>

<p>Q:Why is it simple in design? </p>

<p>A:It&#39;s the heart of the UNIX philosophy. </p>

<p>Q:But I need ! </p>

<p>A:Sorry, &quot;Removed code is debugged code&quot;. -- suckless.org </p>

<p>Q:I need support for distribution ! </p>

<p>A:Be my guest, but Keep It Simple. </p>

<p>IntroductionThis simple 2-node cluster aims to be easy to use and changed if needed. This cluster is supposed to have: </p>

<p>Replicated shared storage to be mounted by the means of DRBD (Distributed Replicated Block Device: a distributed storage system for the Linux platform) One or more services/applications to start on failover One or more virtual network interface(s) to provide the clients of the services a single hostname</p>
