 title : The toolz Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A collection of random tools in python.  Mostly geared towards scientific data processing and visualization.</p>
 summary : <p>AbstractThe android platform provides the ability to geo-locate data easily and at all times. The potential list of applications that can use such location aware data is endless. Topophilia is a pluggable framework for location aware data. It enables applications/modules to query for location aware clusters (a center point and radius) and enables the user a central UI for most location aware applications. </p>

<p>MotivationGeolocated information will be one of the most interesting field within the forthcoming mobile market. The ability to generate geobased data in real time and space gives the ability to create endless applications. Such application will affect the way we live and interact. The android challenge showed a majority of submitted application being geolocated. Each generating different data with the singularity of being geolocated. The idea of topophilia was born out of it. Being able to group the data generated from several applications within a single framework - and map overlay. Users will be able to see all geo data on a single map and have a good view of different information coming from different application. </p>

<p>Geoaware data should be kept private while enabling mining and clustering. Topophilia will be released under LGPL and will provide a transparent framework. We don&#39;t want to use the data in other means then social mapping. Its final aim will be to provide and open and transparent framework (both android based and web based).    </p>

<p>Module exampleA photo application might take geolocate the position of the picture. Such application will suit idealy to topophilia. Its integration would be closed to fully. </p>

<p>Another example is a navigation system. The navigation system might not require to display all data within Topohilia. The application might want to just displayed saved routes or favorite routes.  </p>

<p>The list of modules can be found here. </p>

<p>A wishlist of modules can be found here. </p>

<p>If you have created a module, send an email to ... and we will add it to the above list </p>

<p>Technical information and future evolutionThe aim of topophilia is to link and cluster the data together. Topophilia is not intended to generate any information on its own. It will cluster data from other applications - called modules - and enable modules to be &#39;aware&#39; of other applications. For instance you will be able to query for any modules with the following uri: </p>

<p>content://topophilia/modsThe main aim of topophilia is to map the geo data to a user defined place. For instance, a user living in London will most likely define a place called london against which to cluster data. A place is defined by its center (latitude and longitude) and its radius. You can query for all user defined places with the following uris: </p>

<p>content://topophilia/placesThe following will give all modules that generated some information for that place - in this case london: </p>

<p>content://topophilia/places/london/modsIf you want to get the data generated by a module for a specific place, you would use: </p>

<p>content://topophilia/places/london/mods/</p>
 title : The topophilia Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The vmsom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Aim of the project is to create various models of the Self Organizing map, which can be used for clustering different types of data sets such as images, music, text and so on. </p>

<p>The toolkit will contains the SOM models of type, a) Simple SOM (SOM) b) Growing SOM (GSOM) c) Hierarchical SOM (HSOM) d) Growing Hirearchical SOM (GHSOM) e) High-Dimensional Growing SOM (HDGSOM) f) Randomized High-Dimensional Growing SOM (HDGSOMr) g) Hyperbolic Hierarchical SOM (H2SOM) h) Randomized Hyperbolic Hierarchical SOM (H2SOMr) I) any other SOM that needed to be added. </p>

<p>Along with these SOM models, some applications will also be added so that one can also find the usability for each of these SOM&#39;s.</p>

 title : The wcdest Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>wcd is an open source tool for clustering expressed sequence tags. It implements matching using either d2 or edit distance, which provides sensitive matching. Heuristics speed up the clustering process. wcd parallelises well under MPI and also provides Pthreads clustering.  wcd has a very compact memory representation which means that large files can be clustered on a single processor (and it can run quite happily without MPI or Pthreads headers or libraries being available). Of course, if you have a 100 CPU cluster -- it&#39;ll go much faster!</p>

 title : The STIHRS Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The xtdoi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>创业成功的七个必要条件　　团队：共同认可的理念+专属技能+性格合拍的人。理念就不多说了，没有统一的目标最好不要创业，不然到后面还是以分裂告终。技术是网站的基础，如果技术很薄弱，最好也不要创业，否则除了不能将理念完全表达、延误项目进度外，失去对于初创最重要的时间，就意味着机会和成本的失去。技术最好有个比较强的架构师，产品是网站的核心，你未来要怎么发展基本就看构架了。市场是初创期重要的角色，除非你不想让别人知道你们的存在，有业内媒体资源的人是必须的，如果没有，现在开始培养也来得及。团队成员性格要合拍，至少在初期是必要的，没有必要把时间花在内耗上，最好是有过一段时间配合过的朋友。 </p>

<p>　　产品：价值+创新。我们在做一个产品的时候，考虑的就是它的价值，对于用户的价值是什么，商业价值是什么。对于互联网创业我更愿意看作是一种创造性的工作，我们在创造新的事物、创造一种新的服务，或者改变了提升了现有服务，让用户的体验更好。同时我们所创造的商业价值，要明白迎合哪些人。创业是为了创造商业价值，如果你不清楚商业出口在哪里，未来谁为你的创业买单？你还需要考虑，产品的差异化，不要和巨头去竞争。 </p>

<p>　　用时间去经营心态。时间是检验项目成功与否的根本条件，创业不是半年一年的事，需要用心去经营。创业将会面对很多困难，很多时候对内心而言是种煎熬，坚持未必胜利，但放弃必然失败。做企业是困难的，它需要经历几个阶段，第一步需要开发及完善，第二步需要巩固用户，第三步需要将用户积累到一定规模，第四步也许才是尝试性的商业探索，第五步也许才是真正的规模商业模式发展，然后继续发展，扩大规模。这些都需要时间，这些都需要平稳的心态稳步去经营，任何一个行业都无法改变商业的本质，商业的规则是恒定不变的，浮躁的心态只能揠苗助长，最终无所收获，包括投资的急功近利。 </p>

<p>　　资金。初创期需要必要的资金，至少你知道这笔钱可以让你的项目走向一定的轨道，这笔资金的来源更应该来自团队内部，如果你的钱不足以支持必要的发展，那最好不要创业，否则只能是浪费时间和金钱。项目到了一定程度，投资是必要的，但是遇到短视和投机的投资者，创业者就要格外小心，因为投资而毁掉项目发展的案例不计其数。融资是创业者和投资者博弈的过程，需要平起平坐，包括对人格、心态、价值的相互认可。 </p>

<p>　　适度的工作经验。世界上非常成功的互联网公司80%的创业者创业年龄小于30岁。同时90%的大学生创业会失败。所以适度的工作经验是必要的，它更多考验的是创业者对未来无法预测事物的敏感度和判断力，往往正是因为这种凭感觉的决策决定了创业的成功与否。同时很多职业素养也是在工作中磨砺出来。 </p>

<p>　　推动项目发展的必须资源。比如你要做个购物或商务社区，对于这个项目发展的必须资源可能是：某个领域的意见领袖、某类产品的销售渠道、潜在的合作伙伴、社区传播的营销渠道、具有高端客户资源的传媒公司等等。如果你的资源范围内不具备必要的资源，那么很有可能在发展到一定阶段的时候，会非常缓慢甚至被后起之秀超越。没有资源的人往往为他人做嫁衣，除非你的产品优秀到VC没有选择。 </p>

<p>　　营销的传播通路、口碑。初创期的企业，难有足够的实力去推广项目，也没有足够的市场预算，所以需要巧妙的借势而行，调动web2.0的口碑力量。在这个互联网眼球经济的时代，曝光度也会决定项目一定的价值含量。如果你可以整合一些资源帮助传播的网站，借用blogger口碑的力量，联合一些低成本传播的群体，或者人脉关系的媒体资源，都能够大大推动项目的市场工作，行之有效而且成本很低。初创企业需要懂得以小博大的道理。 </p>

<p>　　也许如此合拍的人有缘分在一起合作就是多么的一种幸福，无论如何的风险，无论如何的结果，这段因为共同奋斗而多彩的经历也会让我们感到人生中多了一座曾经胜利的里程碑！ </p>

<p>BANNER BATTLE      </p>

<p>李嘉诚先生的商业训导查看详细 </p>

<p>扩张中不忘谨慎，谨慎中不忘扩张。……我讲求的是在稳健与进取中取得平衡。船要行得快，但面对风浪一定要捱得住。  好的时候不要看得太好，坏的时候不要看得太坏。最重要的是要有远见，杀鸡取卵的方式是短视的行为。   人才取之不尽，用之不竭。你对人好，人家对你好是自然的，世界上任何人都可以成为你的核心人物。  不为五斗米折腰的人，在哪里都有。你千万别伤害别人的尊严，尊严是非常脆弱的，经不起任何的伤害。  与其到头来收拾残局，甚至做成蚀本生意，倒不如当时理智克制一些。</p>
 summary : <p>Zenoss is a powerful, integrated, easy-to-use IT infrastructure monitoring software product.</p>

<p>* Zenoss provides a compelling alternative to:
<br/>low-end commerical monitoring tools that provide limited functionality and scaleability (e.g What&#39;s Up Gold...)</p>

<p>* High-end commercial packages that are notoriously expensive and complicated (e.g. IBM Tivoli, BMC Patrol, HP OpenView...)</p>

<p>* Building an integrated, scalable open source solution yourself by pulling together many component projects</p>

<p>Zenoss is a written in Python using Zope, MySQL, RRDtool, PySNMP, Net-SNMP, libsmi, sendpage, Twisted and several other open source components.</p>

<p>Zenoss is monitoring-focused today; it will evolve to include deeper &quot;management&quot; functionality through additional development and partnering with other open source projects.</p>

 title : The zenpdb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SummaryZenPDB is a Python module to process and analyze macromolecular structures. Macromolecular structures are represented as hierarchically nested python dictionaries, which allows to traverse and manipulate them in a pythonic way and implement structural biology algorithms compactly. This module is also useful to establish processing pipelines. ZenPDB is currently capable of parsing and writing PDB files, but PDBML input is also planned. </p>

<p>ZenPDB provides fast and versatile Cython implementations of important algorithms in structural biology, namely accessible surface area (ASA) and distance contact calculations by using kd-trees for nearest neighbour look-up. It is crystallography-aware and can construct crystal lattices, unit cells and biological units. </p>

<p>DocumentationInstallationDependencies</p>

 title : The nading-network-library Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to the Nading.Network.Library </p>

<p>UPDATE: added new libs that now include the new packet queue system for those that dont want to use the events. you will have to enable or disable the queue system when you start the client or server if you are going to use it or not. also some other minor changes and cleanups.. pretty stable version up! </p>

<p>This library was written in and for the .NET Framework.. Visual Basic, C# and Managed C++. The library utilizes the .NET sockets class. Its a Client / Server architecture driven by events. </p>

<p>Some of the current features include: </p>

<p>TCP so all packets are delivered in order guaranteed. Excellent Packet organization with packet and packettype Single line of code to send a packet Your own custom packet types, anything you want Event based connections, disconnections and packet transfers Super simple implementation with less than 10 lines of code for a complete client </p>

<p>Some basic single line of code functions include: </p>

<p>Connect() to server Disconnect() from server Send() sends a packet to the server utilizing a packet type StartServer() starts the server StopServer() stops the server SendPacketToClient() sends a packet to a single specified client utilizing a packet type SendPacketToAllClients() sends a packet to all connected clients utilizing a packet type DropClient() drops a client from the server All actions are risen with events. </p>

<p>Functions in progress include: </p>

<p>Dynamic automated encryption and decryption transparent to your code Ability to poll bandwidth statistics including packets sent and network ping times Functions to allow for bandwidth throttling Lag situations simulated Multiple client simulation scenarios Automatic replication of any type or object on both ends Built-in heartbeat system to ensure connectivity Multiple levels of data compression</p>

 title : The lazyhome Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The scan-network Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>On a debian like system, scan_network is a little tool running during the bootup process to dynamically generate the interfaces file. It targets on aiming mobile users who have static ip settings, wifis, and different networks around but painful to all of these into interfaces file since whenever you have a static info in interfaces file, the boot process just waits forever to get over it when you are NOT in that env anymore. Instead of writing those configuration info into interfaces, you write to scan_network profile files and then you can just leave the rest of things to scan_network. It will probe the right ip setting for you when you are in a certain network env and ignore those aren&#39;t going to work. No wait on boot time!</p>

 title : The skipole-monitor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This program is a network monitor. </p>

<p>Skipole-Monitor allows the user to input host IP addresses, it then regularly pings these hosts and displays their status via a built-in web server. It can optionally send email alerts and syslog messages if the hosts change status. </p>

<p>So calling http://your_pc_address:8000 will display pages showing green, yellow or red host or group symbols. </p>

<p>Each host is pinged four times every interval (default five minutes), and symbols are displayed as: </p>

<p>green  : if three or four pings are successful 
<br/>yellow : if only one or two are successful 
<br/>red    : if all four fail 
<br/>As well as hosts, group symbols are displayed, and can be opened to show hosts, or sub-groups nested within. The operator can create groups, and sub-groups via the gui. </p>

<p>It has been tested on Windows XP and Linux platforms. </p>

<p>Windows users; to install, download and run skipolemonitor_0_80_py25_install.exe </p>

<p>Linux users; a tar file of Python source code is available in the downloads section. You will also need WxPython and the Python Imaging Library (PIL) which are used to provide the gui and graphing functions. See the Wiki for details. </p>

<p>To upgrade: save the network data somewhere safe, uninstall the old version, re-install the new version. </p>

<p>Further information, including screen shots can be found at </p>

<p>http://www.skipole.net</p>

 title : The whiteboard-over-network Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>There is always a need for conferencing. There are several application for instant messenging (IM) with remote people. The programs usually feature text, audio and video chatting and file transfers. Some IMs can host conferences. Conferences are rooms with invited users. Text conferences are possible with the Jabber protocol. But none of the popular IM services (MSN Messenger, Jabber, Yahoo IM, Skype) provide group CASE and diagram creation. </p>

<p>Whiteboard Over Network (WON) is a tool written in Gtk+ for making on-line whiteboard conferences with other people. The tool transmits data in encrypted form and draws shapes using vector graphics. </p>

<p>Features </p>

<p>totally opensource conferencing tool, security with TLS encryption, certificates, vectorized graphics, portable to Windows, Linux, FreeBSD. </p>

<p>The tool is written in C language using the Gtk+ library for creating user interfaces and GnuTLS for data encryption. Becose Gtk+ supports cairo which is a library for drawing vector graphics, so the tool can use this feature to draw smooth shapes.</p>

Convert (convert2DTo3D) Convert a 2D maze into a 3D maze by adding width and height to the walls. View (view3DMaze) View/handle a 3D maze from afar. Explore (explore3DMaze) Step inside the maze and explore it in a first person fashion.    </p>

 title : The ambienthackystat Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PurposeThe AmbientHackystat project is, at its essence, a system of alerts that lets a development team be aware of the status of their project at all times. But instead of blaring alarms whenever a build fails or annoying pop ups that can distract a developer while he&#39;s on a roll, the AmbientHackystat project uses ambient devices that unobtrusively reminds a developer of the current state of the project. These devices simply change color or move around a little when a build fails or if unit tests are not passing.  </p>

<p>The AmbientHackystat project is a offshoot of the Hackystat project. Where the Hackystat project aims to gather information from developers through sensors installed on the developer&#39;s computer and tries to make sense of that data, the AmbientHackystat project takes that same data, which we call &quot;Triggers,&quot; and links them to &quot;Actions&quot; that are carried out by a Ambient Device such as the Ambient Orb or the Nabaztag Bunny. This &quot;Trigger/Action Pair&quot; is the core of the AmbientHackystat project.  </p>

<p>Here&#39;s a screen shot of our program in action (command line version): </p>

<p> </p>

<p>CapabilitiesCurrently, we have two types of Triggers that we can use and two different ambient devices that carry their own set of actions. The type of triggers that we have available are SensorData Triggers and Coverage Triggers. SensorData triggers can take the data from QA tools such as !JUnit, CheckStyle and PMD and assign a threshold value to it. The value could be something easy as passing a build or CheckStyle check or you could bundle a couple triggers together to create complicated triggers.  </p>

<p>As for Actions, we have two ambient devices currently interfaced into our server, the Ambient Orb and the Nabaztag Bunny. The Ambient Orb has the ability to change its color and its animation in reaction to a trigger. The Bunny on the other hand can move its ears and convert text into speech in reaction to a trigger.  </p>

<p>More informationTo learn more about the project, please visit the GuidedTour, Actions, and Triggers pages.  </p>

<p>To install the project, visit the InstallationGuide. </p>

<p>To install the source and develop on the project visit the DevelopersGuide. </p>

<p>To view the project user interface, it is actually another project and can be viewed here: AmbientHackyStat UI </p>

<p>The ambient devices we currently using with this project are: </p>

<p>Ambient Orb Nabaztag Rabbit </p>

<p>More may be added in the future. </p>

<p>AmbientHackystat (AH) Important Links: </p>

<p> AH Discussion Group - Please visit our discussion group if you are a project member and would like to discuss issues.    AH Wiki pages - Please visit our wiki pages for detailed information regarding this project.   ICS 414 Discussion Group - This site contains our Software Engineering class&#39; discussion board.  Javadoc pages - You may not be able to view it correctly on Mozilla Firefox.  Use Internet Explorer. Known Issues Road Map</p>
 title : The ambienthackystat-ui-wicket Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project provides a web application interface using wicket for the AmbientHackystat project.  The user interface is adapted from the Hackystat-ui-wicket project by Dr. Philip Johnson. </p>

<p>PurposeThe ambient server, at its current state, can only be run from the command line because it has no user interface. This also creates implications with editing the configuration file for the ambient server.  To edit a configuration file, a user must open the configuration file and edit its contents manually.  Additionally, the ambient server needs to be restarted every time changes are made to a configuration file in order for the changes to take effect. </p>

<p>One of the goals of the project is to simplify the editing of the configuration file for running the ambient server.  With the user interface, we hope to eliminate the editing of a configuration file manually.  We hope to display the configuration file through the user interface and have the user edit the file through the interface.  Additionally, we hope that it will automate the restart process of the ambient server.  This means that the user does not even have to touch the ambient server file as everything should and can be done from the user interface. </p>

<p>CapabilitiesThis project was started in the first week of April, 2008.  It was originally implemented with stripes and the Tomcat server, however due to some implications, we opted to go with Wicket and Jetty.  Although it does appear to be much cleaner and easier to work with, we are still currently learning about the Wicket framework as we design the interface. </p>

<p>Currently the system can take in a HackyStat user name and password and have a user edit an already existing configuration file.  It allows a user to save a configuration file, which also restarts the Ambient Server for changes to take effect.  The user interface can display current Trigger/Action Pairs and the user may add and edit Trigger/Action Pairs if desired. </p>

<p>Below are snapshots of the current user interface, which is still heavily in development.  The first snapshot is of the page for editing actions, while the second snapshot is of the login page. </p>

<p>Changing Settings: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Login Page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>More InformationPlease feel free to browse the project page.  Below is a list of important links that can help a new user or developer with the current state of the project. </p>

<p>JAVADOCS - The page containing javadocs.  For some reason, it is not displaying correctly on the Firefox browser.  Internet Explorer is confirmed to display it correctly. AmbientHackystat - The main project that this user interface is being developed for. Hackystat-ui-wicket - The project that this web application is based on. DevelopersGuide - A start up guide for developers interested in moving the project forward. RoadMap  - This contains what have been done so far with the current user interface and what we hope to ultimately as our first stable release. KnownIssues - Known issues that a user and developer should be aware of about the project. SystemEvaluation052008 - An evaluation of our system with fellow developers.  This allowed us to find design flaws of the system and help create the RoadMap.</p>

 title : The btfm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>with tarballs of a bunch of modules, I want to loop round all the tarballs, extracting them, running Makefile.PL, ignore missing dependencies (as we&#39;re going to get to them), run make install and skip all tests.  </p>

<p>this tool automates those steps. </p>

<p>btfm is based on krang(krang.sf.net) - actually a stripped-down version of krang&#39;s build tools. </p>

<p>How does it worksimple, btfm extrats the module and builds it(support Module::Build or MakeMaker).  </p>

<p>Quick startget the source and assume you have the source under /tmp/btfm cd /tmp/btfm and run perl bin/module_build. this will install module Expect, IO::Tty and Module::Build from ./src into ./lib directory. These 3 modules are required to build other modules. download a cpan module and save it into ./src directory. note the module name should be of xxx-yyy-0.0.tar.gz format which is cpan convention by default. run perl bin/module_build --module xxx-yyy from /tmp/btfm. this will install the module xxx-yyy into ./lib directory. all built modules are in ./lib/ directory and you can copy them to wherever you want. </p>

<p>There are two common perl module install problems tackled in btfm: </p>

<p>answering module installation question.  module installation order. </p>

<p>They are handled by a perl syntax configuration file ./YuSis/Config.pm.  </p>

<p>hash ref $Expect_QA is where you can specify the module install question and answer.  </p>

<p>array @FIRST_PERL_MODULES specify module installation order. </p>

<p>I have used it a lot on Debian 4.0 and some on solaris. Based on my experience, most of the modules will install fine even if the dependent module is not installed yet as long as the installation doesn&#39;t die. As long as the dependent installed in the end, the module still work fine. some modules that i have installed using this tool are DBIx::Class, Class::DBI, DBI, DBD::mysql; Email::Send. Those are the kind of module that has bunch of dependencies.  </p>

<p>Commandsto build every modules under ./src directory: </p>

<p>perl bin/module_build </p>

<p>to build a specific module(s): </p>

<p>perl bin/module_build --module xxx-yyy  </p>

<p>you can also install more than one modules: </p>

<p>perl bin/module_build --module xxx-yyy --module aaa-bbb </p>

<p>to build all modules under ./src directory except few modules: </p>

<p>perl bin/module_build --skip-module xxx-yyy</p>
 title : The build-ng Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>BuildNG is a programmatic build tool using plain old java. No more XML! It provides a concise and powerful programming infrastructure for developing software builds. Its inspired by some of the concepts of Maven 2. Its leveraging ant for the common build tasks by introducing a programmatic fluent interface on top of ant (elegAnt).</p>
 title : The bzreader Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The main purpose of BzReader is to allow the offline browsing of the Wikipedia. </p>

<p>UsageThe typical usage would be: </p>

<p>Download one or several .xml.bz2 dumps of Wikipedia topics from http://download.wikipedia.org/backup-index.html You will need the files named pages-articles.xml.bz2 for your language. Alternatively, you may use any database dumps which follow Wikipedia XML format - Wikibooks, Wikitravel etc. 
<br/>Install BzReader Open the Wikipedia dump in BzReader (you can have multiple dumps opened at the same time, all of them will be searched together) Let BzReader create the index for fast retrieval of topics. This might be quite lengthy for big dumps. It takes about 4 hours on Core 2 Duo to index the current dump of all English topics (enwiki-20080312-pages-articles.xml.bz2, 3.5 Gb file). The BzReader index for this dump takes about 550 Mb. Browse! Enter your search terms into the search window on the left, wait for the result(s) and click on the topic. Try also something like &quot;music*&quot; to find anything that starts with &quot;music&quot;. 
<br/>Screenshot </p>

<p>New in v1.0.12Fixed a minor issue when trying to search for the empty string Known issuesChinese/Japanese/Korean users - please note that indexing the dumps in your languages is currently too slow to be of real use. This is due to the complexity of the actual languages. Unfortunately, I don&#39;t really know the appropriate languages to actually fix the tokenizing code. Just as a guide - 2.7 Mb compressed jawikinews dump takes about 1.5 hours to index on Core 2 Duo.</p>

 title : The cant2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CAnt2 is a build tool targetting C/C++ source code projects, though it is also intended to be useful for more general build tasks. </p>

<p>It is currently in a very early state, with the initial set of source code being put together in a Win32 environment. </p>

<p>CAnt2 is intended to be Ant like, in that an XML file is used to define the build process. However C/C++ is not Java, and so it is expected that there will be some differences. The XML schema will grow around the needs of the project more as they are discovered, and may or may not mirror features of Ant. </p>

<p>These are the current goals, though some are long term. </p>

<p>Multiplatform. CAnt2 should be usable on Windows and Linux. The same build script should be usable on any platform. Efficient builds. Builds should be limited by the speed of the compiler/linker/related tools. Where possible, source files should be batched for the compiler. Fast incremental builds. A simple change to one file should take less than two seconds to compile and link. (Assuming that code is written to compile/link quickly) Customizable. Arbitrary programs need to be run by the users, and most needs should be satisfied without needing to touch the cant2 sources. Correctness. The build process should do the minimum amount of work, and do it right. Scalable on multi-core/multi-processor machines.  Scalable to many projects. All source code should be able to use one common build system, so one can just invoke the tool once to build everything. These goals are inspired by other build tools such as make, Jam/MR (and variants) as well as of course Ant. CAnt2 is also inspired by a blog entry made by Noel Llopis (http://www.gamesfromwithin.com/articles/0506/000092.html). </p>

<p>CAnt2 has the &quot;2&quot; as there is already a cant project hosted by code.google.com, but it is inactive and apparently dead. Initially this author thought to fork the cant source code, but the code in the repository has obvious license issues.</p>
 title : The code-base Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Conventional IDE bases tools does not scale as the volume of code in the project increases. IDE based build-solution is one such example. Another example is type navigation and searching. Brute force solutions like ‘grep’ fail to give reasonable response as the code size increases.  </p>

<p>Code-Base is tool that will help solve the above issue. This tool can parse managed assemblies, and stores the information in structured database. Once this is done, operations like type navigation and analysis becomes database operations – as such is much more scalable. </p>

<p>Code-Base is source-code persisted as a database. This tool can be run on the build machine as one of the final steps in the build process. The database could be a central DB, accessible to the whole team. Yet another approach would be to use in-memory DB like SQL Compact Edition and re-distribute the DB to all team members.  Once code is represented in a structured manner in the Database, we can think of different use-cases like analyzing code complexity, static analysis etc.</p>

 title : The condition-alert Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>See What Condition Your Condition Is InA condition is an ongoing state of affairs, such as a server being unreachable, a project build being broken or unread mail waiting in your in-box. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>This project provides a daemon that other programs can inform over DBus when a condition starts or stops.  The daemon will notify the user by adding an icon into the system&#39;s status icon tray and popping up a notification bubble via the system&#39;s notification daemon. </p>

<p>The project also provides command-line tools for raising and clearing conditions.  These can be executed from scripts that monitor resources or processes.</p>
 title : The cpcsdk Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Amstrad CPC/Plus is an old 8-bit microcomputer. It&#39;s still used nowadays by some people to create demos. However, there are almost no tools to do that under Linux. This project aims to collect the various bit of existing sourcecode in one common place, add the missing features, and make life easier for all developpers. </p>

<p>Available tools include : </p>

<p>The Caprice Reloaded emulator, with integrated assembler and debugger, gfx2crtc, a tool to convert pictures to the amstrad sceen format An imporved version of Ramlaid&#39;s cpctools, now running under linux, with (limited) support for usb floppy drives A special version of STSound from Leonard, modified to emulate an AY3 more accurately (the original emulates the slightly different YM chip used in the Atari ST) &quot;Hideur Maikeur&quot; from Downwater fo</p>

 title : The dragmovedrop Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SummaryI&#39;m proud to present you the first release of DragMoveDrop project in collaboration with Pleyo </p>

<p>This is the first included drag and drop for GWT. It is also the first simple and optimized Drag and Drop. Tested on every Operating system, on every browsers, and build with a small computer (1Ghz and 512Mo Ram). His unique system of detecting allows you to increase performance when you are moving a widget.  </p>

<p>That is not all, i&#39;m preparing many examples of use ; as 2000 Widgets in a page, and keep a very fluid move on yours Widget, create and drag you own list, and many others behaviors (block Widget into a panel, copy a Widget on Drag, etc...) </p>

<p>To install DragMoveDrop, please look at gwt : http://code.google.com/p/dragmovedrop/w/list </p>

<p>If you have any question : http://groups.google.com/group/dragmovedrop </p>

<p>Demo 1The demo is visible here : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/demo1/DragMove14.html </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Demo 2The demo is visible here : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/demo2/DragMove14.html </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Demo 3 (from sansrob)The demo is visible here : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/demo3/DemoApplication.html </p>

<p>Thanks to sansrob for this demo, to contact him : sansrob@gmail.com </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Supported Drag &amp;&amp; Drop Widgets (directly) :Label. Image. Focus Panel. (Every others Widget are indirectly droppable or draggable. Everything is explain on the Getting started guide). </p>

<p>4 new methods per Widget :</p>

<p>addDragListener(DragListener);   addDropListener(DropListener);   removeDragListener(DragListener);   removeDropListener(DropListener);  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The methods handle 11 listeners :</p>

<p>DragListener  DropListener   onDragStart(Widget sender, int x, in y)  onDropEnter(Widget sender, Widget source)   onDragMouseMoved(Widget sender, int x, in y)  onDropOver(Widget sender, Widget source)   onDragEnd(Widget sender, int x, int y)  onDropExit(Widget sender, Widget source)   onDragEnter(Widget sender, Widget target)  onDrop(Widget sender, Widget source)   onDragOver(Widget sender, Widget target)   onDragExit(Widget sender, Widget target)   onDragDropEnd(Widget sender, Widget target)  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Control your DragThe Drag Move Drop Project include the possibility to entirely control your drag : </p>

<p>Stop a move, Sets a Draggable Widget, which move on the click of an other, Sets Your detection padding, Control the fire of the listeners, Control the Drop Map, and disable some target, Update the position of the drop target when you want to. ... </p>

<p>Tests and doc around the project :</p>

<p>- Report Tests : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/test/Doc-Test.doc   - JUnit Test : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/test/JUnit.java   - Limits Test demo : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/test/Test-Charge/testDragDrop.html   - The javadoc : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/test/doc/   - The demo 1 source code : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/code/GWT-DmD-demo1-source-code.zip    - The demo 2 source code : http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/code/GWT-DmD-demo2-source-code.zip    - The demo 3 source code :  http://alexandre.gorisse.com/gwt/code/GWT-DmD-demo3-source-code-(sansrob).zip </p>

<p>If you have any demo to show me, don&#39;t hesitate, I&#39;ll put on my presentation page </p>

<p>Pleyo team = http://www.pleyo.com</p>

 title : The flex-template Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>FLEX TEMPLATE PROJECTAn Ant-based AS3 compiler project for Flex application development.If you are using other script editor other than Flex Builder in authoring Flex applications, here is something very useful for you. </p>

<p>The project is setup for ANT-based compiling and you can easily toggle a property to switch between testing and publishing your final SWF file. </p>

<p>Upon packaging the SWC file, project documentation is automatically generated for you into the &#39;docs&#39; folder using ASDoc.  There is also a FlexUnit integration using FlexUnit for Ant  created by Peter Martin. </p>

<p>REQUIREDWhat you will need to use this template: </p>

<p>JDK  ANT Flex 2 SDK </p>

<p>HOWTOMake sure you update your Flex SDK installation paths in the template&#39;s build properties file before using the template.  </p>

<p>FLEX_HOME=/home/flex2/sdk
<br/>DEFAULT.LOCAL = fr_FR
<br/>ENCODING = UTF-8</p>

<p>## Components
<br/>components.lib.name = &quot;MyComponents&quot;
<br/>components.lib.version   = 0.1
<br/>components.lib.description = &quot;MyComponents package&quot;
<br/>components.swc.name=${components.lib.name}-${components.lib.version}.swc</p>

<p>## Proprieties
<br/>src.dir=src
<br/>bin.dir=deploy
<br/>build.dir=build
<br/>dist.dir=dist
<br/>docs.dir=docs
<br/>docs.asdoc.dir=${docs.dir}/asdocs
<br/>docs.junitreport.dir=${docs.dir}/junitreport
<br/>lib.dir=lib</p>

<p>main.class = ${src.dir}/examples/App.as
<br/>swf.export = ${bin.dir}/App.swf</p>

<p>## ASSETS DIR
<br/>assets.dir=${src.dir}/assets/
<br/>Ant next run  </p>

<p>ant compileThis will compile all files in src/ and generate ower App.swf. </p>

<p>You can specify witch library can you include to compile your source, all swc are localized into lib/ directory. </p>

<p>Hopefully some of you will find this template useful. If you have any questions, suggestions, or feedback, certainly let me know.</p>

 title : The foraytool Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Fortran 90 can include reasonably complex dependencies, which must be taken into account when building a multiple-file program. Unfortunately, most build tools either don&#39;t support Fortran, or don&#39;t help the developer much. A standard make file, for example, requires you to enter dependencies manually, or develop a script to do it for you.  </p>

<p>Foray is a build tool designed specifically for Fortran projects. It can be applied to anything from a small utility program with tens of files to a million line monster. Foray natively handles Fortran dependencies, takes care of locating files in subdirectories, and includes advanced features like multi-threading for better performance on multi-core systems, and multiple build configurations (eg debug, release, serial, parallel).</p>

 title : The kernel-janitors Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Kernel Janitors FAQ </p>

<p>Q: What is Kernel Janitors? A: It is a project to help wannabe kernel hackers get their feet wet </p>

<p>while doing something useful for the community. </p>

<p>Q: What will I be doing? A: Basically, cleaning up the kernel. </p>

<p>You can look at TODO for some example tasks. </p>

<p>Q: Prerequisites? A: Knowledge of C, being able to compile and boot Linux kernel. </p>

<p>Q: What documents should i read? A: SubmittingPatches, CodingStyle from Documentation/ . </p>

<p>http://www.zip.com.au/~akpm/linux/patches/stuff/tpp.txt 
<br/>and http://linux.yyz.us/patch-format.html are good to read also. </p>

<p>Q: What version should I be patching against? A: Latest &quot;linus&quot; (2.6.x-rcY from kernel.org). </p>

<p>Be sure to check -mm and -kj trees to see if someone already did that. </p>

<p>Q: Where should I send patches to? A: Mailing list: kernel-janitors@lists.osdl.org </p>

<p>If you feel confident enough, you can CC: someone from MAINTAINERS too. </p>

<p>Q: I have lots of patches that do the same thing. Can I just send them in </p>

<p>one mail? 
<br/>A: No, but don&#39;t send them in lots of small mails either. Try splitting them up per subsystem (drivers/net/, fs/ext3/...). See here: 
<br/>http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=linux-kernel&amp;m=112105809816217&amp;w=2 
<br/>for details. </p>

<p>Q: Where can I find janitors? A: On our mailing list and #kerneljanitor at irc.oftc.net </p>

<p>Q: I got some negative replies. Am I just wasting peoples&#39; time? A: A nice motivational post from Linus: http://lkml.org/lkml/2004/12/20/255</p>

 title : The krash Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Krash (Crash) is a build tool which produces self contained Javascript applications in a jar file for use with the Rhino Javascript engine. The current version of Krash is 0.1 (29 August 2008)  </p>

<p>Photo courtesy of BigFoto.com </p>

<p>What&#39;s in the box?Krash (Crash) is a small project to help make creating compact, robust, multi-platform JavaScript applications practicable using the Mozilla Rhino JavaScript engine. </p>

<p>Since Rhino is written in Java, Crash makes use of this to help build JavaScript applications using standard Java tools. It also provides a small set of Java classes, and a simple JavaScript library specifically designed to leverage both Rhino and Java, but within the JavaScript environment. </p>

<p>Using Crash, your JavaScript application can be distributed in just two files; the standard Rhino jar file, and a specially constructed jar file containing all the code and other artefacts of your application. </p>

<p>With the help of Crash, launching your JavaScript application can be as easy as typing: </p>

<p>  java -jar crash.jar  </p>

<p>What&#39;s under the hood?Krash (Crash) uses Java, Mozilla Rhino and the Apache Ant build tool to produce most of its magic. The rest is supplied by JavaScript itself. </p>

<p>You will need Java and Mozilla Rhino for your JavaScript application development anyway, only Apache Ant is an additional tool requirement. </p>

<p>Want to know more?Why not take a look at the manual? </p>

<p>29 August 2008: The good news is that version 0.1 has been released.</p>

 title : The lrf-epub-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Usage: java -Xms200M -Xmx300M -jar LRFTools-vx.y.z.jar action (params) </p>

<p>Note: Java VM gets 200MB minimun, 300 maximun memory to work. If you plan to  convert only a few books, you can reduce significantly these values (40,60). </p>

<p>Actions: </p>

<p>1) convertLRF dir (-d dirOut |-z zipfile) (-XML|-PDF|-RTF|-HTML|-EPUB) (options) 	 Converts to XML, PDF, RTF and/or HTML every LRF file in &#39;dir&#39; recursively.  
<br/>You can specify more than one format conversion simultaneously. 
<br/>Converted files go to the same place as original, except if you specify  
<br/>&#39;-z zipfile&#39;, then go to zipfile; or &#39;-d dir&#39;, then output files are created 
<br/>in dirOut replicating the same original directory tree structure. </p>

<p>(options) one or more of:   -A4 : Means normal paper size (trying to reflow) 
<br/>  -rf nn : Fonts Size</p>
 summary : <p>Managarm is a modern operating system that is based on a virtual machine. Its objective is to provide a fast and stable operating system for daily use. Managarms device drivers are written in a managed programming language and are verified before executed. Modern virtual machine and just-in-time compilation techniques are used to achieve high performance without risking a loss of stability and security. </p>

<p>At the moment Managarm is in the very early stages of development and only few programs are supported. It is available for the Intel x86 (Pentium or better) architecture, however, it could be easily ported to other platforms. </p>

<p>Managarm is primarily written in the Korona programming language that was specifically designed for managed operating system and driver code. Some parts of the runtime library are written in assembly language; some utilities and applications are written in Java. </p>

<p>Currently Managarm&#39;s virtual machine only runs its own bytecode format, later also Java bytecode will be supported. It would be possible to implement a frontend for .NET but that is not planned to be realized in the near future.</p>

 title : The merevaik Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is an ended proof-of-concept project. If you are finding a non-maven build tool try http://gradle.org or http://easyant.abrm.info/trac . </p>

<p>Our goal is to create a build tool with the functionality of the Maven and with the simplicity of Ant.  </p>

<p>Merevaik is an extension to the Ant which attains the convention over configuration principle over the three levels of ANT:  </p>

<p>properties,  tasks,  and targets.  You shouldn&#39;t define same targets and properties in your every project with Merevaik, just define once, and upload the repository, and dependency management will use it automatically. Merevaik uses Ivy as the dependency management. </p>

<p>Benefits of Merevaik: </p>

<p>Simple learning curve: You shouldn&#39;t learn a new tehcnology.  You may use plain old ANT tools Simple installation You sholdn&#39;t modify your existing build environment, only drop two jar files to ANT_HOME/LIB Lightweight tool The core of the Merevaik not bigger then 15-20 classes Easy IDE integraton The most of the IDE supports ANT based projects so supports Merevaik based projects too. You needn&#39;t specail plugins to handle Merevaik projects. Works in offline mode You can use components of Merevaik as traditional ANT task. (If you wouldn&#39;t like to use Merevaik). Our goal is maintain the documentation on high level. </p>

<p>See also: GettingStarted</p>
 title : The minime Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MiniME is a light weight J2ME library that let you build game and advanced UI.  MiniME features: </p>

<p>a resource manager to easily import and use Image and Text. event manager to ease communication between view and different component of the library.  a set a predefined UI component, such as Label, EditField, RadioButton group, CheckBox group, to build UI. an open and evolving build system with a set of Mobile Device description. a set of pre-defined antenna properties to customize the code and ease portability  integrated documentation (powered by Doxygen). a Tutorial. <p>Check out our discussion group at http://groups.google.com/group/minime-dev</p>
 title : The mismo-bindings Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project provides bindings of MISMO XML documents to Java Beans. Later we may provide bindings in .NET and other platforms as well. </p>

<p>What is MISMO?MISMO is short for Mortgage Industry Standards Maintenance Organization. It is a group mortgage industry participants that define and promote common standards across the industry. As part of their mission, they also define XML grammars (DTDs or W3C Schemas) that define the structure of XML documents that describe industry data (e.g. loan application, credit request, credit report, flood certificate, title etc.) and the rules governing it. </p>

<p>You can download the entire collection of their specifications at http://www.mismo.org/files/mismo/MISMOSpring2007Release.zip </p>

<p>What is &quot;mismo-bindings&quot; project?There are several DTDs and W3C Schemas published by MISMO. This projects aims to ... </p>

<p>create Java classes that model those XML structures create Java/XML bindings to convert XML documents to Java Beans and Java Beans to XML documents create other utilities that developers working with MISMO (and perhaps other XML documents) will find useful at a later stage, do the same for .NET </p>

<p>In other words, mismo-bindings is a toolkit you&#39;d use to develop applications that work with MISMO XML documents. </p>

<p>FeaturesMapping of Java Beans to XML elements and attributes and back. This means you can unmarshal an XML document into a graph of Java Bean instances (not DOM tree) and also marshal the Java Bean instance graph back into XML. More natural naming of Java Bean classes and their properties. If you use automated code generation tools, it will not be as natural, because ours is done by hand (we do start out with generated code, but we then refactor it extensively by hand). More expressive relationship between nodes in the graph. By that we mean that if an attributes &quot;points to&quot; another element in the document (using IDREF or IDREFS), we provide not only properties that provide the values of the IDs, but also the actual bean instance representing the element that is being pointed to. In other words, if an &quot;ASSET&quot; element has a &quot;BorrowerID&quot; attribute with value &quot;ssn111111111&quot;, the &quot;borrowerID&quot; property will give the String value &quot;ssn111111111&quot;, but there will be another property named &quot;borrower&quot; on the same class that is a reference to the actual Borrower instance &quot;ssn111111111&quot; points to. More type-safe properties. In DOM, everything looks like a String. We create our mappings such that not just Strings, but Dates, Booleans, ints/Integers, BigDecimals and doubles/Doubles are represented when appropriate. As we said, we want to make it very easy to create applications that deal with MISMO XML documents. </p>

<p>DocumentationThe following documents are available ... </p>

<p>UserGuide DeveloperGuide (read the UserGuide first) </p>

<p>Technology StackCurrently, we use and support the following technologies. This may change over time ... </p>

<p>Software  Version  Comments   JDK  1.5  although we don&#39;t use any special features of JDK 1.5, but simply haven&#39;t tested with prior versions   JiBX  1.1.5  XML binding framework - high performance, low memory usage   Ant  1.6  for building/compiling   W3C Schema ?  XSD (W3C Schema) rather than DTD, because XSD are more evolved   JUnit  1.2.8  for Unit Testing with assertions  </p>

<p>About UsWe are a group of veteran developers with decades of industry experience (most of it in the Finance and Mortgage industry) who want to provide free, common technology to the industry so no one has to keep re-inventing the wheel. When foundational technology is given to you for free, you will be able to focus on creating better products for your customers. </p>

<p>Jitesh Doshi is a Principal Architect and Partner at Sysdelphia, Inc. Nagaraj Poojary is a Senior Consultant at Sysdelphia, Inc. Sunitha Sreedaran is a Consultant at Sysdelphia, Inc. If you have a question or comment, please email opensource@sysdelphia.com.</p>

 title : The myisern-2-violet Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionMyIsern is a web application for the International Software Engineering Network (ISERN) community to track their collaborations, community growth, and membership information. The application is written in Java on a Stripes framework with the help of Prefuse for data visualization. </p>

<p>We are a group of computer science graduate students at the University of Hawaii at Manoa in a software engineering course taught by Professor Philip Johnson. </p>

<p>If you are interested in adding to this project space, please feel free to contact one of our members: Shaoxuan, Laura, or Lisa at the email address found under Project owners to the right. Thanks for looking! </p>

<p>DocumentationPlease take a look at our ReleaseNotes for information about what this version of our MyIsern system contains.  You can use our InstallationGuide if you would like to simply install and run the system.  If you would like to continue development on this project, our DeveloperGuide will help you get started.  Our code documentation may also be helpful for external developers to this project. </p>

<p>DescriptionISERN is a community of software engineering researchers who collaborate together on various projects.  MyIsern is a system created to help keep track of the researchers, organizatons, and collaborations within ISERN.  In the system, researchers belong to organizations.  MyIsern uses the organizations to keep track of the collaborations going on between researchers.  An example would be if reseachers at the University of Hawaii and Mississippi State University were working together, they would have a collaboration called UH-MSU to represent their work. </p>

<p>MyIsern allows users to create, edit, and delete information about the researchers, organizations, and collaborations that make up ISERN.  The system also produces a report of any records that may contain errors, such as a researcher who does not belong to an organization.  Users may also view a graph which represents the network by displaying organizations as nodes and collaborations as the edges between nodes. </p>

<p>ScreenshotsHere are some screenshots of the MyIsern system.  Please note that this site performs best in IE7 or Firefox. </p>

<p>1.  Login screen </p>

<p> </p>

<p>2.  List of Organizations </p>

<p> </p>

<p>3.  List of Researchers </p>

<p> </p>

<p>4.  List of Collaborations </p>

<p> </p>

 title : The myisern-pink Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The myisern-tan Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Overview and PurposeMyIsern is a web application used to facilitate collaboration within the International Software Engineering Research Network (ISERN).  The applications does this by providing access and storage of information about researchers, the organizations they represent, and ongoing collaborations.  We hope that this tool will help foster improved and increasing collaboration activities within the network.  By keeping track of metrics, ISERN can better measure initiatives in hope of finding ways to fulfill its collaborative mission. </p>

<p>For an overview and motivation for creating this collaboration tool, see:  http://groups.google.com/group/ics-software-engineering-fall-2007/web/myisernspace </p>

<p>Quick Links</p>

<p>Link  Description  Installation Guide  Executable only install and user guide  Developer Guide  Design, tools needed, and full package installation.  JavaDoc  Source cod documentation Release Notes Release Note Version 2.0  Executable DownloadExecutable only download Full DownloadFull package download for developers </p>

<p>CapabilitiesThe capabilities of MyIsern-Tan Version 2.0 is as follows: </p>

<p>Provide list of ISERN researchers with pictures, contact, research, and organization information. Provide list of ISERN organizations with affiliated researchers, homepage links, and research areas. Provide list of ISERN collaboration activities with contributing organizations and descriptions. Allow for entry and updating of information by researchers. Allow for downloading and uploading for data in Xml format. Provides a tool to examine data integrity (missing links) and fix them. Web-based application. </p>

<p>BehaviourThe application starts of with an login page.  Once you enter a login and password, the following navigation screen is provided: </p>

<p>Home Page </p>

<p>You can now select any of the links at the top of the page to query records.   </p>

<p>Home will bring you back to this page. Researches provides a list of all ISERN researchers with their pictures.   Organizations will list all organizations whom these researchers belong to.   Collaborations will provide information about any joint projects between organizations.   Data Semantic Check provides a list of missing links between these tables, and give you a chance to fix them. </p>

<p>ResearchersSelect the researchers link at top of page.  You will get the following page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>You can now do the following actions: </p>

<p>New Researcher: takes you to a form for entering a new researcher. Clear All Researcher: clears all researchers in the database. Import Button: imports researchers from an Xml file entered in preceding texbox. Export Button: exports researchers to an Xml file entered in the preceding texbox. Edit (in Row): edits the researcher in the current row. Delete (in Row): deletes the researcher in the current row. Email (under name): opens an email message. </p>

<p>OrganizationsSelect the organization link at top of page.  You will get the following page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>You have the following options: </p>

<p>New Organization: enter new organization in a separate form. Clear All Organizations: clear out organizations from database. Import Button: import organization data from specified xml file. Export Button: export organization data to an xml file. Edit: edit the organization in current row. Delete: delete the organization in current row. Link (under name): takes you to organization&#39;s home page. </p>

<p>CollaborationsSelect the collaboration link at top of page.  You will get the following page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Commands available on this page: </p>

<p>New Collaboration: enter new collaboration. Clear All Collaborations: clear out collaborations from database. Import Button: import data from specified xml file. Export Button: export data to an xml file. Edit: edit the collaboration in current row. Delete: delete the collaboration in current row. </p>

<p>Data Integrity CheckSelect the Data Integrity Check link.  The application will go through the database and identify all records that link to missing records.  For example, if a researcher record indicates that the researcher belows to University of Hawaii, but there is not University of Hawaii in the Organizations table, this report will flag this for you.  You will have an opportunity to fix this problem. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>At this point, a list of data integrity issues are shown.  For each issue, you have the following options for addressing the issue: </p>

<p>Edit the main record: you can modify the main record to fix the dangling link. Delete the main record: you can simply delete the main record. Edit the record being pointed to: in this case, it will create a record where currently there is a missing record. Current StatusVersion 2.0 of the application is released and can be downloaded from the downloads tab in this hosting site.  To download the executable only version of the application, you can use download.  For the full download: full download. </p>

<p>To get a list of current issues with this release, please look at the ReleaseNotes. </p>

<p>Documentation AvailableInstallation Guide for the download and installation instructions of the executable only application. Developer Guide for a programmers introduction of the application including design, tools, and full package installation. JavaDoc for documentation of the source code.</p>

 title : The obibuild Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AboutObi has been superseded by the excellent sbt. </p>

<p>Obi is a build tool for Scala and Java projects. Obi uses a flexible DSL style syntax to specify a build configuration.  </p>

<p>Consider the following examples of a Java compilation task: </p>

<p>// Compile Foo and Bar in src/main/java into build/main-classes.
<br/>javac(srcdir(&quot;src/main/java&quot;)).
<br/>        destdir(&quot;build/main-classes&quot;).
<br/>        srcfiles(List(&quot;Foo.java&quot;, &quot;Bar.java&quot;))</p>

<p>// Create a compile task for all files in src/main/java.
<br/>val jc = Dir(&quot;src/main/java&quot;) &lt;&lt; javac</p>

<p>// Execute the task
<br/>!jcObi encourages builds that are simple, sufficient and efficient. Obi exposes tasks that exploit Scala&#39;s type system to reduce the amount of mistakes you make with a build. For example invalid files will not compile and tasks that do not have their preconditions fulfilled (e.g. a Javac task without a source dir) will not run. As Obi&#39;s tasks are immutable (side effect free) you can combine them in flexible ways to implement common features in other build tools. </p>

<p>DownloadThere are currently no downloads. Please consult the source. </p>

<p>SponsorsObi development is sponsored by Workingmouse.</p>
 summary : <p>Dependency Injection (DI) is a technique used in Object Oriented Programming to help decoubling and improve testability.</p>

<p>Objection is a lightweight Dependency Injection library to help the &#39;wiring&#39; of a an app using DI.</p>

<p>It is currently only available for .NET, and is used within the CruiseControl.NET application.</p>

 title : The pers-ant-ivy-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A collection of Ant tasks that makes the project development cycle easier. The tasks reduces the burden for the programmer when creating build files. </p>

<p>The collection currently consists of the following tasks. </p>

<p>Apache Ivy tasks: </p>

<p>IvySubantTask which is a subset of Ant&#39;s subant task merged with Ivy&#39;s info task. Major differences compared to Ant&#39;s subant task are: </p>

<p>Input should only be a list of ivy files. A generic ant build must be set, the build file is executed in the directory of the ivy file. The ivy file is loaded (and properties set in the build) before the target is executed. Properties which are simmilar to Ant&#39;s subant tasks: buildpath, target, genericantfile, failonerror, inheritall, inheritrefs </p>

<p>The following nested elements are also support (see Ant&#39;s Subant task for documentation): property, propertyset  </p>

<p>InstallExample usage
<br/>   </p>

<p>First the ivy:buildlist task is used to get a ordered list of ivy files. The directory which they are located in are used as basedir when invoking module-build.xml. </p>

<p>IvyManifestCreates a property containing the transitive dependency for a given module. Useful when creating a jar manifest and dependencies needs to be specified. </p>

<p>Other tasks: </p>

<p>Launch4jWrapper - Wrapper task for the Launch4j project. The single purpose is to make the definition of a launch splash screen optional and configuring a little more easier then the default task.</p>

 title : The protoj Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Roadmap Version 2.0.0 </p>

<p>Work on version 2.0.0 has already started that will: </p>

<p>greatly solidify the code-base and depart from the maven-style command line include full and extensive documentation transform the jboss demonstration project into a quickfix based trading application introduce beanshell to make every part of the project as clean as possible This will take months to complete. If you believe in pure java builds and you have a real contribution to make then please email me at ashpublic@mac.com </p>

<p>Ashley Williams June 2009 </p>

<p>Introducing ProtoJ The Pure Java Build APIProtoJ is a pure java build, installation and deployment library that hands control over to you. There&#39;s no third-party ProtoJ application directory to maintain, no environment variables to set up and absolutely no other required software. Simply add the ProtoJ library to your project and get ready to experience the joy of a friction-free development cycle. So why not give ProtoJ a try right now, it really is as easy as 1-2-3: </p>

<p> Download the ProtoJ executable jar file.  Create a new &quot;basic&quot; project by executing java -jar protoj-exe-jdk5-1.9.2.jar -sample basic.  Try a few commands from the basic/bin directory: ./basic.sh compile archive hello-basic. When you&#39;re feeling more adventurous take a look at the jboss demonstration that demonstrates how ProtoJ can be used to build, store persistent configurations and launch a jboss project with considerable ease. You may be amazed at how easy this is to accomplish: not because ProtoJ is rocket science, but because it is based on java rather than xml. </p>

<p>Features to Enhance Any ProjectProtoJ abandons build scripts. It&#39;s &quot;unique selling point&quot; is that all use-cases are accessible in-code through the api, with just one call to Java in just one starter script! If you ever wished you could get rid of your build scripts then look no further: ProtoJ is targeted at you!!! </p>

<p>ProtoJ is part of your project. You don&#39;t have to hide away use-cases related to the build inside some xml file, to be handled by some other tool merely at the start of your project life-cycle. Compilation and jar creation for example belong to your project just as much as your core business use-cases and are accessible at build-time through to run-time.    </p>

<p>   ProtoJ plays nicely with maven. ProtoJ uses a traditional lib directory and support for filling it up from a maven repository is provided right out of the box. And going in the other direction, you can easily deploy your project artifacts to a maven repository so that they can be shared with other ivy or maven projects. Or indeed with other ProtoJ projects! </p>

<p>ProtoJ plays nicely with aspectj. Aspectj compiler support can be enabled with just a single method call, as can support for load-time-weaving. Then just drop your .aj files alongside your .java files and they will be picked up by the ajc compiler without any additional aspectj installation. </p>

<p>ProtoJ is available on all major platforms. Each release of ProtoJ is subjected to rigorous testing on Linux (Ubuntu), Unix (Mac OS X) and Windows (XP) and also on Java 5 and Java 6. If you work with any other platform then you can easily check for compatibility by following the instructions in the BuildingFromSource page.</p>

 title : The rockboxplayer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project to design and build a Free/Open hardware/firmware audio player and recorder, for use with Rockbox firmware. </p>

<p>We have moved for a new page (http://lyre.sourceforge.net) to promote Lyre project (ex Rockbox Player). </p>

<p>http://lyre.sourceforge.net</p>
 summary : <p>RTEMS is a real time operating system developed for high performance embedded applications. RTEMS is implemented in C, though it was originally developed in Ada, so it supports application development in Ada and C as well as C++. It supports a variety of architecture for deployment including specialized embedded CPUs to x86. Development is normally done on a standard desktop or workstation using a cross compiler. </p>

<p>Since RTEMS is normally used in embedded applications the users normally develop their software on a different OS and machine then that which will be running the application. The tool chain that is used to build for RTEMS is based on the standard GNU compiling tools with various patches that are specific to RTEMS. Setting up the development environment from scratch is a complex task and very time consuming. Supplying pre-built tools for development aids users in adopting RTEMS for application development and keeping their development environment up to date with the current releases of RTEMS.   Currently there exist pre-built tools for RPM based Linux distributions and Windows (via MinGW). Given the rise of usage of Debian based Linux systems in recent years developing Debian packages for RTEMS would help expand the user base and service it better. The objective of this project would be to develop a set of Debian packages of the current RTEMS tool chain for a few of the most common Debian based Linux distributions, specifically Debian and Ubuntu. In addition to setting up packages for the current version of RTEMS, scripts will be built to help automate the packaging and testing future releases of RTEMS. The automation tools will be used to produce a liveCD that will have an entire RTEMS development environment on it that will allow users to test RTEMS before committing to it. With an install feature the liveCD would also allow for rapid deployment/upgrading of RTEMS development systems.</p>

 summary : <p>sbt is a simple build tool for Scala projects that aims to do the basics well.  It requires Java 1.5 or later. </p>

<p>FeaturesFairly fast, unintrusive, and easy to set up for simple projects Configuration, customization, and extension are done in Scala Accurate recompilation (in theory) is done using information extracted by a compiler plugin Continuous compilation and testing with triggered execution Supports mixed Scala/Java projects, packages jars, generates documentation with scaladoc Supports testing with ScalaCheck, specs, and ScalaTest Starts the Scala REPL with project classes and dependencies on the classpath Multiple project/subproject support Parallel task execution, including parallel test execution Dependency management support: inline declarations, external Ivy or Maven configuration files, or manual management Getting StartedTo get started, read Setup, RunningSbt, and BuildConfiguration. See DocumentationHome for other documentation. </p>

<p>The mailing list is at http://groups.google.com/group/simple-build-tool.  Please use it!</p>

 title : The SuperF4 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SuperF4 kills the foreground program when you press Ctrl+Alt+F4. This is different from when you press Alt+F4. Alt+F4 only asks the foreground program to exit, allowing it to decide for itself what to do. Read more... </p>

<p>You can also kill a process by pressing Win+F4 and then clicking the window with your mouse. You can press escape or the right mouse button to exit this mode without killing a program. </p>

<p>SuperF4 should be able to kill all kinds of processes, whether they are hung or not. Beware though, killing a program does not give it a chance to save unsaved work. If you accidentally kill explorer.exe, you can start it again by opening Task Manager (Ctrl+Shift+Esc). </p>

<p>Program made by Stefan Sundin.</p>

 title : The tabimswitch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Other Languages: 简体中文 日本語 </p>

<p>TabIMSwitch is an FireFox extension which enables FireFox to save the Input Method of each Tab and change it accordingly when switching tabs. It also enables disabling Input Method for address bar. </p>

<p>For most east-Asian user such as Chinese/Korean/Japanese, people always have to use Input Methods for typing characters. But FireFox 2.0 has poor support for intelligent Input Method switching. For example, people may open several tabs, one for writing blog in Chinese, one for writing wiki in English, and the other for chatting (via Google Talk online) with Japanese friends in Japanese. When switching between these tabs, people may expect the Input method can switch intelligently. But FireFox 2.0 does not support that. </p>

<p>To enable this feature for FireFox, this extension is developed. The feature of the extension includes: </p>

<p>Save the input method status of each tab and switch the input method according to current tab. Switch to English input method when focus on address bar. Switch the input method status when changing between different windows. </p>

<p>Version 1.0 supports Windows 2000/XP/2003 with FireFox 2.0.0.*, FireFox 3.0, and new FireFox 3.1 beta. If anyone is interested in porting it to Linux platform, please contact me. </p>

<p>Now, view the tutorial and begin to setup it! </p>

<p>Thank all users of the extension, this extension has been reviewed and nominated as public addons. Access the page on Mozilla Addons Page</p>

 title : The torrentmediatools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The general idea is to build upon already available tools and services, make them work together to ease the process of tracking, downloading, watching and managing TV series and movies. </p>

<p>The main focus revolves at the moment around the &quot;auto downloader&quot;, a tool which allows users to select TV-shows to follow, as an effect the &quot;auto downloader&quot; will make sure that all upcoming episodes will get downloaded.</p>
 title : The LASengine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>LASengine is a powerful game engine to create 2D point-and-click adventure games. It uses Lua as the scripting tool.</p>
 title : The traffometer-rsi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The emergence of GPS-enabled phones with internet access, highly variable traffic conditions, and the high cost of fixed road condition sensing equipment (such as traffic cams and in-road sensors)  has led a number of companies in recent years to the same conclusion:  why not utilize the presence of cell phones in people&#39;s cars to obtain data about traffic conditions?  As a simple example, if a cell phone transmits its location at various times during a driver&#39;s commute to work in the morning, this data provides a real-time report of traffic speed along the corridor taken by that commuter at that moment in time.  Companies that are working on technology to exploit this potential data include Inrix , Dash Navigation , and IntelliOne . The approaches vary between vendors, but there are some basic similarities:  the software is proprietary, the services are not extendable, and  the costs of the service will be significant.</p>

<p>The goal of the TraffoMeter Project is to create an open source community of developers and users around open protocols and applications for the transmission, analysis, and presentation of traffic data.  The potential advantages of the open source TraffoMeter Project over current venture-capital driven approaches include:</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;* Lower cost. Both client and server software will be freely available.  Individuals, organizations, and communities can establish TraffoMeter servers and populate them with data. In contrast, none of the commercial vendors indicate that their servers will be freely available.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;* Improved privacy.  There are significant privacy concerns associated with the commercial offerings.  These concerns can be addressed more easily in TraffoMeter. For example, the code used to capture and analyze the data is available for inspection, private servers can be established for people who desire to control access to their data completely, and privacy protections can be introduced and improved as needed and desired.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;* Improved extensibility.  There are many kinds of data that can be applied to the problem of traffic analysis, many ways that data can be made available to a server for analysis, many ways that data can be delivered back to users, and many ways in which the data can be presented once delivered.  A goal of the TraffoMeter Project is to evolve an extensible infrastructure for traffic data collection, transmission, analysis, and presentation, enabling developers and users to &#39;scratch their own itch&#39; more easily and cheaply than would be possible with proprietary solutions.</p>
 title : The virtualagc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Virtual AGC and AGSThe purpose of this project is to provide an emulation of the on-board Apollo guidance computers, along with some ancillary items needed to make the emulation do something interesting. &quot;AGC&quot; stands for Apollo Guidance Computer.  The AGC was the principal on-board computer for NASA&#39;s Apollo missions, including all of the lunar landings.  Both the Command Module (CM) and the Lunar Module (LM) had AGCs, so two AGCs were used on most of the Apollo missions, but with differing software.   The computer and its software were developed at MIT&#39;s Instrumentation Laboratory, also known as Draper Labs. </p>

<p>&quot;AGS&quot; stands for Abort Guidance System, of which the computer portion was the Abort Electronics Assembly (AEA).  The AEA was a completely separate computer system from the AGC, with a different architecture, different instruction-set, and different runtime software.  It was in the LM as a kind of backup for the AGC, but was only supposed to be used (as the name implies) in case of an aborted landing. </p>

<p>Special thanks go to Ron Burkey for starting this magnificent project and for bringing the wonders of the Apollo era with regards to computing back to life. The purpose of this project is to continue the project by adding new capabilities like GDB/MI functions to allow debugging in gdb capable IDE&#39;s.</p>

 title : The want2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>WAnt is a Pascal-friendly build automation tool. It automates the process of building, testing, and packaging applications and libraries much like Apache (ex Jakarta) Ant does. WAnt is kind of like Ant, without being Java-dependent, whereas Ant was &quot;kind of like Make, but without Make&#39;s wrinkles.&quot;  </p>

<p>WAnt is written in CodeGear Delphi (formerly Borland Delphi), primarily — but not exclusively — for users of Delphi and other Pascals. It was originally written by Juancarlo Añez in 2001. Juanca eventually ceded control of the project to Andrew J. Wozniewicz in 2005.  </p>

<p>WAnt features a GUI IDE called WIDE, in addition to the traditional command-line version of WANT.  </p>

<p>Both WIDE and WANT can run scripts written in WANTScript, a new, general-purpose, block-structured scripting language based on Modula-7 and designed to be programmer-friendly (i.e. readable, in the tradition of Pascal-like languages).  </p>

<p>WAnt is FREE software. It is released under the Mozilla Public License 1.1 and its distribution includes the complete Delphi 7/Object Pascal source code.</p>

 title : The emLib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>If you reach this page most likely you are looking for Rodi P2P binary release - check web site rodi.sf.net If you are looking for CLI/FFS/AOS portable C/C++ libraries for RTOS &quot;emLib&quot; package is the way to go</p>
 title : The winfoldersjava Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This small interface library for Java will allow your Java program to access the Win32 API call SHGetSpecialFolderPath without using Swing (see below for the Swing method). This call gives you the locations of system folders such as &#39;My documents&#39;, &#39;Application data&#39; and others. Comprises of a tiny Jar and a DLL file. Just include these in your project and you&#39;re ready. </p>

<p>How to use: </p>

<p>import com.catnapgames.winfolders.WinFoldersJava;</p>

<p>public static void main( String[] args ) {
<br/>	// The DLL needs to be loaded dynamically.
<br/>        // Adapt to your way of finding the file; here we assume it is in the current directory.
<br/>        // Load different DLLs according to whether the platform is 32 bit or 64 bit.
<br/>        String platform = System.getProperty(&quot;sun.arch.data.model&quot;).contains(&quot;64&quot;) ? &quot;_x64&quot; : &quot;&quot;;
<br/>        System.load( new File( &quot;&quot; ).getAbsolutePath() + &quot;\\WinFoldersJava&quot; + platform + &quot;-1.1.dll&quot; );
<br/>	System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_PERSONAL\t\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_PERSONAL ) );
<br/>	System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_APPDATA\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_APPDATA ) );
<br/>        System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_LOCAL_APPDATA\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_LOCAL_APPDATA ) );
<br/>	System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_MYPICTURES\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_MYPICTURES ) );
<br/>	System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_COMMON_APPDATA\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_COMMON_APPDATA ) );
<br/>	System.out.println( &quot;CSIDL_COMMON_DOCUMENTS\t&quot; + getSpecialFolderPath( CSIDL_COMMON_DOCUMENTS ) );
<br/>}You may ask &#39;why not just get the java user.home property and append Desktop or My documents to that?&#39;. Well, that may work in the English version of Windows, but in other languages, Windows names the folders differently. Also, Vista has a different folder structure compared to WinXP. Calling the aforementioned API function is necessary to get the correct folder location. </p>

<p>Also, if you need only the &quot;My documents&quot; path and don&#39;t mind touching Swing you may not need WinFoldersJava. You can use javax.swing.filechooser.FileSystemView.getFileSystemView().getDefaultDirectory() instead.</p>
 title : The xml-protocol-testing-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Metis is an application that tests conformance of client and service implementation with XML/HTTP protocols. Metis functionality is exposed to the user as a Web GUI desktop application. </p>

<p>Metis leverages several third-party components (some of them mentioned below). To ease distribution and execution, the Metis code tree includes binaries (.JAR files) of its software dependencies. For example: Metis&#39; Web GUI leverages Jetty, an open source servlet container; while Metis&#39; persistent storage leverages HSQLDB, a relational database management system written in Java. </p>

<p>This site describes how to build Metis from source code and how to run/stop Metis using Apache Ant. Ant is a Java based build tool. More information on using Ant is available at http://ant.apache.org/manual/. </p>

<p>You’ll find an Ant build file at the root directory of the tools branch of the project source code tree. Ant build files are XML files, usually named build.xml. </p>

<p>The Ant build file describes itself. First, several global properties are created to specify several build or run/stop parameters. These parameters specify the location of the source code, build (or classes), and libraries (lib) directories. Other properties specify the name of the JAR file that contains the client  communication module (i.e. the classes required by client applications to  Communicate with the data server) and some JVM execution parameters. </p>

<p>You should be able to use the included Ant build file without further  modifications. If you do modify the parameters therein, make sure to adjust the  project’s structure accordingly. </p>

<p>Contents </p>

<p> Prerequisites  Building Metis  Run/Stop Metis  Documentation  Sample Protocol: Robo Speak  This Project Site Documentation is under construction</p>
