 title : The repk Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>REPK (Restriction Endonuclease Picker) finds sets of 4 commercially available restriction endonucleases which together uniquely differentiate user-designated sequence groups from a user-supplied FASTA format sequence file. The user-defined sequences groups allow the user to determine particular groups (e.g. taxonomic) of sequences to be differentiated by the program. REPK is thus particularly useful in the case where a microbial community has been characterized by clone library analysis, as the actual sequences can be input into the program. If you have a database of known sequences from an environment, this program could be useful to pick some enzymes that uniquely discriminate the different groups in your database. </p>

<p>available at: http://rocaplab.ocean.washington.edu/tools/repk</p>

 title : The reu08huang Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The rscviht Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Remote system control via infrared head trackingSynopsisBy placing points of infrared light on either side of the users head and viewing it through an infrared camera it is possible to find the relative position of the users head. The Wii Remote is an inexpensive piece of hardware which contains, among other things, an infrared camera and an image processor which transforms sources of infrared light to point data on board the controller. The Wii Remote communicates with its home console using the Bluetooth HID protocol which means that by simply pairing a remote with the computer we can receive this infrared point data directly and process it further in MATLAB for the purpose of controlling remote hardware such as a camera mounted to a stepper motor. </p>

<p>ImplementationMany infrared goggles contain white LED&#39;s on either side of the wearers head. By simply replacing these with infrared LED&#39;s we can track the relative motion of the users head along the Tait-Bryan rotations (pitch, roll, and yaw). To receive point data from the Wii Remote a DLL has been written in C++ to act as a bridge between MATLAB and Brian Peek&#39;s WiimoteLib (http://www.brianpeek.com/blog/pages/wiimotelib.aspx). </p>

<p>Project MembersKapur, Parul Clayton, McKenzie Whited, Sam Equipment3x Wiimote IR LED equipped Glasses Scribbler Robot with Bluetooth Webcam Stepper Motor </p>

<p>.gadget-title {
<br/>  margin-bottom: 2px;
<br/>}</p>

<p>function resizeIframeHandler(height) {
<br/>  var elem = document.getElementById(this.f);
<br/>  height = Math.max(100, height);
<br/>  if (elem) {
<br/>    elem.style.height = height + &#39;px&#39;;
<br/>  }
<br/>}
<br/>gadgets.rpc.register(&quot;resize_iframe&quot;, resizeIframeHandler);</p>

<p>gadgets.rpc.register(&#39;set_title&#39;, function(title) {
<br/> var elem = document.getElementById(this.f + &#39;_title&#39;);
<br/> if (elem) {
<br/>   elem.innerHTML = gadgets.util.escape(title);
<br/> }
<br/>});</p>
 title : The saveme Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The original goals of improving the support of Agilent microarray platform in Bioconductor, streamlining the microarray data analysis pipeline from statistical testing to experimental validation, and demonstrating the utility of pathway-focused annotation in the MAQC-II study may be implemented at a later date. Due to a change in priorities, I am now creating an embedded Entrez Gene database. We believe this change in focus will demonstrate a different methodology when practicing scientific discovery. </p>

<p>Entrez Gene database has a wonderful wealth of genetic information that is accessible via the internet. With the interactive search mechanisms in place at NCBI, you can learn such things as a gene’s proposed function, where it is located, and its relationship to other genes. As researchers, mining the information for specific goals can be a cumbersome task. Moreover, there is a need to integrate genomics information with the statistical applications written in R/Bioconductor. Being able to download a copy of the information from Entrez Gene on your specific computer allows easy accessibility and enables data mining. SQLite is a free database program written in C that is available over the web. With this tool, you can access the Entrez’ data we selected to be most useful. We have proven that this database, once constructed, can be easily embedded into other applications written in R, Java and Perl as well. R is a free software environment that allows statistical operations and Bioconductor packages to be run; Bioconductor is an open source project for the analysis of genomic data; being able to access the database via R can help researchers get at information they need without switching programs.  BioJava is a open source, bioinformatic organization, which focuses on using Java for the analysis of biological data. Java is highly availed by many bioinformatic researchers; by using an SQLite Java Wrapper/JDBC Driver, this data can be extracted, without switching to a C environment, though a C environment is required in the setup.  BioPerl is an organization that creates reusable, Perl programs for bioinformatics. Perl, likewise, is a great language for parsing specific information out of a database. Permitting the Entrez Gene database to be accessed in any of these languages allows for wider usability in data mining of this data. Our goal is to make examination of genomic data faster for the end user, available at no cost, and the database highly portable.</p>
 title : The scanmem Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Scanmem &amp; GameConquerorscanmem is a simple interactive debugging utility for linux, used to locate the address of a variable in an executing process. This can be used for the analysis or modification of a hostile process on a compromised machine, reverse engineering, or as a &quot;pokefinder&quot; to cheat at video games. </p>

<p>A PPA is available here:  https://launchpad.net/~coolwanglu/+archive/scanmem  </p>

<p>FeaturesInteractive command mode, with online help. Efficient and easy-to-use syntax. Support different types of variable: int{8|16|32|64}, float{32|64} -- known type and width int, float -- known type, unknown width number -- neither unknown, just guess bytearray, string -- powerful for advance usage Support different types of scan: equalto greaterthan, lessthan changed, unchanged increased(by), decrased(by) Set variable to any value. Detailed information about mappings, allow users to eliminate regions. More in GameConqueror: </p>

 title : The semanalytics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project develops a set of well-defined operations founded on information theory foundations. These operations are aimed at enhancing the typical faceted exploration of data with summarization and comparative analysis functionality. In addition to the core implementation of the analysis operators, this project also develops a set of utilities to extract and load annotated data into relational databases (including concept hierarchies and associated objects). It also implements efficient queries to extract sub-hierarchies from the database corresponding to a give set of annotated objects which in turn will be fed into the analysis operators.</p>

 title : The spsc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A supercompiler is a program transformer that traces the possible generalized histories of computation by the source program, and builds an equivalent target program, whose structure is, in a sense, &quot;simpler&quot; than the structure of the source program. The simplification is achieved by removing certain &quot;redundant&quot; actions from the source program. </p>

<p>The goal of the project is to implement in Scala a positive supercompiler that is very close to the one described in papers by M.H.Sørensen, R.Glück, and N.D.Jones. </p>

<p>The current version of spsc can be run as a command-line application or accessed as a web-application. </p>

<p>spsc deals with programs written in a simple lazy first-order functional language (SLL). The intended operational semantics of the language is normal-order graph reduction to weak head normal form. </p>

<p>SPSC LiteSPSC Lite is a minimalistic version of SPSC, which may be useful for educational purposes and as a starting point for experimenting with supercompilation. </p>

<p>Currently, there are 4 versions of SPSC Lite written in: Scala, Haskell, Python 2.6 and Ruby 1.8. </p>

<p>News2009, September A version of SPSC Lite written in Ruby 1.8. </p>

<p>2009, August A version of SPSC Lite written in Python 2.6. </p>

<p>2009, August A version of SPSC Lite written in Haskell. </p>

<p>2009, June The paper SPSC: Суперкомпилятор на языке Scala. </p>

<p>2009, May The paper SPSC: a Simple Supercompiler in Scala is accepted for PU’09.</p>

 title : The testability-explorer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Quick LinksGetting Started | How Testability is determined | How to Contribute | Scores for Open-Source projects </p>

<p>Sample ReportsSource-annotated Report </p>

<p>Testability-explorer is a tool which analyzes Java bytecode and computes how difficult it will be to write unit tests for the code. It attempts to help you quantitatively determine how hard your code is to test, and where to focus to make it more testable. </p>

<p>Testability Explorer can be used: </p>

<p>As a learning tool which flags causes of hard to test code with detailed breakdown of reasons. To identify hard to test hair-balls in legacy code. As part of your code analysis-toolset. As a tool which can be added into continuous integration that can enforce testable code. </p>

<p>Currently the tool computes: </p>

<p>Non-Mockable Total Recursive Cyclomatic Complexity. Cyclomatic Complexity is a measure of how many different paths of execution are there in the code. It is computed, by counting the if, while, and case as branching primitives. It is recursive because cost of the method as well as any methods it calls are counted. It is total because cost of object construction as well as any static initializations are counted. And finally, it is non-mockable because any code which can be mocked out in test is not counted as part of the cost. This means that the score is based on the amount of complex code that cannot be mocked out in a unit test. Global Mutable State. Counts the number of fields which are globally reachable by the class under test and which are mutable. Mutable global state makes testing difficult as tests are not isolatable, the global state needs to be set up and cleared between tests. Law of Demeter. This is the principle that calling methods on objects you get from other collaborators is trouble, instead, the collaborator should call that method itself. It makes testing harder because your mocks must expose some internal state through these methods. </p>

<p>Check out the Readme, or post a message to the mailing list. </p>

<p>For a demo of testability-explorer in action see http://testabilityexplorer.org/report</p>
 title : The testpositive Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Description:This tool can be used to view any vulnerability outside AppScan. The most common use case is that of a security expert wanting to demonstrate the vulnerability to a developer that doesn&#39;t have AppScan installed. The auditor can simply click on the Send to Test Positive menu item added by the Test Positive Extension, save the report in a convenient location and then zip the Test Positive executable together with the report and e-mail the package to the author of the vulnerable web application. </p>

<p>For more information, see our Wiki page. </p>

<p>The Test Positive utility and eXtension were created by Paul Ionescu, Watchfire Technical Support </p>

 title : The tserieschaos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>tseriesChaos is an R package for the analysis of nonlinear time series mainly motivated by chaos theory. </p>

<p>You can install from a CRAN mirror near you by typing, at the R prompt: </p>

<p>&gt; install.packages(&#39;tseriesChaos&#39;, dep=TRUE) </p>

<p>Its developement was initially inspired by the TISEAN project. </p>

<p>Currently, the 0.1-7 version is out, and mainly includes explorative methods. Among others: </p>

<p>Kantz method for Maximal Lyapunov Exponent (MLE) estimation efficient correlation integral computation for estimating fractal dimension false nearest neighbours space-time separation plots recurrence plots grid-based average mutual information computation ForthcomingA new, completely revised and extended version of the package supported by the PRIN project coordinated by Estela Bee Dagum, Statistics Department, University of Bologna.  </p>

<p>The new version will include: </p>

<p>Statistical tests for chaos based on Lyapunov exponents estimation with different methods available:  Kantz method, resampled version (Giannerini and Rosa, Physica D (2001));  Neural Network, asymptotic version (Shintani and Linton, J. Econometrics (2005)); Local Lyapunov exponents estimation Extension to the stochastic case of Lyapunov Exponents: measures of sensitivity to initial conditions of the conditional mean (Yao and Tong JRSS B (1994)) and of the conditional distribution (Fan, Yao and Tong, Biometrika (1996)), see also Giannerini and Rosa SNDE (2004). Entropy based tests for nonlinearity (Granger, Maasoumi &amp; Racine JTSA 2004, Giannerini, Maasoumi &amp; Bee Dagum forthcoming).</p>

<p>Please spend your time familiarize with the system, and make sure your SVN is setup correctly. We want to have all assignment documents checked-in, even though you’re still working on it, so that we have a better idea on each other&#39;s work progress. </p>

<p>http://del.icio.us/utoronto_csc454_summer08 user: utoronto_csc454_summer08 pass: baecker11 </p>

<p>Quoted from course website </p>

<p>For A4, Your submission should reflect: </p>

<p>a clear description of the idea chosen for the business plan (12.5%) a clear description of the problem the idea is intended to solve (12.5%) an analysis of how the idea fits in the market (5%) an analysis of the market, including size estimates and segmentation (15%) the results of 2 - 3 interviews with potential customers, and an analysis of your intended customer (15%) an analysis of your likely competition (20%). An additional 10% will be allocated to the overall quality of your ideas and your efforts, and 10% to writing, organization, and presentation. </p>

<p>For A3, Your five-page summary must include: </p>

<p>A brief description of the product, including what it does (a high-level description, not details of functionality or interface), how the customer will use it, and how your business will make money (15%) An outline of the potential value or benefit your product would provide a customer, e.g., how it solves a problem or relieves a major source of pain or generates compelling new opportunities for the customer (15%) A first attempt to quantify the market size (how many customers are there) with supporting data and sources (you will go further with this task in Assignment 4) (12%) Identification of at least two competitors with a statement of how your product is different, better, and more valuable to the customer (you will go further with this task in Assignment 4) (12%) Identification of at least one barrier to entry to the market which explains why you are uniquely positioned to address this market, e.g., you have access to unique research or technology being developed, you have specialized and deep domain knowledge which few other people have, etc. (8%) A first try (or several options) at a company name and mantra characterizing your idea. (8%) The idea will involve, and the name may change, as you do more work in the next few weeks, but describe your concept as best you can right now. </p>

<p>We will also allocate 10% for our overall impression of the quality of your idea, your thoughts, and your work.  We will take off 5% for each page over 7 pages (you may need more than 5 pages) that you submit, although you will not be penalized for any data presented in appendices. </p>

<p>Finally, you get up to 10% for the team summary and up to 10% for the pictures.</p>

 title : The winbase Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>WinBase is intended to be used to establish a baseline or obtain a current snapshot of a Windows system.  In an operational environment it is often difficult to to have accurate configuration management data on a system that can be used for comparison after an intrusion.  Additionally, after an intrusion the current baseline of a system must be obtained in order to assist in the act of determining what has changed.  WinBase is a tool that will assist in obtaining this information. </p>

<p>WinBase is a VBScript that utilizes Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) queries to interface and obtain data directly from from select Windows OS WMI classes.  The output from these queries is completely customizable and can be used to automatically produce custom reports.  Due to the granularity of the Methods under a particular class only relevant data is queried thus eliminating irrelevant data to sort through.  WinBase can be executed either locally or remotely under any authentication credentials required to obtain the information sought.  Because WMI and its classes are part of Microsoft Windows &quot;trusted platform computer system&quot; the level of reliability is high and the risk of comprise and/or the yielding of fraudulent data is greatly mitigated. </p>

<p>WinBase is a project I started several years ago.  Due to my insane schedule I have only worked on the script off and on as I had a chance.  If anyone has scripting experience or just wants to learn and help out, please email me.</p>

 title : The agrajag Open Source Project on Open Hub

<p>Pygame as its foundation Phil&#39;s pyGame Utilities (abbr. PGU) - a mostly GUI library lightweight Python XML DOM implementation (xml.dom.minidom) </p>

<p>Sometime/somehow it may use Psyco (but currently doesn&#39;t, as it&#39;s not available for x86-64, and that&#39;s what I /lavrin/ use). </p>

<p>DescriptionThe design (ughhh... if we can dignify it by using the word) of the game strives to allow for easy extension. Adding new enemies, bonuses, weapons, shields, etc. is a matter of creating the graphics and an XML description. At least it should be that easy... </p>

<p>Most artwork for the game comes from free internet sources. Some is created by the authors. </p>

<p>Agrajag features a level editor developed in PyQt4. Unfortunately, it&#39;s currently only a little more than a piece of crap. </p>

 title : The aimdojo Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionA collection of AIM-related JavaScript modules that are designed to work with the Dojo JavaScript Toolkit. The modules include a wrapper for the Web AIM API and UI widgets that show a user&#39;s presence, buddy list and allow sending and receiving instant messages (IMs). </p>

<p>By using these modules, you can get a fully functioning AIM-based text IM client running in a web page.  </p>

<p>The modules are designed for Dojo 1.1 and above. </p>

<p>The modules are open source versions (new BSD license) of the modules used by AOL Webmail. Two other open source components are bundled and used with these modules: </p>

<p>SoundBridge.swf from the BSD-licensed JavaScript Sound Kit. The aim.date module includes some functions from the MIT-licensed Matt Kruse&#39;s Javascript Toolbox. </p>

<p>In addition to wrapping the Web AIM API, these modules use AOL&#39;s OpenAuth to handle user authentication. This means the modules do not handle a user&#39;s name and password. </p>

<p>Latest News and ExamplesThe first release, 1.0.0 is available in the Downloads area. For information on how to use the code, download  the 1.0.0 source, and open the index.html file. </p>

<p>The code is also usable from the AOL CDN, so you do not have to install all the code on your server. Examples that use the AOL CDN are here (same examples in the source downloads, but configured to use the AOL CDN): </p>

<p>Simple.html: Just shows the simplest usage of the modules, using aim.ImPanel with the default options.  ResizableFloatWithHoverCard.html: Shows how to use aim.ImPanel inside other dijit widgets that allow the buddy list to be dragged and resized. Also shows configuration options for the HoverCard (the info card that shows up as you hover over buddy names).</p>

 title : The ansitape Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Ansitape reads, writes, and creates magtapes conforming to the ANSI and IBM standard for magtape labelling. Primarily, this is useful to exchange tapes with VMS and IBM systems, which make this kind of tape by default. </p>

<p>Ansitape was originally written by David S. Hayes, Site Manager, US Army Artificial Intelligence Center and was submitted to comp.sources.unix in August 1986.  </p>

<p>Kern Sibbald from the Bacula project corrected a Y2K bug, and edited it to compile on Linux in 2004, and the SNA gang did some cleanup and packaging. this version is derived from the results of that.</p>

 title : The btbt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is an attempt to fill in the gap left out by BlogTorrent.</p>

<p>The idea is to have a simplified torrent tracker based on BlogTorrent without the &quot;EasyDownload&quot; and which exists now between nerds running trackers and normal users doing the download. And with many of the publicaly available trackers availablity not being guranteed and folks who co-host not_so_legal stuff, which being taken down all the time, there is a urgent need to have a software infrastructure which will allow any reasonably knowledgeable user to setup and serve his files via bittorrent from his shared server.</p>

<p>The Project attempts to achieve the following:</p>

<p>* Run a efficient non-binary tracker -  to be able to run on a shared server
<br/>* Ability to share from server, popularly called a server-side seeding – to prevent sharing from dying off due to lack of a full or complete seed.
<br/>* Simple to setup
<br/>* Be OS/Platform neutral – PHP and python for glue code</p>

<p>The software will be shipped with scaled down version of the official bittorrent client so as to benefit from upstream modifications.
<br/>It will also be shipped with a stripped down version of python to support the bittorrent client and to make sure we work most OS/platforms.</p>

<p>The Software has the ability to use a database or can run off a flat-file database.</p>

<p>Users will have the ability to do most tasks that need to be done with bittorrent
<br/>* creating torrents for files on the server - maketorrent.php
<br/>* seeding torrents - seeder.php
<br/>* stopping and starting torrents - start.php and stop.php
<br/>* modify torrent - updating tracker information - updatetorrent.php</p>

<p>All the above php files are mostly front-ends to equal programs available in the official bititorrent client.</p>

<p>Once the torrent is created and tracked. It can be downloaded via any available bittorrent client.</p>
 title : The casiousbmididriver Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThis project provides a simple Mac OS X driver for a USB MIDI interface found on Casio keyboards. </p>

<p>This is entirely based on the SampleUSBMIDIDriver provided by Apple with the CoreAudio SDK. </p>

<p>You can download it here: </p>

<p>Casio USB Midi Driver (Universal) </p>

<p>Please also visit the Compatibility Reports wiki page and add your keyboard if it&#39;s not already there. </p>

<p>Update: Snow LeopardA new version of the driver is available for Snow Leopard (10.6) users. This driver will not work with previous Mac OS X version. The installation procedure is the same. </p>

<p>InstallationTo install the driver, simply copy the CasioUSBMIDIDriver.plugin file into the Library/Audio/MIDI Drivers folder in your home folder or your system&#39;s harddrive. </p>

<p>You should then be able to plug your keyboard with a USB cable and power it up, it will show up in the Audio &amp; MIDI Setup utility as &quot;Casio USB MIDI Interface&quot;. </p>

<p>The driver should be compatible with Mac OS X 10.4 (Tiger) and up, on PowerPC (G4 and up) and Intel processors. </p>

<p>IMPORTANT NOTICE THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED &quot;AS IS&quot;, WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE. </p>

<p>Updates2008/01/06: Now targets G4 - the previous one actually only worked on G5 and Intel processors.  </p>

<p>  2008/01/05: The default download link above now points to the real Universal version of the plugin. </p>

<p>2008/01/01: The original driver worked only on Mac OS X 10.5 (Leopard.) The download page has been updated with a new Universal driver that should work with 10.4 (Tiger) and up.</p>
 title : The cnc-milling-machine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The CNC PCB Milling Machine project is the complete specifications for the software and hardware for a complete light duty Computer and Numerical Control (CNC) milling machine designed primarily to mill isolation traces in copper clad printed circuit board material.  Additionally, it can handle milling of soft materials such as plastics and aluminum. </p>

<p>This entire project is now open source.  This includes the design of the physical machine itself (most of which I owe to many other excellent sources), the design of the electronic motor driver circuit, the PIC assembly source code for the firmware embedded in the driver circuit, and the Java source code for the GUI based application that runs the machine. </p>

<p>I am very much a junk box designer.  The primary selection criteria from most of the hardware that makes up this project was what I already had on-hand or could obtain cheaply form local resources and EBay.  The design of the physical machine was limited by what I could do with a limited set of power woodworking tools (Table Saw, small Drill Press, Router and Router Table, and Power Miter saw).  There is practically nothing in the physical design of the machine itself that did not come from one of the many excellent references sources I found via a never-ending series of Google searches. </p>

<p>The software is my own design, influenced heavily by the ideas of many others that had done similar projects in the past.  It is not the best example of my Java development work, but I am proud of it just the same. </p>

<p>Currently, the software works only with my machine microcode.  It does not generate any G-Code output or convert between formats, but it certainly could go that direction.  There is a simulated machine mode that can work without a connection to the microcode.  It will do the displays and generate the isolation traces, etc.  Modifications to output G-Code (or any other protocol) would not be terribly hard to do, and could be fit into the project nicely.</p>

 title : The corebio Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CoreBio is a python toolkit for writing computational biology applications. For
<br/>further information on the CoreBio API, please consult the source code or the
<br/>API docmentation at &#39;docs/apidocs/index.html&#39;.</p>

<p>o data:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Standard information used in computational biology.
<br/>o db:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Database access: astral, scop ...
<br/>o moremath:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Various bits of useful math not in the standard python library.
<br/>o secstruc:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Protein secondary structure and associated tools and data.
<br/>o seq:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Alphabetic sequences and associated tools and data.
<br/>o seq_io:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sequence file reading and writing: array, clustal, fasta, genbank,
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;intelligenetics, msf, nbrf, nexus, phylip, plain, stockholm, tabular.
<br/>o ssearch_io:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Parse the output of BLAST and similar sequence search reports.
<br/>o transform:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Transformations of Seqs (alphabetic sequences).
<br/>o utils:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Extra utilities and core classes not in standard python.</p>

<p>------------
<br/>Installation
<br/>------------
<br/>CoreBio requires python version 2.3, 2.4 or 2.5. The following command will
<br/>quickly determine if python is available.
<br/>(Download python : http://www.python.org/download/)
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; python -V
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Python 2.4.2</p>

<p>If you have setuptools installed (http://peak.telecommunity.com/DevCenter/),
<br/>then installation can be accomplished with a single command:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; sudo easy_install corebio</p>

<p>Or to upgrade:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; sudo easy_install -U corebio</p>

<p>Alternativly, download the latest distribution from the project home
<br/>page, http://code.google.com/p/corebio/
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; curl http://corebio.googlecode.com/svn/dist/CoreBio-X.X.X.tar.gz &gt;CoreBio.tar.gz
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; tar -zxf CoreBio.tar.gz
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; cd CoreBio-X.X.X</p>

<p>To install corebio from the main CoreBio directory:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; python setup.py --help install         # Show installation options
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; python setup.py install                # Install code.
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&gt; python setup.py install --home ~/local # Install into alternative location</p>

<p>---------------------------------------
<br/>Development and Subversion Installation
<br/>---------------------------------------
<br/>To modify or extent CoreBio, or to use the latest code, obtain the source
<br/>directly from the subversion repository. (Subversion clients can be obtained at
<br/>&amp;nbsp;http://subversion.tigris.org)</p>

<p>&gt;  svn checkout http://corebio.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ corebio</p>

<p>See the DEVELOPERS.txt file for more information.</p>

<p>-----------------------------
<br/>Distribution and Modification
<br/>-----------------------------</p>

<p>This package is distributed under the new BSD Open Source License.
<br/>Please see the LICENSE.txt file for details on copyright and licensing.</p>

 summary : <p>IntroductionDoxygen2GWiki is a tool which takes Doxygen generated documentation and converts it into a Google Code&#39;s Wiki markup. It can also control subversion, adding and removing files from the repository as necessary. </p>

<p>Running Doxygen2GWikiTo run Doxygen2GWiki simply type... </p>

<p>doxygen2gwikiThis will look for Doxygen generated XML documentation in doc/xml and place the resulting code into wiki/. </p>

<p>The location of the various files can be controlled through the use of options... </p>

<p>doxygen2gwiki -d examples/doxygen/doc/xml -o examples/doxygen/wiki -p ExampleThis command will look for the XML documentation in examples/doxygen/doc/xml and will place the output into examples/doxygen/wiki. All filenames will be prefixed with Example_ rather than the default Doxygen_. </p>

<p>ExamplesAs an example, the complete Doxygen user manual can be found here. The equivalent HTML output is here.</p>

 title : The easyhook-continuing-detours Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project Description </p>

<p>EasyHook starts where Microsoft Detours ends. This project supports extending (hooking) unmanaged code (APIs) with pure managed ones, from within a fully managed environment like C# using Windows 2000 SP4 and later, including Windows XP x64, Windows Vista x64 and Windows Server 2008 x64. Also 32- and 64-bit kernel mode hooking is supported as well as an unmanaged user-mode API which allows you to hook targets without requiring a NET Framework on the customers PC. An experimental stealth injection hides hooking from most of the current AV software. </p>

<p>The following is an incomplete list of features: </p>

<p>A so called &quot;Thread Deadlock Barrier&quot; will get rid of many core problems when hooking unknown APIs; this technology is unique to EasyHook You can write managed hook handlers for unmanaged APIs You can use all the convenience managed code provides, like NET Remoting, WPF and WCF for example A documented, pure unmanaged hooking API Support for 32- and 64-bit kernel mode hooking (also check out my PatchGuard 3 bypass driver which can be found in the release list) No resource or memory leaks are left in the target Source code was rewritten entirely and this will greatly improve performance, stability and maintainability Experimental stealth injection mechanism that won&#39;t raise attention of any current AV Software EasyHook32.dll and EasyHook64.dll are now pure unmanaged modules and can be used without any NET framework installed! All hooks are installed and automatically removed in a stable manner Support for Windows Vista SP1 x64 and Windows Server 2008 SP1 x64 by utilizing totally undocumented APIs, to still allow hooking into any terminal session. Managed/Unmanaged module stack trace added Get calling managed/unmanaged module inside a hook handler Create custom stack traces inside a hook handler You will be able to write injection libraries and host processes compiled for AnyCPU, which will allow you to inject your code into 32- and 64-Bit processes from 64- and 32-Bit processes by using the very same assembly in all cases. EasyHook supports RIP-relative addressing relocation for 64-Bit targets. License has changed to Lesser GPL (LGPL) No unpacking/installation necessary anymore. No CRT bindings for release configurations, reducing deployment size about some megabytes. The Visual Studio Redistributable is not required anymore. First feature complete release of EasyHook... The library is currently still in BETA state, but should be stable enough for development. Don&#39;t hesitate to report any bugs you find, because that&#39;s the only way for me to fix them. You can be sure that any serious bug you report, will be fixed soon... </p>

<p>Donations to support Intel Itanium </p>

<p>I want to add support for Itanium, so that EasyHook will span through all architectures, platforms and modes (managed/unmanaged/kernel). If anyone has used/new hardware, supporting Itanium, which he/she can donate, please contact me. Also money for buying such hardware would be appreciated! As I am currently a student, I can&#39;t effort this myself. Of course we could talk about some sponsorship agreements... </p>

<p>WHAT ARE THE IMPACTS OF THE LICENSE CHANGE? </p>

<p>To wrap it up (without warranty): </p>

<p>You are granted to sell any software that uses EasyHook over DLL, NET bindings or EasyHookQueryInterface(). This is covered by the native API and the managed interface. You are NOT granted to sell any software that includes parts of the EasyHook source code or any modification! If you want to modify EasyHook, you are forced to release your work under the LGPL or GPL... Of course this only applies to the library itself. For example you could release a modification of EasyHook under LGPL, while still being able to release software, which takes advantage of this modification over DLL or NET bindings, under a proprietary license! You shall include a visible hint in your software that EasyHook is used as module and also point out, that this module in particular is released under the terms of the LGPL and NOT under the terms of your software (assuming that your software has another license than LGPL or GPL). I decided to release EasyHook under LGPL to prevent commercial abuse of this free work. I didn&#39;t release it under GPL, because I also want to address commercial vendors which are more common under Windows. </p>

<p>Best regards Christoph Husse</p>
 title : The ezlame Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>EZLame is a simple graphical front end for the LAME command line encoder. </p>

<p>I created this project because I was dissatisfied with several existing LAME front ends. It has options for encoding mp3&#39;s using the standard VBR presets and common CBR bit rates. There is no current support for ABR encoding. </p>

 title : The feedpope Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>feedpope is a server-side RSS aggregator that populates an Amazon SDB database with parsed feed entries, allowing use of a variety of front-ends.</p>
 summary : <p>This is a translation of the javascript side of Ely Greenfield&#39;s FABridge to C++. The idea is that you can write flex code in C++ instead of simply making externalinterface calls to communicate with the flex side. It uses a slightly modified version of Ely&#39;s FABridge.as on the actionscript side. </p>

<p>For more details, see: http://anirudhs.chaosnet.org/blog/2008.03.13.html  </p>

<p>Sample:  </p>

<p>oRootObj.Call(&quot;getpanel1&quot;).Call(&quot;settitle&quot;, &quot;Panel1&quot;);
<br/>pBridge-&gt;ClassRef(&quot;mx.controls.Alert&quot;).Call(&quot;show&quot;, &quot;SampleAlert&quot;);Currently, this is a windows only solution where the flash player ActiveX control is embedded onto a Visual C++ application. You can use externalinterface to talk to the flash player, but you&#39;d have to handle passing of the XML back and forth yourself. </p>

<p>The bridge can have N worker threads processing requests from flash and vice versa. This frees the main MFC thread from getting blocked while some heavy CPU intensive operation is happening. </p>

<p>Multiple flash player instances are supported by the bridge. </p>

<p>Actionscript exceptions are serialized and passed across the bridge and thrown as C++ exceptions. </p>

<p>It uses TinyXML to parse XML. </p>

<p>Hopefully with the help from the opensource community, the Flex C++ bridge will be available on the Linux and Mac in the future. For more info regarding this, see FutureDirections.</p>

 title : The freeway-ccfr Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Freeway (CCFR) is under active development as a lightweight replacement for the clunky-feeling front ends for car computers that have been released.</p>

<p>Freeway runs as a front-end for Winamp. This means that all the actual audio and video file handling is done by Winamp, a rock-solid and well-trusted media player, although Winamp is never actually seen on-screen. Using Winamp as a sturdy backbone, Freeway supports many more audio and video file formats, including protected WMA files, and can take advantage of Winamp input and output plugins, as well as visualizations (AVS and Milkdrop).</p>

<p>Other features include GPS compatibility, movie listings, weather, driving directions, web browser, NES/SNES emulation support, Bluetooth support, and more.</p>
 title : The gempaq Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The googlebugs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This site is intended to track bugs *and* feature-request for Google services and products. There is absolutely no guarantee that Google will fix these bugs or even look at them. Go to http://www.google.com/support/ before you submit a bug here. And most importantly: star issues which you want fixed, this will give a digg-like measurement of which issues are important.</p>

<p>Quick rules
<br/>1. Go to http://www.google.com/support/ for real support. There you can find discussion groups and contact forms to submit bug reports directly to Google.
<br/>2. This is *not* a support group, go to the corresponding Google Group to discuss any problem you might have.
<br/>3. This is *not* an official bug tracker from Google, they might never read these bug reports.
<br/>4. Do *not* add bugs for the software which runs this issue tracker (Google Project Hosting), add those to http://code.google.com/p/support/issues/list
<br/>5. Search for your bug first, star the bug if you found it and add more information if necessary.
<br/>6. If you get an error message from google type it in completely in the bug report.</p>

<p>This project is not affiliated with or endorsed by Google.</p>

 title : The ild-fa07 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Indexing Large Databases project classThe class website: http://www.cise.ufl.edu/class/cis4930fa07ilg/Overview and Course DescriptionThis course will cover the topic of indexing for different type of large, (typically) disk-based data sets. Indexing generally refers to the design, implementation, and use of data structures that allow you to quickly find database objects that satisfy a particular selection criteria. For example, in a database containing a large number of surveillance photographs, you may want to find all photographs that are similar to the picture of a known criminal, without having to check each and every photograph in the database explicitly. In the class, we will study data structures that are appropriate for this problem, as well as for many other database search problems.  
<br/>Assignment 1:Basic Record/Schema/File Management </p>

<p>Due September 21, 2007 </p>

<p>The goal of this assignment is to implement the basic database record management code that will serve as a basis for the other assignments in the class.  All told, you will be asked to implement six different C++ classes in this assignment, as well as a menu-based, main program that makes use of them. When you are done, you will have a program that is able to store database records with an arbitrary schema on disk in binary format, retrieve them as needed, and apply basic selection predicates to files of binary records (an example of the sort of selection query that your code will be able to answer is &quot;Find all records corresponding to women over the age of 35&quot;.) 
<br/>The key reason that I am asking you to implement these six C++ classes is that they will fully encapsulate the steps that are need to store structured data records on disk in binary format, where the records possibly have many different data attributes, and each attribute has its own name and type. By carefully designing and implementing this set of classes, it will be possible to encapsulate and then then subsequently &quot;forget&quot; about all of the problems and difficulties associated with storing structured data records in binary format, then loading them into memory once again at a later time and correctly interpret the bits and bytes. Since all database indexing tasks revolve around being able to get data off of disk and make sense of it, and this is exactly what the six classes will allow you to do, it is probably not surprising that we will use these classes as the basis for all of the subsequent programming that you will do in this class. 
<br/>Assignment 2:Assignment 3:</p>

 title : The jangle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>WhatJangle (Just another generic library environment) is an experiment with middleware for library applications. If you build, use, manage or just want simple access to a library system, Jangle could be for you. </p>

<p>WhyThe aim of the Jangle project is to provide a free, easy to use framework for building web services for LMSs/ILSs by exposing resources through the Atom Publishing Protocol. </p>

<p>The goal of Jangle is to develop conventions intercommunication between the backend library services, such as ILSes and other applications and the AtomPub server (known as the Jangle &quot;core&quot;). </p>

<p>By leveraging AtomPub, it eliminates the need to develop an entirely new API and allows developers to use existing client library and knowledge to easily integrate library data into new places. </p>

<p>WhoSeveral Jangle developers work for Talis, a major provider of library systems. More information about Talis&#39; involvement. </p>

<p>However, Jangle is open source software, released under the GPL v2: see Licensing for more information. It is free for anyone to use, modify and redistribute under the terms of that licence. </p>

<p>The project hopes to engage with: </p>

<p>Developers of open source ILS software who want to develop consistent, standardised APIs for their software Developers who would like to add REST services to an ILS they have been provided by a vendor Companies interested in adding REST services to their products DocumentationUsing JangleInstalling the provided reference implementations Jangle APIThe format for requests to Jangle and responses back. </p>

<p>GeneralPrinciplesForSchemas BorrowerSchema ReservationSchema Prototypes/experimentsBorrowerSchemaDiscussion ( discussing the database schema for borrower info.) NCIPXMLSchemaForBorrowers (experiments with translating the NCIP requests to REST requests, and mapping borrower model onto NCIP responses) DevelopersHow to write a Jangle Connector for your ILS Example of how to import your own data into the Base connector</p>

Though, with any combination of user skill-level, version control systems, configurations, and front-ends, and open source and commercial diff/merge applications, achieving simple and effective merges is something of a crap-shoot.</p>

 title : The jcrasher Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>UsageThe most convenient way to use JCrasher is by running an Ant script like jcrasher.xml: </p>

<p>ant -f jcrasher.xml </p>

<p>It performs all steps completely automatically. </p>

<p>ExampleThe Ant script performs the following steps. You can follow along with the example files included in the examples directory. Download the examples directory, open a command line in your copy of the examples directory, and run our Ant script: </p>

<p>ant -f jcrasher.xml </p>

<p>jcrasher.xml compiles the Java source files under test. It looks for a file like testees.txt and interprets every line as the location of a Java source file under test, relative to the src property in jcrasher.xml. Our testees are trivia/DivByZero.java, trivia/ManyParameters.java, and trivia/NullDeref.java located in the src directory. jcrasher.xml runs JCrasher on the compiled Java classes under test. JCrasher will generate JUnit test case (as Java source files) for the classes under test. Now we should have the JUnit test cases DivByZeroTest1, DivByZeroTest2, DivByZeroTest3, ManyParametersTest1, etc. Additionally, JCrasher has generated a test suite that aggregates all generated test cases in JUnitAll. (All these files are included in the result zip file generated in step 5.) jcrasher.xml compiles the generated Java source files (the JUnit test cases). jcrasher.xml runs JCrasher&#39;s extended version of JUnit on the generated test cases. This will enhance the JUnit text output by suppressing redundant warnings. jcrasher.xml packages the results into a zip file like examples-jcrasher-2.1.3-2007-03-17-2206.zip. This zip file includes the original testee sources, the generated JUnit test case sources, the log output of JCrasher and JUnit, and the configuration files used: jcrasher.xml and testees.txt. Optionally, you can clean up all generated files (except the zip file) with the following. </p>

<p>ant -f jcrasher.xml clean </p>

<p>RequirementsJCrasher should run on any machine that has a Java Virtual Machine installed. </p>

<p>The most convenient way to use JCrasher is by running an Ant script like jcrasher.xml. You can download Ant for free. </p>

<p>JCrasher generates JUnit test cases. You can download JUnit for free. </p>

<p>InternalsJCrasher links against (uses) the following: </p>

<p>Ant-ContribVersion: 1.0 b1 License: Apache License 2.0 FB-CrasherLicense: Apache License 2.0 GNU GetOptVersion: 1.0.10 License: LGPL Jakarta Commons LangVersion: 2.3 License: Apache License 2.0 JUnitVersion: 3.8.1 License: Common Public License Version 1.0 Not included in the JCrasher distributions. We assume you have JUnit installed. NoticeThis product includes software developed by The Apache Software Foundation (http://www.apache.org/).</p>

 title : The jugc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>JUGC is a tool for generating a conversion library from a set of measuring unit descriptions and translations. It makes it possible to define units, their relationships and translations in XML files, to generate code from those definitions and deploy the generated code as a library in a Java or a Python project. The generated code can then be used to convert values from one unit to another without the need to read and parse the original definition files. </p>

<p>The code generator is written in Java, and it can generate either Java or Python code. The generated Python code doesn&#39;t depend on Java in any way.</p>

 title : The latex2utf Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>LATEX 2 UTF is a Python script for converting LaTeX formulas to Unicode text. You can try online version now. </p>

<p>For example, this line </p>

<p>\int \alpha x dx = \frac {1} {2} \alpha x ^2 + Ccan be converted to </p>

<p>∫αxdx = ½αx² + CFull list of supported commands can be found in wiki. </p>

<p>Converted formulas can used in forums, chats etc. (where only text messages is supported). </p>

<p>The GTK+ and web CGI front-ends are available.</p>
 title : The ldap-and-kerberos-out-of-the-box Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>LDAP and Kerberos out-of-the-Box for Ubuntu Linux </p>

<p>Code written by Patrick Clancy 	  		       README Written by Patrick Clancy 		       Project proposed by Patrick Clancy  		       Contact Info: patrick.j.clancy@gmail.com	       </p>

<p>Mentored by Rodrigo Pereira Braga (pereira@gmail.com)  </p>

<p>Google Summer of Code 2007			       </p>

<p>Table of Contents </p>

<p>I.	Overview II.	Tool Information and Dependencies III. 	Running the Code IV.	Editing the Code V.	Future Work </p>

<p>I. Overview </p>

<p>This project is the result of two other projects that were canceled during the summer of 2007.  Initially, we had planned to write a  program to install the Fedora Directory Server, but after weeks of  work with little success, we realized that FDS may not be a viable option for Ubuntu. </p>

<p>After the FDS problems, we needed to change the direction of the project.  The minimum goal was automating the installation of a simple LDAP server.  So the first steps were figuring out how to install LDAP on Ubuntu.  After that we needed to find out what  pieces of information were needed for the LDAP installation. Around  this point we found out that work had resumed on the another Ubuntu  project that did all of this work already. The program was called  authtool, and it supported a number of different authentication  protocols.  Among them was an LDAP and Kerberos server.  After  seeing the code for the backend, it was clear that it would take us more than a month to improve upon the installation, but the frontend was not nearly as well established. </p>

<p>So, the final project was working on the authtool frontend for  LDAP and Kerberos, because the only information given was the title of each text entry box.  I added a regular expression syntax checks and information buttons that explained the purpose of each piece of information.  These features should make deploying a LDAP+Kerberos server significantly easier. </p>

<p>II.	Tool Information and Dependencies </p>

<p>I wrote the programs using the Emacs editor, designed the GUI with  the Python Glade-2 GUI builder, and used Python code to tie  everything together.  If you want to edit the code, install the  following Ubuntu Packages: </p>

<p>python 
<br/>glade-2 
<br/>emacs </p>

<p>III. 	Running the Code </p>

<p>Once you have the necessary dependencies installed, you can enter  the appropriate directory and run the code with the following  command:      </p>

<p>python LDAP_and_Kerberos.py </p>

<p>From here use the program as instructed, check the syntax of your entries by clicking the button labeled &quot;More Info&quot; next to the text entry box. </p>

<p>IV. 	Editing the Code </p>

<p>To edit the code use your favorite text editor to LDAP_and_Kerberos.py, and use glade-2 to edit LDAP_and_Kerberos.glade.  Be sure to build the GUI using glade-2&#39;s built-in &quot;Build&quot; function. </p>

<p>V. Future Work </p>

<p>There are a number of reasons why I would like to continue this  work after the Google Summer of Code.  First of all, my project  changed three times, so I didn&#39;t get as much time to work on it as I would of liked.  Second, I see that I can help improve code for Ubuntu in my free time.  Third, Ubuntu doesn&#39;t have a great tool for easily installing authentication, and authtool would help Ubuntu take the next step into the server market if it worked well. </p>

<p>So, I would like to continue writing authtool front ends.  The next  step would be writing another tool for a NIS server.  It would build nicely on the work I have already done.</p>
 title : The llvm-qemu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is part of the Google Summer of Code 2007. </p>

<p>The goal of this project is to modify the QEMU dynamic binary translator to use components of the LLVM compiler infrastructure to turn it into a highly optimizing dynamic binary translator in order to increase the performance of QEMU even further. </p>

<p>Instead of directly emitting code for the host architecture QEMU is running on, the target code is first translated to LLVM IR, then a selection of LLVM&#39;s optimization functions are applied to the IR and the LLVM JIT is used to generate code from the optimized IR for the host architecture. </p>

<p>Since the translation to LLVM IR, the optimization and the code generation comes at a cost of an increased execution time, it&#39;s not feasible to apply this process to any piece of code, else the execution time would be even lower. Especially since on average a program spends 90% of its time within 10% of the code it is critical to get these 10% to execute fast, for the other 90% of the code parts might only execute once or only a few times and the extra time spent to generate the optimized code would not pay off. Therefore the idea is to identify the &quot;hotspots&quot; of the program. The most simple way is to count how many times a piece of code has been executed and performing an optimizing translation once a certain threshold is hit or falling back to the current binary translation of QEMU if not. </p>

<p>Another approach could be to instrument the target code at LLVM IR level to get an execution profile (LLVM already contains support for profiling) and use it to identify hotspots and to be able to perform profile-guided optimizations during runtime. Possibly a combination of both approaches will lead to the biggest overall performance gain. Detailed speed measurements will be performed in order to evaluate the efficiency of the different approaches, especially in comparison to the approach currently used by QEMU.</p>

 title : The ocaml-burg Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OCamlburg is a code generator generator that emits Objective Caml source code. Conceptually, OCamlburg is close to tools like OCamlYacc and OCamlLex: it reads a specification and emits code derived from this specification. Just as these tools, OCamlburg is most useful for compiler writers. While Lex and Yacc are typically used to generate compiler front ends, OCamlburg (and Burg-style code generators in general) are used to implement compiler back ends, that is, code emitters. </p>

<p>For documentation, see the OCamlBurg page in the Wiki. A manual page and examples are part of the source code.  </p>

<p>OCamlburg is originally part of the QuickC-- compiler project, where you can still find it. However, since it is a little burried there, I am making it available here on its own. The QuickC-- compiler is released into the public domain. Since this license is not available here, I have chosen the also very liberal BSD License.</p>

 title : The phpwidgetstoolkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Introductionthe PHPWidgetToolkit (PWT) was started to enable web developers to easily develop rich PHP web applications with javascript front ends. The introduction of the scriptaculous toolkit (http://script.aculo.us) into the public started a revolution in the web development world. However, the toolkit is still quite low level. The PWT project&#39;s aim is to create an extremely high level interface to this toolkit and extend it in order to help web developers everywhere. </p>

<p>Project AimsThe PWT project aims to: Create a high level programming interface to scriptaculous via PHP Enable PHP developers unfamiliar with javascript to write AJAX applications Create an Open Source toolkit that anyone is free to use to create rich web applications</p>

 title : The portfolioaccounting Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is the beginnings of a portfolio accounting package aimed at small-to-medium brokerages and hedge funds.  </p>

<p>PA is designed to be driven by activity in real time wherever feasible. This means that it is suitable for use as a transaction-processing-based real-time system as well as a traditional batch-oriented system.   </p>

<p>Current features: </p>

<p>Calculates necessary sale price for a given desired profit Automatically-updated position statistics  Automatically adds unknown products during import Each position currently maintains the following information: clean/dirty price total profit per position across buys/sells Rudimentary REPO support.  Easy setup - just type &#39;make&#39;. All core code is implemented inside of the database to ensure efficiency and data integrity.  We plan to support a full range of products, including Mortgages, Swaps, Repos. </p>

<p>For more information, please see AboutPortfolioAccounting in the wiki.  </p>

<p>Portfolio Accounting is provided free of charge by Spadea Enterprises, Inc (http://www.spadea.net). It comes with no warranty whatsoever. We do our best to release quality code, but sometimes bad things happen. Please test all code thoroughly before using in an environment where monetary loss is a possibility.  </p>

<p>Spadea Enterprises, Inc. offers for-fee consulting services. If you&#39;d like to sponsor a feature in Portfolio Accounting or would like to do custom programming on another project, please contact me at David.Spadea@gmail.com.</p>

 title : The scrobblify Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Happy times!Version 0.3.9 of Spotify makes Scrobblify obsolete by adding scrobbling support! </p>

<p>I&#39;m removing the executable Scrobblify but leaving the project as it is. </p>

<p>Scrobble the songs you listen to with Spotify. </p>

<p>ScrobblifyScrobblify sends the tracks you play with Spotify to Audioscrobbler (Last.fm). It is still an experimental program. </p>

<p>At the moment, only Windows is supported (but it also works under Wine). </p>

<p>Use the Issues tab when reporting errors. You want to check out the Frequently Asked Questions page first. </p>

<p>ImportantYou need the Last.fm client, and untick the option which makes it send status messages to MSN Messenger (Spotify does that anyway) under Tools &gt; Options &gt; Messenger. </p>

<p>Make sure that you are logged in to Last.fm in the client. </p>

<p>Latest versionMultiple Spotify accounts supported Falls back on a five minute track length if no meta-data is found New icon Allows only one running instance Other solutionsTwo scrobbling-solutions for OS X can be found here: Scrobble for Spotify discussions on Last.fm: Spotify scrobbler for Mac OS X (quick link to the second: spotify-scrobbler project page). </p>

<p>A more general approach to Spotify plug-ins (for the Windows client), with an implementation of a scrobbler, can be found on the spotify-plugins project page. </p>

<p>Building the source codeTo build, you need to link against Audioscrobbler. </p>

<p>Scrobblify is in no way affiliated with Spotify or Last.fm</p>

 title : The tweego Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>General informationTweego is an AS3 tweening engine based on the Go ActionScript Animation Platform. It’s one of the first parsers for Go. The syntax is similar to the glorious Fuse. It’s perfect for complex tweens with multiple sequences. </p>

<p>At the moment special properties and a documentation is missing. </p>

<p>Current version0.5 </p>

<p>Syntax examplesThere are various ways to use Tweego, e.g. </p>

<p>var t:Tweego = new Tweego;
<br/>t.push({target: target, x: 100, y: 200, time: 1, ease: Bounce.easeOut});
<br/>t.push({delay: 2});
<br/>t.push({target: target, width: 500, time: .5, ease: Elastic.easeOut, func: onComplete});
<br/>t.start();var t:Tweego = new Tweego;
<br/>t.target = target;
<br/>t.push([{x: 100, time: 1, ease: Bounce.easeOut}, {y: 100, time: 3, ease: Quad.easeOut}])
<br/>t.push({func: someCallback});
<br/>t.push({target: target2, scale: 3, time: .3});
<br/>t.start();Single sequences also can be created via: </p>

<p>Tweego.tween(target, {x: 500, y: 500});Some examples are included in the package. </p>

<p>FAQIs Tweego Fuse 3? </p>

<p>In a way yes. It&#39;s actually based on the Fuse syntax and you can use it in the same way. But some features are still missing. </p>

<p>Can I use the current version yet? </p>

<p>Of course you can. The API is ready and the core features have been implemented. Newer version will only have extensions and internal optimizations. </p>

<p>What classes I need to know? </p>

<p>You just need to use the main Tweego class (org.tweego.Tweego). If you want to work with events, you have to know the event classes, too. All other classes are used internally. </p>

<p>Has Tweego exactly all featurs of Fuse? </p>

<p>Well, at least it will have most of them. Beside the still missing things, on one hand some things are optimized and on the other hand we don&#39;t want to overload Tweego. But all important (and also some not so common) features are or will be implemented. If you are missing something, let us know. </p>

<p>What role plays Go? </p>

<p>To dumb it down: The Go ASAP by Moses Gunesch is the core engine, which handles the sequences. Tweego parses and prepares the data and finally applies it to your target object.  </p>

<p>How is the performance? </p>

<p>For Benchmark tests on the core platform please see: http://www.goasap.org/benchmarks.html Even if Tweego is not hardcore optimized, it&#39;s quite powerful. Of course the performance can not be exactly that good, because Tweego has a lot of functionality. But for example the performance is much better than the widespread Tweener&#39;s performance.</p>

It will also be a nice base for other developers to build front ends for. </p>

 title : The wordsend Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The WordSend project consists of a set of software tools that convert Scripture file formats to and from USFM or USFX for the purpose of typesetting, publication, and archiving translations of the Holy Bible in many languages. This is a cross-platform, open source project based on Microsoft .NET and the Mono Project with GTK (depending on the platform). The primary development language is C#. The primary platforms targeted are: Microsoft Windows XP or Vista, Linux (with emphasis on Debian and Ubuntu), and Mac OS X. WordSend works with a word processor to do the &#39;heavy lifting&#39; of Scripture typesetting. The initial target is Microsoft Office Word 2003 or 2007, but we have plans to support Openoffice.org Writer (and anything else that supports Open Document Text). </p>

<p>If you want to be informed of updates to WordSend, you may join the mailing list at http://groups.google.com/group/wordsend or http://lists.ebible.org/mailman/listinfo/wordsend for the (currently very infrequent) updates. </p>

 title : The wpbt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is an attempt to fill in the gap which exists now between nerds running trackers and normal users doing the download. And with many of the publicaly available trackers being taken down for all sorts of reasons, there is a urgent need to have a software infrastructure which will allow any reasonable user to setup and serve his files via bittorrent from his shared server.</p>

<p>The Project attempts to achieve the following:</p>

<p>* Run a efficient non-binary tracker -  to be able to run on a shared server
<br/>* Ability to share from server, popularly called a server-side seeding – to prevent sharing from dying off due to lack of a full or complete seed.
<br/>* Simple to setup and ideally should be part of an existing publishing frame work, to reduce or remove any learning curve involved – hence the choice of intergration with WordPress
<br/>* Be OS/Platform neutral – PHP and python for glue code</p>

<p>The software will be shipped with scaled down version of the official bittorrent client so as to benefit from upstream modifications.
<br/>It will also be shipped with a stripped down version of python to support the bittorrent client and to make sure we work most OS/platforms.</p>

<p>The Software has the ability to share the database that is being used by wordpress or can run off a flat-file database.</p>

<p>Users will have the ability to do most tasks that need to be done with bittorrent
<br/>* creating torrents for files on the server - maketorrent.php
<br/>* seeding torrents - seeder.php
<br/>* stopping and starting torrents - start.php and stop.php
<br/>* modify torrent - updating tracker information - updatetorrent.php</p>

<p>All the above php files are mostly front-ends to equal programs available in the official bititorrent client.</p>

<p>Once the torrent is created and tracked. It can be downloaded via any available bittorrent client.</p>

<p>The whole interface will be integrated into wordpress as a plug-in so that the complexity is hidden from the users. The admin can setup the plugin with minimal knowledge of bittorrent and the users can use with no or very little knowledge of the infrastructure that allows them to do it.</p>
 title : The wyome-xaraya Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A bundle of Xaraya add-ons, themes, modules, and development tools for Xaraya written by Wyome Development.</p>
 title : The xnu-dev Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is a fork of the XNU kernel utilized by Darwin and Mac OS X whose goal is to provide additional support for hardware and functionality to users which use XNU kernel driven operating systems. </p>

<p>Latest NewsAvailable here: Latest News </p>

<p>We added a Wiki page for news snippets so you can keep up on the latest developments easily by subscribing to the Wiki RSS feed. </p>

<p>User documentationThe Voodoo team has put great effort into preparing proper documentation for the end users. Please make sure to go through it as it answers several common questions. </p>

<p>Unfortunately currently the documentation is only available in English. We would appreciate if the community helps in translating it to other languages. We are looking for the following translations (in order of importance): Chinese, Korean, German and Russian, at the moment. </p>

<p>Developer documentationTwo white-papers detailing the technology that went into the kernel are being prepared and will be available soon. One of them describes the changes made in the kernel from a higher abstraction level, to enable developers to get to grips with the source tree. The second one is a highly technical paper describing the design and implementation of the vastly improved SSE3 emulator. Further documents may be available in the future. </p>

<p>Bug reportsNote: We have exceeded the attachments quota for Issues on Google Code. We&#39;re going to ask Google to extend it, and/or find alternative methods for you to get your system info or KP screenshots to us. Until then, please use SendSpace or Mediafire for the .tar.gz files, Pastie for pasting crash logs and ImageShack for putting KP screenshots. </p>

<p>Please go through the list of open bugs and if your problem is in the list, STAR it instead of posting a new report. Starring a bug report means voting for it and will push us to try fixing that first, and also helps avoid duplicate reports. </p>

<p>We are not accepting any more bug reports for sleep/resume problems. Incomplete reports will NOT be entertained. Please be prepared to describe what steps you have taken to fix the problem yourself. Only report an issue if you believe its a bug in the kernel. We have found that almost all bug reports for the release candidate have been because of external reasons (like kexts, not updating to 10.5.5 and so on). Once ready, go to the Issues tab. </p>

<p> Other Kernel Features (slightly outdated info) </p>

<p>Supports sleep/resume as well as SpeedStep on most systems (use in conjunction with the SpeedStep kext) Massively improved SSE3 Emulation layer, up to 3 times faster and fully multithread-capable (thanks Turbo) Real-time clock fix for SSE2 users (no system slowdown/stutter when SpeedStep is on, supports less than 1 GHz cpu speeds) On-the-fly cpuid opcode patching for AMD support (boot retail on AMD!) Support for 64bit on AMD Black-listing of problematic kernel extensions More secure: Execute-Disable (XD/NX) is turned on by default for supported systems HPET enabled on supported systems, cleaner boot-up code Legacy VMware support by using busratio= bootflag. Source-code is open under APSL. (Not New BSD!) </p>

<p>Theme track info </p>

<p>Is it legal to distribute them? They are taken from publicly available samples on the record company websites themselves (hence the sometimes low bitrates), slightly edited/enhanced. Some tracks are also composed by mercurysquad who holds the copyright.</p>

 title : The annoweb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This framework allows for a web site to be built without any xml configuration files.  </p>

<p>All of the configuration is done via the annotations in the web page itself. </p>

<p>The framework provides Inversion of Control functionality to allow a web page to be built by just having to write standard POJO&#39;s. All parameters to the action methods will be determined by the framework at startup.  </p>

<p>The framework interrogates the web site on startup, and generates a series of helper classes that represent the IOC control for the site. This removes the dependancy on using reflection at run time. </p>

<p>Please note that this framework is in alpha stage at the moment.  In general it works quite well, however there are no unit tests and little documentation at the moment.  </p>

<p>This will improve as time goes by. </p>

<p>At the moment there is only 1 person working on this project, but if anyone else is interested in helping out, please let me know. </p>

<p>Also, if you use the framwork and have any feature enhancements/requests. please let me know. </p>

<p>please download the framework, or get the sourcecode from subversion. </p>

<p>You can find the documentation in the wiki</p>

 title : The apismartvisite Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>API Smartvisite </p>
