 title : The semanticinvocationservice Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The usage of semantic web services in enterprise computing promises many advantages. Instead of hard-wiring web services in business processes during design-time, business experts just specify the expected functionality and matching semantic web services are bound automatically during runtime. However, the introduction of semantic web services requires the replacement or extension of existing middleware and standards. We suggest a more realistic approach based on existing standards like BPEL. Therefore we introduce the Semantic Invocation Service (SISi), which handles semantic web service calls.</p>

 title : The sgarlatur Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The projectThe aim of this project, now codenamed &quot;sgarlatur&quot;, is to provide a Mozilla Firefox langpack for North-Western Lombard. (Lombard language and its variants are mainly spoken in Lombardy and in a region in the South of Switzerland. You can find more technical and authoritative details on the Ethnologue website.) </p>

 title : The shapeshed-ee-addons Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The shurikencomponents Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What? </p>

<p>Shuriken is an ActionScript 2 component framework created to enable developers to create applications for mobile devices that support Flash Lite 2 (phones/mobiles, Chumby, Windows Mobile, etc.). </p>

<p>Why? </p>

<p>There is currently no component framework for Flash Lite 2.  The existing Flash MX 2004, Flash 8, and Flex 1.5 components do not work in Flash Lite 2.  While it is basically Flash Player 7, the devices it runs on cannot handle the CPU &amp; memory requirements. </p>

<p>How? </p>

<p>Shuriken&#39;s goals are, in order of importance: </p>

<p>work on the lowest common denominator; if it can run Flash Lite 2, the component framework should work. provide commonly required GUI components &amp; utility classes while being easy for developers to extend. no styling or skinning code; developer / designer is responsible for decorating and/or changing base skin symbols.</p>

 summary : <p>Réalisation d&#39;un framework pour la reconnaissance de la parole., </p>

 summary : <p>Project DescriptionA directory/portal script designed to allow a web site to offer a full-featured directory of resources/links similar to the Yahoo! search engine. It is completely customizable, easy to use and navigate, and is fully controlled by an integrated control panel. It includes a choice of DBM, MySQL, MSSQL, or Oracle backend. </p>

<p>Project StatusOnce sold by organisations under the names Obsidian-Scripts and PlasmaPulse Solutions, SuperLinks is now provided for free under the GNU General Public License (GPL). It should be considered abandonware and comes with no support whatsoever. However, if someone would like to take over development please contact the author.</p>

 title : The testjs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>TestJS is a Javascript Unit Tester. Assertions, Tests (groups of assertions) and Test Suites are written in pure Javascript, not in HTML and Javascript as in some other frameworks. </p>

<p>TestJS is alpha software. It contains a useful set of assertions that can be composed into tests and test suites. Tests can be run in the browser and on the command line (basic HTML and text formatting of results). 	 The TestJS roadmap includes support for asynchronous tests, todo tests, skipped tests, integration with Cruise Control (generation of xUnit style XML) and integration with Perl testing tools (generation of TAP).</p>

 title : The tetrominoes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Finally! Tetrominoes comes to Adobe® AIR™! Play everyone&#39;s all time favorite game on virtually any computer, right from your desktop! </p>

<p>For those unfamiliar with the game - a random sequence of tetrominoes (shapes composed of four square blocks each) fall down the playing area. The object of the game is to manipulate these tetrominoes with the aim of creating a horizontal line of blocks without gaps. When such a line is created, it disappears, and any block above the deleted line will fall. The game ends when the stack of tetrominoes reaches the top of the playing area and no additional tetrominoes are able to enter. </p>

<p>Enjoy!</p>

 title : The tuntun Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Tuntun is an applet for Gnome panel written in Vala and it can manage a list of vpn connections through the OpenVPN Management Interface. It&#39;s a rewrite and a replacement of my ovpnClient and it implements some items that were on ovpnClient todo list. </p>

<p>Main featuresSimple &amp; lightweight just a client GUI to start/stop your OpenVPN tunnels and nothing more Integrated with the Gnome Desktop (support for the Keyring and notification daemon) Support for Auth and Private-Key OpenVPN authentication methods Note </p>

<p>Although Tuntun was written in Vala you will need the valac compiler only if you want to contribute to the project or compile it from svn. Since valac compiler just translate vala code to straight C code + GObject, every Tuntun release will build and install with only gcc. Just do: </p>

<p>./configure --prefix=/usr --libexec=/usr/lib/gnome-applets 
<br/>./make 
<br/>./make install 
<br/>Beside that I advise you to try Vala because it&#39;s just a more fun and productive way to write programs that integrate well in the Gtk+ and Gnome technologies. </p>

<p>NEWSMon Jan 11 2009: </p>

<p>Tuntun version 0.4.0 &quot;back to life&quot; released! </p>

<p>Main changes from 0.3.1 are: 
<br/>Dropped GNIO and used GLib for networking (requires GLib &gt;= 2.22) Support for .config XDG directory specification Fully compatible with valac 0.7.9 Tue Aug 26  2008: </p>

<p>Back from vacation :( </p>

<p>New AMD64 Debian package uploaded for tuntun version 0.3.1 
<br/>(thanks to Ivars Strazdiņš) 
<br/>Mon Jul 28  2008: </p>

<p>Tuntun version 0.3.1 released! </p>

<p>This is a bugfix release, main changes from 0.3.0 are: 
<br/>Fixed internationalization support Added Latvian translation (thanks to Ivars Strazdiņš) Sat Jul 19 2008: </p>

<p>New Ubuntu 8.04 package uploaded for tuntun version 0.3.0 </p>

<p>Main changes from 0.2.0 are: 
<br/>S.n.u.l. adapted to use GIO/GNIO library New summary tooltip with the current connection status Automatically reconnect to the openvpn daemon management interface on connection lost Fully compatible with valac 0.3.4 Sat Jun 7 2008: </p>

<br/>Animated panel icon on activity Assigned ip shown in the notification  More consistent status icons in the menu / notification / connections dialog A connection may be selected for a quick (shift + click) connect action Fully compatible with valac 0.3.3 Fri Mar 14 2008: </p>

 title : The tvdblib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>tvdblib is a library written in c# .net which allows pulling information through the api provided at http://thetvdb.com .  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>To demonstrate the features and usage of the library, the program TvBrowser allows you to browse through the shows available on thetvdb and watch all available content. </p>

<p>   </p>

<p>The features covered by the library at the moment are: </p>

<p>series information episode information caching of downloaded data save to xml files save to serialized files updating of cached data banners (including thumbnails) series season episode fanart poster actors add/remove user favorites user ratings actors information zipped downloading </p>

<p>If you find any bugs, do not hesitate to post them within the &quot;Issues&quot; section. </p>

<p>.::News::.Version 0.7 (2009-06-18)Because of a few open bugs I decided on releasing a new version, even though no major new features have been added. The most noticable changes are: </p>

<p>fixed all known bugs Sorting of episodes (aired, dvd, absolute) Running Updates can be aborted A few new properties (e.g. ContainsSeriesName at TvdbFanartBanner) </p>

<p>Version 0.6 (2009-02-14)The version 0.6 offers a heavily redone update and caching mechanism and a differentiation between TvdbDownloader and TvdbHandler. </p>

<p>Amongst others, these are the main changes/additions to the library: </p>

<p>Redone caching mechanism: Improved performance and much lower memory consumption TvdbDownloader: Only download informations from http://thetvdb.com TvdbHandler: Download and handle (cache, update, etc.) the downloaded data Improved update mechanism All banners (except actors) support thumbnails </p>

<p>You can download the new version from here </p>

<p>Version 0.5This version adds the new api features to get all rated series for a user, get all rated items from a series and the episode lookup using the air-date. </p>

<p>A few minor bugfixes where made and the TvBrowser app now has the ability to store the user identifier.  </p>

<p>Version 0.4Version 0.4 implements all features offered by the API. It also fixes a lot of bugs of the previous versions. Language handling is much improved now as well as downloading updates for cached content.</p>

 title : The v8cgi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is v8cgiSmall set of C++ and JS libraries, allowing coder to use JS as a server-side HTTP processing language. Basic functionality includes IO, GD, MySQL, Sockets, Templating,  FastCGI and Apache module. </p>

<p>If you wish to support this project,  at PayPal! </p>

<p>News8.2.2010Release 0.8.0 is ready! Some big changes and features made it into this release: Binary/B is available and test/assert modules are now also CommonJS compatible. v8cgi now builds on Mac, features the &quot;global.v8cgi&quot; free variable, supports multiple MySQL queries. A new DOM module was introduced. </p>

<p>Windows binary is compiled without Context reusing, as this feature is still somewhat problematic. Also, the XDOM (Xerces-based DOM) module is not included in Windows release. Use the JS DOM module instead. </p>

<p>For a full list of changes, see the Changelog. </p>

<p>16.11.2009Release 0.7.5 is ready! Many things have changed and more features are available. v8cgi achieves higher level of compatibility with CommonJS Modules/1.1 and Windows users can now use DOM and PostgreSQL modules. For a full list of changes, see the Changelog. </p>

<p>20.10.2009Release 0.7.0 (anniversary edition) is ready! This release brings many new modules (postgresql, process, dom, gl, sprintf more), better (configurable) error handling, stability fixes and more improvements. Version 0.7.0 also features code from much more contributors than before. </p>

<p>25.6.2009Release 0.6.0 is ready! Numerous improvements, features and fixes were implemented in this version. New support for SQLite and Context reusing. New unit tests, reworked global.system object, refactored DB libraries and much more. </p>

<p>15.6.2009Revision 454 renames several scons options. Type scons -h to see a list of them. </p>

<p>3.6.2009Release 0.5.2 is ready! Complete V8 sources are now included in the src tarball. New features include Securable Modules compliance, testing framework, assert+getopt modules and lots of stability and compatibility-related fixes. </p>

<p>14.4.2009Starting from revision 391, v8cgi now ships with an assertion module, basic set of unit tests and a tiny testing framework runner. </p>

<p>8.4.2009Revision 381 is compliant with Securable Modules specification and passes all current tests at http://code.google.com/p/interoperablejs/ :) </p>

<p>30.3.2009Release 0.5.0 is ready! This version fixes several fatal bugs and adds support for command line arguments. The MySQL module now automatically closes opened connections on exit. UPDATE: 0.5.1 contains a critical bugfix regarding MySQL with Apache module :) </p>

<p>26.2.2009Release 0.4.0 is ready! Module system has been rewritten to support both include() and require() methods; path handling is better and MySQL module is able to close its database connection. </p>

<p>6.2.2009Release 0.3.0 is ready! Apache module included, for both Windows and Linux platforms. Also, the build process on MacOS X is now a bit easier :) </p>

<p>22.1.2009Release 0.2.0 is ready! This one contains many improvements and libraries: sockets, http client, fastcgi and GD. Windows build does not contain FastCGI support. </p>

<p>6.1.2009Release 0.1.0 is ready!</p>

 summary : <p>You can see an example of an experiment here. </p>

<p>I&#39;m now providing free hosting for Ibex (0.3) experiments over at the Ibex Farm. </p>

<p>This software allows self-paced reading and speeded acceptability judgment tasks to be run online through a web browser. The server is written in Python and stores results in a CSV file, suitable for later analysis using R, Matlab, etc. There is some reasonably comprehensive documentation at Documentation. </p>

<p>A beta of version 0.3 is now available. As of this release, the software has been renamed to &quot;Ibex&quot; (&quot;Internet Based EXperiments&quot;). Documentation for this release is at Documentation03. This new version is significantly easier to deploy, since it requires only  Python &gt;= 2.3 and the modules that are bundled with it (the dependency on the &quot;paste&quot; module has been removed). There are a few other minor user-visible improvements, but the main focus of 0.3 has been improving the code structure using jQuery, and making it easier to automatically deploy Ibex (for the Ibex Farm). </p>

<p>The code is developed in a git repository (see Source).</p>

 title : The weebox Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>weebox是一个基于jquery的弹窗插件，一开始只是拿了一个modaldialog来用，但那位任兄写的支持太有限了，于是就着手修改代码，但改到后面，发现基本上看不到原来的代码了，只有css样式中几张背景图留下来了，我就改了个名字。  </p>

<p>欢迎加入QQ群:83404470 </p>

<p>DEMO网址:http://www.jsres.com/weebox/demo/weebox.html
<br/>论坛网址:http://bbs.jsres.com
<br/>使用webox0.1做的项目:http://www.9wee.com
<br/>使用webox0.3做的项目:http://www.xtowns.com
<br/>下载网址:http://www.jsres.com/weebox/download/weebox0.3.zip </p>

<p>它含有以下特性： </p>

<p>.支持多层弹窗 </p>

<p>.支持单一弹窗，即同ID弹窗在打开第二次使用时，前一个将被自动关闭，参考boxid选项 </p>

<p>.支持自定义样式，参考boxclass选项 </p>

<p>.解决IE中SELECT的问题，使用了bgiframe功能 </p>

<p>.支持拖动效果，通过draggable设置，参考draggable选项 </p>

<p>.支持内容来源方式Ajax, Selector(jQuery的), Text(直接内容) </p>

<p>.支持多种弹窗类型,参考type选项 </p>

<p>.支持自动关闭,参考timeout选项 </p>

<p>.支持遮照效果(modal弹窗)，参考modal选项 </p>

<p>.支持不同的显示位置，中间或者以某个元素为参照物，参考position选项 </p>

<p>.支持弹窗打开前(onopen)、点确认(onok)、点取消(oncancel)、关闭窗口(onclose)等的回调函数 </p>

<p>.支持打开后，重新设置标题(setTitle)、内容(setContent)、按钮等方法 </p>

<p>.支持只在弹窗内查找元素的方法:find(selector) </p>

<p>.支持打开和关闭时的动画效果，参考animate、showAnimate,hideAnimate选项 </p>

 title : The wordtube Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The wordTube Plugin creates your personal &quot;YouTube&quot; in wordpress. Together with the fantastic Flash Media Player from Jeroen Wijering you are able to very easily show your streaming videos. </p>

<p>wordTube supports the streaming video format (Format .flv or .swf),  sound files as MP3 and JPG, GIF or PNG grafic files.  With wordTube you can simply insert it into your blog with the  tag [ media id=x ] or as playlist [ playlist id=x ]. </p>

 title : The wxpita Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>WxPita is a a wrapper library for wxPython, which is itself a wrapper library for the wxWidgets cross-platform GUI framework. </p>

<p>WxPita has two main goals:  </p>

<p>Allow the structure of your layout code to correspond more closely to the structure of your GUI Allow event callbacks to be bound and defined in a single step By accomplishing these two goals, wxPita lets you write simpler, more maintainable GUI code. </p>

<p>Let&#39;s take a look at a simple example: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The code for this example: </p>

<p>from wxpita import *
<br/>import time</p>

<p>f = SizedFrame [
<br/>    Button(name=&#39;btn1&#39;, label=&#39;Button 1&#39;),
<br/>    Button(name=&#39;btn2&#39;, label=&#39;Button 2&#39;),
<br/>    TextCtrl(name=&#39;textc&#39;, style=&#39;te_multiline&#39;, expand=True, proportion=1),
<br/>]</p>

<p>@f.btn1.button_clicked
<br/>@f.btn2.button_clicked
<br/>def _(evt):
<br/>    text = &#39;You clicked on &quot;%s&quot; at %s\n&#39; % (
<br/>        evt.EventObject.GetLabel(), time.ctime())
<br/>    
<br/>    f.textc.AppendText(text)</p>

<p>f.Show(&quot;A Simple WxPita Example&quot;, size=(400,250))Compare with the equivalent code, written using wxPython: </p>

<p>import wx
<br/>import wxaddons.sized_controls as sc
<br/>import time</p>

<p>app = wx.PySimpleApp()
<br/>frame = sc.SizedFrame(None, title=&quot;A Simple WxPython Example&quot;)
<br/>panel = frame.GetContentsPane()</p>

<p>btn1 = wx.Button(panel, label=&#39;Button 1&#39;)</p>

<p>btn2 = wx.Button(panel, label=&#39;Button 2&#39;)</p>

<p>textc = wx.TextCtrl(panel, style=wx.TE_MULTILINE)
<br/>textc.SetSizerProps(expand=True, proportion=1)</p>

<p>def onclick(evt):
<br/>    text = &#39;You clicked on &quot;%s&quot; at %s\n&#39; % (
<br/>        evt.EventObject.GetLabel(), time.ctime())
<br/>    
<br/>    textc.AppendText(text)</p>

<p>btn1.Bind(wx.EVT_BUTTON, onclick)
<br/>btn2.Bind(wx.EVT_BUTTON, onclick)</p>

<p>frame.Show()
<br/>app.MainLoop()</p>

 title : The Sutri Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Sutri is a system for tests management. It does not deal directly with testing tools but enables you to manage tests, results and reports in a coherent way, without concerning about what tool is used to execute such tests.</p>
 summary : <p>Yay! MockA standalone mock object library for PHP 5 (based on jMock)Yay! Mock aims to be a test framework-independent mock object library with the most flexibility possible.  Based on jMock (Java) it makes expectations based on Invocation signatures rather than just on method names and/or call timings. </p>

<p>Mock objects only contain the methods of the original type they mock.  In other words, mock objects created with Yay! Mock do not have any expectation methods embedded inside them; instead they &quot;record&quot; invocations to the context in which they were created. </p>

<p>Yay! Mock encourages dependency injection and loose coupling without pushing you into corners of testing implementation details.  It works with any unit testing framework. </p>

<p>Particular features includeMock interfaces (preferred) or classes Object identities via type-hints remain integral Expect invocations based on signatures Specify return values for specific invocation signatures Specify actions to perform on specific invocation signatures Match signatures loosely based on various Matchers Expect invocations when the environment is in a specific state Expect sequences of Invocations Yay! Mock code (like jMock) is intended to be easy to learn and to understand when read.  The code written within test cases is very fluent and expressive. </p>

<p>The current development status is beta 3</p>
 title : The yaymock Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The 40tasks Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Walk Trough of Task Admin for 40 Websites </p>

<p>The admin team for the forty websites that make up 40 websites are Lucy, the owner and editor based in LOndon UK, Carol Ng and Susie both based in China. </p>

<p>Carol and Susie are studying for English and Public Relations masters degrees at university.  They both work 20 hours a week for 40 websites. </p>

<p>Before joining they had not done any webwork before. </p>

<p>UK culture and what UK consumers may want to see in a website is alien to them. </p>

<p>Yet they contribute 90% of 40 websites content every week. </p>

<p>This is how it works. </p>

<p>Lucy for each of the forty websites researches and sets-up tasks and lists the websites, serach terms, forums and user names, facebook, myspace and other social network contacts, scanned physical media where content can be found for each website. </p>

<p>Carol goto the 40 websites task admin website, login and then select a website from the menu on the home page. </p>

<p>She goes to the website task list page. </p>

<p>This page list tasks and sources of content for that particular website. </p>

<p>She clicks on the first task, &quot;Search google&quot; and then clicks sub-task &quot;use search term for tube reasons to be careful&quot;. </p>

<p>She does the tasks and adds the content to another database she has open, the content admin for 40 websites (Casper is working on this). </p>

<p>She then goes and clicks the next task and so on. </p>

<p>She then works out a new task so she adds it to the data base.  First the task as text written instruction then the url to click on.  She then adds several sub tasks consiting of search terms for the website, user name, password and specific threads. </p>

<p>She spends an hour going through the task list, finding content and adding it to this other database. </p>

<p>She also updates the task admin database when ever she finds a new source of content. </p>

<p>Some of the content she finds from memory as she is familiar with updating this particular website. </p>

<p>At the end of the hour she moves on to update anothe website. </p>

<p>And so it goes until she has done her 20 hours updating 20 websites. </p>

<p>Lucy checks the task database for every website to add new tasks and delete out of date or poorly performing tasks. </p>

<p>So as you can see the task admin database is a simple to do list that should take about a week to develop using active scaffold. </p>

<p>It can then be used to find and store the knowledge of where to find content from for the forty websites. </p>

<p>Specification </p>

<p>Data Model We have: </p>

<p>websites Tasks Sub Tasks Websites have the following information  as a minimum: </p>

<p>Name Description url Name of editor Name of sub editor Mission -  why we have a website and why anyone should bother visiting it Editors weekly comment - e.g. We need more content last week you only update 3 pages. I know you can do better than that Susie.  Lucy Tasks have the following information as a minimum: </p>

<p>Task e.g. goto facebook and pick out the best posting from the &quot;best chat up lines&quot; group and similar groups. Editors comments e.g. This tasks is working really well, good work - Lucy Sub Tasks have the following information as minimum: </p>

<p>content url user name password search term Description of content e.g. anything that looks new and interesting on the page. Comment All fields do not have to be filled in.  So a google search term would only have google as url and search term as e.g &quot;what annoys me&quot;, and description of new postings. </p>

<p>In addition to the tasks admin database Susie and Carol would have access to a google email account which contains &quot;Google alerts&quot; etc. </p>

<p>The point of the task admin database is that in accumulates knowledge so that if Susie leaves and Tracey takes over she can immediately see where to get content from for each website. </p>

<p>Controllers </p>

<p>CRUD (create, can&#39;t remember what R stands for look it up, Update, Delete) </p>

<p>Search and Navigation including nested AS </p>

<p>Views </p>

<p>Simple views that are easy to use</p>

 title : The acts-as-gradable Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The actsasreplica Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>With the current trend of offline applications and solutions as Joyent Slingshot or Rails2Exe to run a stand-alone offline client app written in Rails, we end up having a problem ahead of us: offline data gathering and synchronization back and forth to a main online server. </p>

<p>There is virtually no solution for that matter unless you use some proprietary and expensive package. Google Gears comes to mind but it acts more like a static client-side caching providing no real replication of data. So &#39;acts_as_replica&#39; was really made to scratch my own itch. </p>

<p>It was made for the scenario where you will have several clients working in an offline environment and then they&#39;ll connect at the end of the day to get new data from the server and also send back what it collected through out the day. </p>

<p>This is a very opinionated software, meaning that it was not made to cover every single synchronization scenario in the world, but small and mid-sized solutions should benefit. It uses HTTP to wire both peers and up until now formats the payload packages in YAML. </p>

<p>This plugin was very influenced by the plugin acts_as_syncable by Alex MacCaw. Actually I used his code as the initial structure but it&#39;s now very far departure from his original view. </p>

<p>This project was done under the support of my current employer, Surgeworks. I am not done yet, so this is a work in progress. Any collaboration and ideas will be welcome. </p>

<p>Read the HowToInstall, MustRead and HowToTest Wiki Pages for more information. And don&#39;t forget to download the Example Project so you can have a faster hands on.  </p>

<p>If you have any suggestions, doubts, ideas contact me at fabio.akita@surgeworks.com. </p>

<p>Apr, 3rd, 2008 - Moving to GitI am abandoning Subversion management. I will leave this homepage behind but the source code here is frozen. Newer updates will be only at Github. </p>

<p>http://github.com/akitaonrails/acts_as_replica/tree/master </p>

<p>I am very late updating this code, sorry for that, I will try to make it more user friendlier now. </p>

<p>Sep, 23th, 2007 - Lots of ChangesI just uploaded a batch of new features and bug fixes to the plugin. I finally had time to test it further and I am much more confident about it. </p>

<p>The Sync table was renamed to Replica - the daemons plugin seems to complain with this name Added RemoteMachine table. Now the handshake process exchange Machine IDs (UUID), and the new Replica table keeps track of each machine_id. That way, the transactions are no longer bound to a single User in a single client App. The same username can be used in any client installation and still be able to safely replicate data back and forth. The client and server no longer uses a timestamp (in the last_synced columns of User and RemoteClient) to track each others transaction log entry points. It has been replaced for a simple auto-increment integer number (the primary key for the new Replica table). syncable.yml was deprecated in favor of a SyncSetting singleton Model. You will have to create your own administration screen, though. It was asserted that SSL connection do works Created a proper script/generator instead of the old manual file copy operation. I deprecated the use of the old Engine plugin because it was too buggy with dependency loading. Added support for background jobs triggered through a controller. Sample controller and views included. It is cross platform as well. In nix I use the good ol&#39; system() call and in Win32, the Process.create method. You can control what&#39;s happening tailing the log/replica.log file Added experimental application self-upgrade. lib/daemons/upgrade.rb is a new background job that calls svn cleanup, svn update and rake db:migrate. That way the application can be updated remotely without direct SSH connection to the server Batch control was finalized and tested: the syncs_helper.rb now implements a run_sync method that controls run_upload and run_download. Each can read its local batch_limit settings (see SyncSetting). Then it can retrive XX number of rows at a time. This can be used to refine transfer using slow connections, so to avoid timeouts. Jul, 8th 2007 - New Project MemberI just added Marcus Derencius, a good friend of mine, as a contributor. He pointed out somethings that we could add to this project: </p>

<p>The User class is hardcoded. We need to make this configurable to allow for other authentication plugins that doesn&#39;t use a model named &#39;User&#39; Generate automated RDoc documentation Add support for Rake tasks. And actually Slingshot expects to find a :up and :down tasks in its GUI Devise some cronjob like scheduled task to actively check whether the network is on or not and automatically start replication in the background, thus avoiding having to replication too big packages only at the end of the day Put in some connection checking before starting the &#39;perform_sync&#39; process. If you start it without having the server part online, the client process simply hangs and you have to forcefully kill it. Jul, 17th 2007 - Merged with UserstampI realized that the vanilla Userstamp plugin doesn&#39;t work properly with this plugin. Until I devise a better way, I merged the userstamp.rb in the lib folder of the plugin. The belongs_to proxy method fails in some cases and the usage of the UUID can conflict as well. So delete the original userstamp plugin and use the one in this plugin.</p>

 title : The boundary-generator Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a simple geoprocessing tool that extracts adjacency information from a layer of polygons. The output is a polyline layer with one record for each border between each pair of neighboring polygons. </p>

<p>Download v. 0.1. </p>

<p>After downloading and installing, you can right-click on a new toolbox, choose &quot;Add -&gt; Tool&quot;, and select Boundary Generator under the &quot;MWSW Geoprocessing Tools&quot; group. You can also find MWSW Boundary Generator on the &quot;Index&quot; toolbox view. </p>

<p>Highly recommended: Send a blank email to mwsw-prod-announce-subscribe@googlegroups.com to receive announcements about this and other projects. (You can also sign up via the web). Your email address will never be shared with anyone. </p>

<p>Project status (alpha): </p>

<p>Generating boundaries works; initial spot checks are giving correct answers. Some of the Geoprocessing UI behavior isn&#39;t quite finished -- e.g., you must specify the output location yourself; the tool gives an erroneous validation error if you try to run it on a layer that isn&#39;t in your TOC. (Expect these to be fixed soon.)  The tool hasn&#39;t really been tested in a model builder / python scripting framework yet, and needs some adjustments to work well there. Project rationale: </p>

<p>It is a good demonstration project for custom programming geoprocessing tools in C#, as well as simple computational geometry &amp; spatial indexing techniques. It is robust and geometry based; the other extensions I&#39;ve come across for doing the same thing simply searched for line segments with identical endpoints (and would thus fail with partial overlaps, T junctions, numeric precision issues, and the like) or used polygon-polygon intersection to come up with polygon adjacency lists (but not accurate border lines), as described in this old article. This functionality is available without an ArcInfo license. (If you do have ArcInfo, you can use the offical Polygon To Line tool. I would be curious to see the results of a side-by-side comparison from someone with a license...) If you are still using ArcView 3.x, my (dated and not well-tested; beware!) Avenue script for doing the same thing is available at http://arcscripts.esri.com/details.asp?dbid=12786.</p>

 title : The genx Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionA plug in for text editors, such as TinyMCE and Yahoo&#39;s RTE that will allow one to: </p>

<p>it will plug into your HTML editor directly, so you don&#39;t have to cut and paste into your posts it has an extension architecture, so that you can make forms to create anything it has flexible AJAX forms (using InputEX) it has flexible client side JavaScript (using Trimpath) it&#39;s not limited to microformats -- it can generate RDFa or plain text or whatever it has a &quot;search front end&quot;, so that you don&#39;t have to tediously populate the forms yourself Please see our Wiki for more info, or SVN download the source yourselves.  title : The grubby Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Grubby is a framework to help you quickly generate random (or pseudo random) data to use for testing, etc.  The data can be generated in the form of SQL INSERTs, CSV, or LDIF. </p>

<p>Why does it not just load the data directly?  When you have lot of data to upload (e.g. for performance testing with real world volumes) then this can simply take too long.  If you have files which contain your data then you can use the optimised tools which come with your datastore to do the loadnig for you.  Much nicer. </p>

<p>If you want to help out, please contact me.  Otherwise,happy loading!</p>

 title : The jsf-toolkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The JSF Toolkit is a full-cycle component creation, management, and delivery framework for JSF 1.2. The JSF-Tk seeks to be a model for the implementation of components with the goals of interoperability and AJAX framework independence, while simultaneously integrating seamlessly and automatically with the developer&#39;s chosen framework and JSF implementation. </p>

<p>News30 Oct 2007 - We&#39;re an open source project! Yay! Seeking developers, users, and fans. Please let us know on the mailing list if you&#39;ve tried it, and what your experience was. Thanks! </p>

<p>Why do I need a framework for developing JSF components?To answer that question, first decide: What kind of component developer are you? </p>

<p>Experienced Web Developer - 0 Experience with JSF or Java. You know CSS, Javascript, etc. pretty well. You can do amazing things with DHTML.  Probably you use a Mac, although if you don&#39;t, you probably want one.  You somehow heard about this JSF thing and that it had reusable components and liked the idea of having one of your creations be used by thousands of web sites. JSF Application Developer - You use JSF to produce web applications, you&#39;ve never written a custom component, but you&#39;re otherwise pretty familiar with JSF. You&#39;re here because you want to reuse code and make your application more maintainable. Experienced Component Developer - You&#39;ve written JSF components and generally know what you&#39;re doing.  You&#39;re here because you&#39;re tired of the tedium that goes into creating a component.  You want to be able to prototype, create, and deliver custom components more quickly.  You also want to ensure that your components are usable with a variety of JSF frameworks, toolkits and other component libraries. It may be that you&#39;re somewhere in between as well.  That&#39;s fine, all our lessons move incrementally, so you can find a level you&#39;re comfortable with. </p>

<p>How do I use this thing?Choose a guide </p>

<p>Component Developer - You want to create components. Read the NewComponentDeveloperGuide. Component User - You just want to use one or more components created with the JSF Toolkit in your application. (UsersGuide coming soon)</p>
 title : The System of Sales of Service of Transport Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The kvframework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Important NoteThis project has changed names and moved to http://krai.googlecode.com. Please update your bookmarks. </p>

<p>WelcomeKvFramework is a framework for developing PHP applications using an MVC-like style. It includes a custom, extensible database interface, the beginnings of some markup generators, a not-un-sophisticated router for use with mod_rewrite specifically, and servicable input scrubbing by default. </p>

<p>The GitRepository currently has a branch of somewhat stable code. Although there are directions in the ReadMe on how to get it running (in theory), things are not currently well documented (though Documentation does exist). There is a 2.0 beta 6 release available for download at the moment. Hopefully I will move that up to a full release when the documentation improves. Additionally, in the 2.0 beta 5 release, a DemoApplication is included as an example. If you have any problems, please contact the project developer(s) or the mailing list if you want to try and get a copy running. </p>

<p>This code is currently used in the Hall of Kvasir website, as well as the forthcoming updates to KvScheduler. </p>

<p>Help WantedIf you would like to contribute to the project (documentation writers especially wanted) just e-mail gsmcwhirter@gmail.com and we can talk.</p>

 title : The lacertae Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Update November 17th, 2009 It seems that I have overestimated PHP. It doesn&#39;t have support for 64 bit integers built in. I&#39;m currently working out some test cases to see how well this project works. I will make a beta release with some documentation on the shortcomings as soon as I have something worthwhile.  </p>

<p>Update November 2nd, 2009 Project has stagnated for a long time, but I&#39;ve decided to give it a try again. I&#39;ve implemented support for java generics and some other stuff. Right now I&#39;m working for fixing bugs and releasing a beta. </p>

<p>Note: This is a very short introduction to what Lacerate does. Look in the wiki for a longer example. This is out of date, but the general idea is the same. </p>

<p>This is a code generation tool that is supposed to simplify your life when wanting to create a PHP back-end for your GWT application. </p>

<p>Given the following service interface:  </p>

<p>package client.rpc.services;</p>

<p>import client.rpc.beans.Message;</p>

<p>import com.google.gwt.user.client.rpc.RemoteService;</p>

<p>public interface EchoService extends RemoteService {
<br/>    public String echoMessage(Message message);
<br/>}And this POJO: </p>

<p>package client.rpc.beans;</p>

<p>import com.google.gwt.user.client.rpc.IsSerializable;</p>

<p>public class Message implements IsSerializable {
<br/>    private String contents;</p>

<p>    public String getContents() {
<br/>        return contents;
<br/>    }</p>

<p>    public void setContents(String contents) {
<br/>        this.contents = contents;
<br/>    }
<br/>}You configure the code generation tool&#39;s default.properties file like so: </p>

<p>java.source.path=E:/java/gwt-windows-1.4.60/LacertaeDemo/src
<br/>java.output.path=E:/java/gwt-windows-1.4.60/LacertaeDemo/src</p>

<p>java.beans.package=client.rpc.beans
<br/>java.services.package=client.rpc.services</p>

<p>java.jsonizers.package=client.rpc.jsonizers
<br/>java.proxies.package=client.rpc.proxies</p>

<p>php.output.path=E:/tmp/xampplite/htdocs/LacertaeDemoThe code generation tool will create an abstract Proxy class that looks like this: </p>

<p>package client.rpc.proxies;</p>

<p>import [...];</p>

<p>public abstract class EchoServiceProxy {
<br/>    public EchoServiceProxy(String serviceUrl) {
<br/>        [...]
<br/>    }</p>

<p>    public final Request echoMessage(Message message) {
<br/>        [...]
<br/>        /* Code to serialize function arguments, send
<br/>        request to server, parse reply and call the correct
<br/>        callback method */
<br/>    }</p>

<p>    public void echoMessageSuccess(String result) {
<br/>        GWT.log(&quot;method is not implemented echoMessageSuccess&quot;, new Throwable());
<br/>    }</p>

<p>    public void echoMessageFailure(Throwable exception) {
<br/>        GWT.log(&quot;echoMessageFailure&quot;, exception);
<br/>    }</p>

<p>}It will also generate on the PHP side the following abstract service: </p>

<p>Now you need to write an implementation for the PHP service: </p>

<p>contents;
<br/>    }
<br/>}</p>

<p>$impl = new EchoServiceImpl();
<br/>print EchoService::serviceRequest($impl);</p>

<p>?&gt;You also need to provide an implementation for the callback method: </p>

<p>public class LacertaeDemo implements EntryPoint {</p>

<p>    public void onModuleLoad() {
<br/>        final Button button = new Button(&quot;Click me&quot;);</p>

<p>        button.addClickListener(new ClickListener() {
<br/>            public void onClick(Widget sender) {
<br/>                String url = &quot;http://localhost/LacertaeDemo/impl/EchoServiceImpl.php&quot;;</p>

<p>                EchoServiceProxy proxy = new EchoServiceProxy(url) {
<br/>                    public void echoMessageSuccess(String result) {
<br/>                        Window.alert(result);
<br/>                    }
<br/>                };</p>

<p>                Message message = new Message();
<br/>                message.setContents(&quot;hello, world&quot;);
<br/>                
<br/>                proxy.echoMessage(message);
<br/>            }
<br/>        });</p>

<p>        RootPanel.get(&quot;slot1&quot;).add(button);
<br/>    }
<br/>}Important </p>

<p>You need to modify your Module.gwt.xml file by by adding the HTTP and JSON dependencies like so: </p>

<p>    
<br/>  
<br/>  </p>

<p>    </p>

<p>So now you run the whole thing, click the button and you should see &quot;hello, world&quot;.</p>

 title : The monoquery Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Note: This project is still in active development, but it has moved to Github </p>

<p>Queriac (codenamed monoquery) is a free online tool that allows you to manage your quicksearches, shortcuts, and bookmarklets by taking them out of your browser profile and onto the web, making them portable, taggable, shareable, and generally easier to manage. Drawing from the concept of YubNub and extending it in the spirit of del.icio.us, Queriac effectively turns your browser’s address bar into a flexible command line. </p>

<p>To start using Queriac head over to http://queri.ac and create an account. It&#39;s free and easy. </p>

 title : The pmsoftware Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pm for local software a  daf dsaf safdsf sdf, </p>
 summary : <p>You have found the code base for Php On Rails (kinda) Generator aka PORK.Generator </p>

<p>If you download and run this project, you will see a list of all the databases in your connected MySql database. You can explore all the connections in the tables. If you have set up your database using primary auto increment keys and use these keys througout your database for links, it will recognize what type of relation you mean (1:1, many:1, 1:many, many:many) and you can instantly create classes and plugins for cut-n-paste, or download an entire CRUD backend application zipped up and ready to deploy. </p>

<p>There is also a feature that generates a GraphViz representation of your database.</p>

 title : The spasmoidal Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The SpasmodicEngine selects tasks (spasmoids) from a (heapqueue based) priority queue. The tasks are Python 2.5 extended generators (some call them coroutines: PEP 342). The engine calls task.send() with an appropriate argument. One of the library of  tasks is Pollster. Pollster calls poll() with for tasks that are waiting I/O. Tasks that are ready for I/O are fed to the priority queue.</p>

<p>Spasmodic provides an efficient way to manage a large number of    sockets and/or files. Other processing works well too, if it can be subdivided into brief spasms.</p>

<p>Download from:
<br/>http://www.python.org/pypi/spasmoidal/0.1.1</p>

 title : The cavendish Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Cavendish is ambitious project which goal is to create Standard model of particle physics Framework and Reaction engine that simulate chemical reactions with level of transformations of elementary particles.Project has two phases.  </p>

<p> First phase goal is to create ultimate model of Standard Model of particle physics.  This will be the Framework that includes all known and  hypothetical particles with their properties, behaviours  and functions.  </p>

<p> In second phase we will design sophisticated &quot;Reaction Engine&quot;  on top of Standard Model Framework (SMF). Reaction Engine  is big challenge, it must virtualise chemical reactions as  they are and act in nature and in laboratories.  Best way to do that without modelling a lot of chemical rules  is to think reactions like transformations of particles. </p>

<p>     Name of project is tribute to Cavendish Laboratory and their creat history with the Particle physics, even more name is tribute to Henry Cavendish whose findings about physics area are notable.</p>

 title : The Solar Wind Delay Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Programs to download and work with satellite measurements, calculate solar wind (SW) propagation time and compare data to other satellites. It uses and compares different modern techniques to determine the SW planar structures orientation.</p>

 title : The BiGZiP Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>BiGZiP is a graphically rich, Java based compression tool. It is developed around a user interface that is easy and intuitive to navigate. It fully supports zip compression and allows for the development of new compression schemes via it&amp;#8217;s APIs</p>
 title : The darkgdkoop Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>NEWSVersion 2.0 - Lights and Effects Revisited. Lib organized to compile demos faster.  Version 3.0 - Now Available (NOT Open Source) on Jegas, LLC web site. OverviewThe JGC Library is a collection of integrated C++ object oriented classes that can assist you in making 2D and 3D games. Its designed to work with Microsoft Visual Studio 2008 Free Edition (Or Enterprise with some changes perhaps), The Game Creators&#39; DarkGDK Game Engine, The Game Creators&#39; Dark Physics Product (optional), and the freely available &quot;Sparky&#39;s DLL&quot; (optional but recommended).      </p>

<p> theGameCreators - aka TGC - http://www.thegamecreators.com   DarkGDK - C++ Game Development SDK - http://gdk.thegamecreators.com/  Dark Physics - aka DP - http://darkphysics.thegamecreators.com/   Paul Johnson&#39;s (Sparky&#39;s) Collision DLL - aka Sparky&#39;s:http://forum.thegamecreators.com/?m=forum_view&amp;t=74762&amp;b=5  Ageia PhysX - http://www.ageia.com </p>

<p>DetailsThe Game Creators recently released the DarkGDK C++ library for freeware creations - at no cost and it&#39;s obtainable via the link above for it.  </p>

<p>NOTE: JGC Library is free and open source. </p>

<p>NOTE: DarkGDK is not free for commercial applications. (e.g. To sell a game you make) there is a special license fee required that needs to be paid to The Game Creators (aka TGC).  </p>

<p>Prerequisites Microsoft Windows XP or Vista  DirectX 9.0c Aug 2007 SDK  Microsoft Visual Studio 2008 C++ Express or Other  DarkGDK Game Development Kit - From theGameCreators Optional DarkPhysics - From theGameCreators  Sparky&#39;s Collision DLL InstallationDownload the archive, unarchive the download, open JegasLLC.sln (Microsoft Visual Studio 2008 Solution File), from the Visual Studio Tree, open a branch of any demo, click green run arrow, it should compile and run for you. </p>

<p>Developer NotesRead the release notes! Each Demo has a !readme.txt and there is an extensive one in both the GameClasses and FoundationClasses Projects that more or less map out this development system. </p>

<p>Every effort has been made to try and write neat, efficient, and human readbale code.  There are some things that would be considered not main stream. In short, I wrote my own versions of classes that are available in the STDLIB and they have been performing solidly, so I&#39;m sticking with them.  </p>

<p>ALL COMMENTS Welcome - and I have a &quot;Self Tester&quot; for the FoundationClasses project where the idea is without such a tool for these core routines and classes it can be much harder to understand where something has gone wrong. This self tester tells you if the FoundationClasses are intact and working as epected. This self tester&#39;s source code also serves as a good demo/tutorial program to see how things work. </p>

<p>JGC Library comes with a small subset of media so you actually see something when it compiles for you. I really was trying to keep the media down as previous releases it was just to much for people to download to just &quot;take&#39;r for a spin&quot;. </p>

<p>Note, development has been ongoing for some time and this library is starting to mature. It&#39;s not a finished system, however its PACKED with easy to use and understand classes for almost all the major entities in DarkGDK -- and some new additional surprises are in there for those who dig in. Like Bitmap Fonts, a DirectX Rendered GUI, The JMesh and VMesh &quot;terrain systems&quot; and some others. </p>

<p>Let me know what ya think! JasonPSage # jegas com Enjoy!  --Jason Peter Sage</p>
 summary : <p>2d side scrolling sdl engine with d physics engine</p>

 title : The Feature Diagrams Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The evolve-the-balls Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewHmm... not so much anymore. Moved onto relearning that whole web thing: </p>

<p>http://www.shareplaylearn.net/ </p>

<p>Been a few years.. (5-6).. odd what&#39;s changed and what hasn&#39;t.. </p>

<p>This is now mainly offsite storage of the site&#39;s code. Nothing exciting, just learning AppEngine and GWT (which is exciting, if my code is not :P). Note that the website code is NOT covered by the same license as the project code. </p>

<p>Keeping this stuff just coz: </p>

<p>Create a 3D world of evolving creatures. (yet another one) </p>

<p>Runs evolver, interpreter, physics as separate processes that talk to each other via sockets. Client does rendering, and possibly physics. Hope to factor out physics to separate process. </p>

<p>Currently the system evolved is an lsystem, and it is interpreted as a sequence of points in 3D space. </p>

<p>Note that the Source tab is now irrelevant: all code drops are done via downloads, and the tree is no longer updated. This is due to the fact that I use git on my local machine for version control, and it is rather awkward to try to use two different version control systems for the same code. </p>

<p>Works on linux with Ogre, ODE, OIS, and boost. </p>

<p>For more info see: </p>

<p>evolve blog intro] most recent blog] </p>

<p>gmail  </p>

<p>-stu26code 
<br/>-not checked terribly often</p>
